column2: the writer Joseph Campbell sat down with interviewer Bill Moyers for a lengthy discussion about Campbell‚Äôs ideas on comparative mythology and the ongoing role of myth in human society. The interviews were edited and reduced to six one-hour episodes. Each were broadcasted on PBS in 1988
column3: shortly after Campbell‚Äôs death

column1: Afterwards
column2: the transcript of the entire unedited conversation was published in a book called ‚ÄòThe Power of Myth‚Äô. The book is a true spectacle
column3: a roaring celebration of human history and experience; the depth of Campbell‚Äôs knowledge was remarkable and the enthusiasm in his words bring joy to the hearts of all. It is one of few books that I find myself returning to repeatedly.

column1: The most rewarding part of the discussion
column2: the part that brings the most impact deals with the idea of living a fulfilling life
column3: or
column4: as Campbell would put it
column5: ‚Äòfollowing your bliss‚Äô. During the interview
column6: Campbell quotes from Sinclair Lewis‚Äô novel ‚ÄòBabbit‚Äô:

column1: ‚ÄòBabbit‚Äô tells the story of a man who is dissatisfied with the promises of ‚ÄòThe American Dream‚Äô. He feels empty in his home town called Zenith

column1: And so
column2: Babbit tries to pursue a meaningful life through various acts of nonconformity and deviance. The novel shows how he eventually
column3: after many failed disgruntled wanderings
column4: returns to tired conformity; however
column5: Babbitt never quite loses hold of the sentiment that there awaits a life more meaningful and fulfilling that he has yet to grasp.

column1: Babbit
column2: Campbell believed
column3: is a character who has never experienced what it is like to be truly alive; he is a man who has never lived with rapture
column4: a man not conscious of himself
column5: nor aware of the great fire that he holds within himself.

column1: The ‚Äòfollow your bliss‚Äô philosophy attributed to Campbell after the original broadcast of The Power of Myth comes from the Hindu Upanishads
column2: a collection of ancient texts of religious and philosophical nature
column3: written in India probably between c. 800 BCE and c. 500 BCE.

column1: Campbell studied such texts with great persistence and passion when he was a young man. Indeed
column2: before he became a professor
column3: he lived in a small
column4: rented shack in Woodville
column5: New York
column6: and consumed his days engaged in rigorous and intensive independent study
column7: reading ancient scriptures and mythology of all kinds
column8: from across the globe. This routine carried on for five years before he became a teacher at Sarah Lawrence College. Clearly
column9: Campbell had found his own bliss in the study of myths and folklore.

column1: He came across the idea of bliss when he was learning the language of Sanskrit. Sanskrit is an ancient Indian language and it is the predominant language of most works of Hindu philosophy as well as some of the principal texts of Buddhism and Jainism. Here
column2: Campbell highlights three words that carried Campbell to the idea of bliss:

column1: ‚ÄòThere are three terms that represent the brink
column2: the jumping-off place to the ocean of transcendence: Sat
column3: Chit
column4: Ananda. The word ‚ÄòSat‚Äô means being. ‚ÄòChit‚Äô means consciousness. ‚ÄòAnanda‚Äô means bliss or rapture.‚Äô

column1: He follows this explanation by showing how he used these three words to guide his own life
column2: ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt know whether my consciousness is proper consciousness or not; I don‚Äôt know whether what I know of my being is my proper being or not; but I do know where my rapture is. So let me hang on to rapture
column3: and that will bring me both my consciousness and my being.‚Äô

column1: And so
column2: Campbell held onto his love of mythology and religion with faith that his bliss would guide him to where he was supposed to be. This willingness to live with the questions
column3: to bathe in uncertainty was indeed daring. But
column4: for Campbell
column5: the adventure of living alongside his bliss was its own gift.

column2: Campbell accepted a position as Professor of Literature at Sarah Lawrence College. In the Power of Myth
column3: he explained how the school used a system whereby each student was assigned a teacher to talk with for half an hour about how they were getting along. This meeting occurred once every two weeks.

column1: And Campbell would ask his students about each of their classes
column2: what kind of books they had been reading and what they enjoyed outside of their classes. The school was trying to speed up the process of self-discovery because they understood that their reputation depended on the consciousness of their students.

column1: During the conversation
column2: Campbell
column3: quite suddenly
column4: touched upon a particular topic that caused the student‚Äôs eyes to light up and widen with enthusiasm. In an instant
column5: the student sat up and began talking with eagerness and emotion
column6: sometimes so fast they forgot to breathe. Life had reignited within the spirit.

column1: This short meeting served as a sacred space for the students
column2: a chamber that allowed for uninterrupted reflection and personal discovery
column3: without haste or pressure. Such a meeting encouraged the students to move within
column4: to scramble amongst their depth and question who they really were.

column1: But this meditation requires a state of reflective solitude
column2: a peaceful harmony where no one is able to speak into your thoughts
column3: telling you what is or what is not the truth. And Campbell allowed his students this sacred space by only asking questions
column4: never twisting their answers
column5: and allowing them time to think through their hearts
column6: to reach into their true self
column7: even permitting the students to go home and think about the question more thoroughly before returning the following week. Over time

column2: then
column3: allows you the freedom to feel the vibrations of your own soul and the direction it wants to carry you towards. It is in solitude that you are able to hear the little patters of intuition that are trying to tell you where your bliss might lay.

column1: The students
column2: by speaking about a topic that fulfilled them
column3: opened their hearts and revealed a small glimpse into who they truly are. They unfastened their arms and
column4: entirely defenceless
column5: touched upon a consciousness that no sensible person ought to get themselves involved with.

column1: For a brief moment

column3: and entered into a world of their own
column4: singing the chorus of their spirit. And Campbell sincerely hoped his students would hang onto this rapture with all their love. For life and possibility had opened up to the student when they had allowed this love to wash over them.

column3: that you have discovered what has been waiting for you all this time. Those who know better understand that they ought to trust this feeling even when
column4: especially when

column1: And this love belongs to you ‚Äî it exists for no one else but you. It cannot be taught

column4: as you are also. For love only serves as a reflection into yourself. You cannot find it everywhere

column1: You only discover its power when you see some part of yourself in another that you did not recognise before. And when you discover this love
column2: this shattering rapture
column3: you also discover yourself. Hang onto this passion and
column4: Campbell believed

column1: You are not your own puppet

column3: a belonging
column4: a desire to understand what you are. And you pursue this yearning with great pain and frustration. You will fall over

column8: following
column9: with a great appetite
column10: that which calls your name

column1: This is your calling

column3: your deepest burden. But you refuse such a duty at your own peril. Because you are not merely following your bliss

column1: And if you just follow your heart

column2: I obliged. He said he‚Äôd told this person about me

column4: he hadn‚Äôt so much as breathed a word to this person about me.

column3: even the scary green eyed monster of jealousy

When I started out in polyamorous communities
column2: I was immediately drawn to those ‚Äòexperienced‚Äô people who seemed confident in what they were doing. Those people were not only attractive to me but seemed like the best bet. Obviously confident people communicate clearly
column3: right? Obviously when you‚Äôre just starting out in something
column4: someone who has. had loads of relationships and many partners is a ‚Äòsafe‚Äô bet
column5: right?

column1: Wrong.
Unfortunately
column2: I found that confident people made me feel like I was being heard and listened to but that was rarely actually the case. Confident people can make you feel special and looked after

column4: these people
column5: in my experience
column6: are rarely up for the task. Their ability to make you feel special is part of that confidence

column1: Not to mention
column2: just because someone has had many relationships
column3: doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre better at them. Relationships aren‚Äôt a game where playing gives you more experience. It‚Äôs about an individual exchange and if they have always come up a little short handed

column1: Another thing that beginner non-monogamous sources fail to really discuss is the fact that non-monogamous setups where an individual doesn‚Äôt spend a long time with any one individual but sees them rarely can allow for people who would normally be toxic and difficult to be around to have plenty of ‚Äòfunctional‚Äô relationships. column2: you don‚Äôt necessarily see or have to deal with some of the more dubious aspects of their personality.

column1: So sometimes having more partners than you know what to do with isn‚Äôt inherently a sign that you‚Äôre amazing at non-monogamy and beginners shouldn‚Äôt assume so.
Most relationship advice for anyone regardless of relationship style often boils down to this: Talk to your partner.
Like most advice
column2: it‚Äôs much easier to give than it is to follow. And what non-monogamous beginner resources fail to really take into account is that communication is actually really really hard
column3: but not for the reasons they assume.

column1: As an autistic person
column2: recognising my own emotions and understanding them can be really difficult. As a person with an anxiety disorder
column3: my immediate response to my own fear is to not take it seriously or examine it with a fine toothed comb. And when embarking on something that you‚Äôre completely new to
column4: sometimes you don‚Äôt really know or understand what you need until you‚Äôre not getting it and it hurts.

column1: Pain is the body‚Äôs way of telling us something is wrong. And sometimes you have to experience emotional pain before you really understand that you have a boundary or you have a need that isn‚Äôt being met.
But admitting to your partner that you have a need can be an extremely emotionally vulnerable place. Most beginner non-monogamous resources are written
column2: usually
column3: by white people who more likely than not come from a specific socio-economic background. It‚Äôs not to say that white middle class people never have any problems
column4: but I usually find that if you‚Äôve been treated poorly systemically by society or have a history of being abused
column5: it can be really difficult to feel comfortable enough to be vulnerable with anyone.

column1: I found myself in my relationships trying to manipulate situations so that I got what I really wanted without having to ask for it because asking directly for something you need and being told by someone you care for greatly that they refuse to do it is absolutely gut-wrenchingly horrifying. And the greater my need for any one thing
column2: the less likely I was to ask directly for it.

column1: Imagine if you were heading to a funeral at the same time your partner wanted to go to an event that they were excited about. Imagine asking directly for your partner to be there for you at the funeral and having your partner either say no to you or seeing them huff at the idea of supporting you in a vulnerable place in your life. Even if it‚Äôs not directly a cause for breakup
column2: having such an important need be either not met or complained about by your partner can damage the intimacy you feel with them. If you can‚Äôt be vulnerable and ask for help from them... then it begs the question of what your partnership is.

column1: Talking to your partner is scary. Asking for something you need is scary. And especially because we live in a society that encourages us all to be independent beings that don‚Äôt need anybody
column2: especially if you‚Äôve been encouraged by society to see yourself as ‚Äòclingy‚Äô or worry about being so
column3: and especially because non-monogamous resources reinforce the idea that you shouldn‚Äôt need anyone too much
column4: it can be that much harder to want anything from anybody.

column1: I wrote about how a relationship is not a skill in great detail
column2: but to summarise
column3: I often believed
column4: like many monogamous people even do

column2: blocked me on all forms of social media. column2: as nice and as great at they are at communicating

column1: I‚Äôd read so much information about non-monogamy before I started that I felt like I knew exactly how to handle things. And my first experience being negative
column2: I approached things with a sense that I‚Äôd even learned well from that. One of the things I insisted on after my first experience was trying to be friends with my partner‚Äôs partners.

column3: no jealousy
column4: no negative emotions

column1: And this level of happiness is not expected within monogamy. In fact
column2: in monogamy an unhappy marriage is almost expected. Countless male identified comedians have made entire careers over the idea that marriage and sexual monogamy is the end of their ‚Äòfun‚Äô and although monogamy (read: heterosexual
column3: white monogamy) is a standard encouraged by this society
column4: the idea that it‚Äôs not a picnic and not always fun and happy is also something that‚Äôs widely accepted.

column1: And yet
column2: non-monogamous people
column3: because people so often blame a failed open relationship on opening it up in the first place and assume that it fails because non-monogamous relationships don‚Äôt work

I‚Äôve seen countless people in polyamorous communities feel so anxious by the idea that their forum is filled with people confused and asking for help that they post positive and happy stories to almost reassure the outside world. Monogamous people are allowed to be unhappy and that not reflect badly on monogamy necessarily

column3: not so.

column1: This pressure on me to be happy with my partner‚Äôs other relationships and to be friends with metamours (the people your partner dates) made me anxious and unhappy. I forced myself to socially interact with people beyond my personal means.

column1: Furthermore
column2: I felt like my indifference to my partner‚Äôs romantic exploits made me heartless and even somehow ‚Äòjealous‚Äô. And in fact
column3: listening to details of my partner‚Äôs exploits stood my hair on end ‚Äî not because I was jealous or bothered ‚Äî but because the fear that I would become jealous was so intense it made me just as uncomfortable as jealousy would ‚Äî maybe even MORE uncomfortable. Obviously
column2: yeah
column3: if we were to be friendly and when I am friendly with a metamor it is nice... but forcing myself to be friends with anyone in any situation is never comfortable and that‚Äôs just fine.

column1: Compersion isn‚Äôt compulsory.
Non-monogamous beginners hear multiple times a day that ‚Äòlove is infinite‚Äô and it‚Äôs not necessarily wrong. While you may be able to love an infinite number of people

And this can get lonely. Especially if you‚Äôre in the very likely scenario that one person has loads of dates and the other doesn‚Äôt. It can get sad. And I think we spend so much time trying to stay happy for our partner that we shove this loneliness down
column2: don‚Äôt talk about it

column4: ‚Äòoh no

column1: Monogamy
column2: specifically heterosexual monogamy
column3: is encouraged by the society we live in. And when you‚Äôre just starting out having open relationships
column4: you can feel a bit isolated. You will have experiences where people will judge you for it (specifically if you‚Äôre read as female) and a lot of times people can feel this combination where they are shunned by society

column1: You get a lot of mixed messages as a beginner in non-monogamous communities: It‚Äôs more natural than monogamy and yet it‚Äôs scorned and hated and yet it‚Äôs seen as ‚Äòcool‚Äô and ‚Äòhip‚Äô. And that in turn can make things somewhat confusing
column2: especially when the same sorts of conventions you see in monogamy seem to be still at play within non-monogamy.

column1: For example
column2: in a lot of non-monogamous settings I know
column3: I see a lot of self-identified women in polyamorous families doing the majority of the child rearing or sharing child rearing between women partners while the men go out and do what they‚Äôd like. I see a lot of women stretching themselves providing emotional support for multiple people and getting nothing for themselves. I see a lot of situations where older men are using non-monogamy as an example of their ‚Äòfeminism‚Äô
column4: dating multiple people who are much younger than they are and no one in their actual age bracket. You‚Äôll find a lot of convention within unconventionality.

column1: Also
column2: I find that people tend to have selective memories about history. Even within monogamous people
column3: you have this concept that 50s era 2.5 kids with picket fences zeitgeist family is ‚Äòtraditional‚Äô and has been happening for years and years ‚Äî but this just isn‚Äôt true.

column1: Romantic love and the idea that it‚Äôs not a sickness that needs to be cured is a relatively new idea in human history. Marriage being a symbol of love and not an exchange of property between families is a relatively new idea. Partnerships in life in decades past were not usually about love and sex
column2: they were about wealth and power.

column1: And in some cases even today people practice arranged marriage situations which aren‚Äôt necessarily problematic whereby a marriage is secured and a partnership forms out of a common need rather than what we would consider ‚Äòtypical‚Äô now of two individuals meeting and falling in love.

And ‚Äòaffairs‚Äô have not historically been a problem. Having multiple ‚Äòpartners‚Äô within socially sanctioned monogamy has been possible for wealthy men for hundreds of years. Maybe someone had a ‚Äòmarriage‚Äô
column2: but that has never always meant sexual exclusivity. Or even if it has
column3: that sexual exclusivity has purely been imposed on the person read as a woman within that exchange ‚Äî but very rarely for the men.

column1: Not to mention
column2: so many beginner non-monogmous guides are written from the perspective that the nuclear family was a reality for all of the individuals reading it while many poor and immigrant individuals may have never had that experience or expectation. Living jointly with family members
column3: especially elders
column4: is a common practice for a lot of people. So this idea that non-monogamy is defying all of the traditional conventions... well
column5: it just isn‚Äôt.

column1: Which is not to say feelings of loneliness aren‚Äôt valid or that there aren‚Äôt people who genuinely will dislike you for being non-monogamous. I will say though that ‚Äòopen relationships‚Äô aren‚Äôt necessarily completely unknown to mainstream culture and although there may be many misconceptions about them
column2: there is yet to be a slur developed specifically for non-monogamous people.

column1: And in my experience the vast majority of individuals who experience negative consequences for dating multiple people tend to be experiencing those consequences because they are read as women. People read as men can be judged by other men for ‚Äúallowing‚Äù their wives to sleep with other men
column2: but this isn‚Äôt an anti-male consequence as the roots of this judgement stem from the idea that men need to be sexually dominant of the women they date and that women are subduing men by owning their own sexuality ‚Äî which is misogyny and ultimately about putting women back in their place

column1: So the point of this is that
column2: even while non-monogamy may be ‚Äòunconventional‚Äô

column1: Eurocentric/white societies in general reinforce the idea of the individual as more important. We are encouraged in many ways to shine on our own

column3: and not rely on others for help. Within non-monogamy

column1: The advice so often given to beginners about jealousy is that they have to work it out themselves. In many cases

column1: If jealousy is the scarlet ‚ÄòJ‚Äô of non-monogamy

column3: to challenge them and to reassure themselves that they are worthy and worthwhile.

column1: Insecurity is just that ‚Äî a lack of feeling secure. And when you‚Äôre starting a new relationship with someone
column2: you may feel very insecure about the relationship and what you mean to each other. That makes a lot of sense. Feeling insecure in that situation doesn‚Äôt mean you assume that the person you‚Äôre starting the relationship with doesn‚Äôt like you

column1: Likewise
column2: I‚Äôve seen so many situations where people are kicking themselves for feeling insecure in a relationship (and ‚Äòjealous‚Äô) when it‚Äôs totally rational for them to feel insecure.

column1: For example
column2: say one partner has repeatedly broken promises to the other and then found a new hookup and the other partner is insecure about the new hookup. And the entire reason for that is because their relationship isn‚Äôt stable. If you have a partner who is not doing anything to make you feel valued and wanted or is in fact proving that you aren‚Äôt valued through action
column3: you can tell yourself how awesome you are all you‚Äôd like ‚Äî it still won‚Äôt solve the actual problem or insecurity.

column1: Insecurity isn‚Äôt something that happens always because you hate yourself or you think you‚Äôre unworthy. An Olympic athlete could feel insecure about their performance but still understand that their athletic performance is above average. Someone can have 50 Oscars for their acting work but still feel insecure when they go to an audition. We fear the unknown. We fear bad things happening. And that fear can cause insecurity. And we often mistake fear and insecurity for jealousy when it isn‚Äôt.
Self-hate is when you tell yourself that you‚Äôre not good enough
column2: that your partners secretly hate you
column3: and all of the other negative things that people sometimes experience. And the solution to this is to try and talk to yourself positively and stop attacking yourself. And self-hate can and does indeed cause you to feel insecure in a lot of things
column4: relationships included. But not all insecurity is caused by self-hate.

column1: It‚Äôs complicated because if your partner

column1: I tend to take the Jack Sparrow approach to non-monogamy. The only rules that matter are these: What you can do and what you can‚Äôt do.
I can let my partners date whomever they like
column2: but I can‚Äôt say that if they were to date someone who‚Äôs been abusive and nasty to me it wouldn‚Äôt affect my feelings towards them.

column1: I can let my partners do whatever they‚Äôd like
column2: but I can‚Äôt pretend like missing my birthday or something that‚Äôs important to me wouldn‚Äôt make me upset.

column1: I can let my partners define their own boundaries
column2: but I can‚Äôt
column3: for example
column4: see my partner abuse or hurt someone else and pretend like I‚Äôm fine with that.

column1: Everyone has individual needs within their relationships
column2: and that goes for all things. Any parent would tell you that each kid they have (or even teacher) is different
column3: each individual needing different things. Sometimes you need different things from different people
column4: but those needs become your boundaries and things that you want to deal with.

column1: And part of the reason rules and hierarchies aren‚Äôt inherently bad is because they can help support those needs ‚Äî so long as you aren‚Äôt trying to control the uncontrollable.
So for example
column2: I enjoy doing domestic things with partners. I prefer to have a partner who lives with me and where we establish a life together
column3: maybe by getting a house together. The ideal type of non-monogamy that works for me is one where I have a ‚Äòprimary‚Äô partner I can trust to ask for emotional support and where I have other partners who are more casual and who would give the same amount of emotional support I would expect a friend to give me. This is what works for me and more or less is what works for my primary partner
column4: which is why we have that type of relationship.

column1: My partner does have more of a drive for casual relationships whereas I‚Äôm not as bothered if I don‚Äôt go out on a date for months. This is a situation that works for us both. And we communicate that to other people so we manage expectations. And in many cases
column2: both in my experience as a primary partner and as a secondary who‚Äôs been discarded the moment I became inconvenient
column3: having a clear understanding of expectations is what made things a lot better. Especially as an autistic person who needs clarity.

column1: The problem with rules and hierarchies and why so much of the beginner non-monogamy advice will rail against them is because often people use rules and hierarchies to solve other problems that rules cannot solve.

You‚Äôll often find situations where one person has convinced their partner to do non-monogamy and they create a hierarchy and rules (e.g. you can‚Äôt sleep with someone until I say you can or we can‚Äôt have dates until both of us have one) to try and protect themselves against the fear of the unknown. And that‚Äôs understandable but the problem with rules is that the more you make
column2: the more likely it will be that someone will forget and break one or that situations in life will create problems.

column1: What beginner non-monogamy advice should do instead of unilaterally saying all rules and hierarchies are bad is instead expand on those rules which are likely to blow up in people‚Äôs faces.
For example
column2: creating a rule that your partner has to check with you before sleeping with someone new is something I always advise against. Anything where one person gives ‚Äòpermission‚Äô creates a lot of pressure not only on the person giving permission to say yes to please their partner but also can create resentment if permission isn‚Äôt given.

column1: And sometimes when casual situations arise
column2: you may end up deciding to sleep with someone new at 1 AM in the morning
column3: in which case telling your partner that you‚Äôre going to sleep with someone new could create more problems than it can solve
column4: especially if your partner is having a rough day. Imagine missing your train
column5: spilling your lunch
column6: ruining an outfit
column7: missing your partner
column8: eating dinner alone and then being woken up at 1 AM by your partner calling to tell you they‚Äôre about sleep with someone else.

column1: Yeah. Not so great.

The fear behind making this rule is an attempt to try and make sure that partners check in with each other to make sure they‚Äôre okay. And that doesn‚Äôt need to happen just before and can happen after. Instead of making a rule to enforce this kind of behaviour
column2: what one should do is trying and create an atmosphere where your partner does check in with you
column3: regardless of new partners or not
column4: and makes sure your mental health is okay and where you feel comfortable telling your partner when it isn‚Äôt.

column1: A rule enforced like this will not automatically create that type of atmosphere
column2: so the rule isn‚Äôt going to help and may instead create more problems than it solves. I‚Äôd advise people to think about why they are making the rule and examine the reasoning behind it.

column1: Last but not least
column2: the advice so often not given to newbies is plainly: maybe non-monogamy just isn‚Äôt for you.

column1: A lot of beginner non-monogamy writing is made with rose tinted eye implants
column2: practically. Non-monogamy has a way of defying some of the things that are inherent but not exclusive to monogamy. Sometimes it can be freeing to feel like you can flirt without ‚Äòcheating‚Äô or do what you‚Äôd like. And that in turn makes people feel like non-monogamy is inherently better
column3: inherently more egalitarian
column4: inherently more socially progressive than monogamy.

column1: And it can get to the point where non-monogamous people refer to monogamy derisively
column2: almost blaming it instead of structures like misogyny and heterosexism for the way monogamy has kept them in a box.

column1: That in turn can make people feel like the only egalitarian
column2: ethical and socially progressive choice people can make IS non-monogamy. And like communism
column3: non-monogamy can seem great on paper
column4: but not work in practice for many people ‚Äî AND THAT IS OKAY.

column1: As I said before
column2: accepting non-monogamy means ultimately accepting that any one partner you have will not spend the entirety of their time and resources on you and visa versa. And maybe that‚Äôs not setup you want. Maybe that doesn‚Äôt work for you. Maybe having more people is just too complicated. Or maybe you‚Äôre just too damn tired to date more than one person.

column1: All of this is okay. Choosing monogamy doesn‚Äôt mean you choose everything that society can tack on with it. Choosing monogamy doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôll flip out if your partner notices someone else. It doesn‚Äôt mean you have a problem with your partner having sexual feelings or romantic feelings for someone else. Assuming that someone just being monogamous means they endorse society‚Äôs ideas about what monogamy should look like is a huge false equivalency.
That‚Äôs like me assuming as a non-binary person that any binary identified human being
column2: trans or cis
column3: automatically by identifying as a binary gender endorses everything that society tacks onto that gender ‚Äî and it‚Äôs just not true.

column1: You may try non-monogamy and find it isn‚Äôt what you want
column2: and that‚Äôs cool. It doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre backwards or want to live in the 50s. It may just mean it isn‚Äôt your cup of tea. And you‚Äôd think among ‚Äòunconventional‚Äô people
column3: even that would be tolerated but sometimes it isn‚Äôt.

column1: So that‚Äôs it. I‚Äôm sure there will be more when I think about it some more
column2: but for now
column3: if I had known this before I started out
column4: it would have saved me a lot of heartbreak and I‚Äôm hoping that for some beginners out there it helps them too.

column1: To any mind who approaches love with logic

column4: such as education
column5: hobbies
column6: or whatever it is that matters to you. My personal quirk for Tinder was that I was never going to swipe right on a man who had a picture of him holding a fish. For my lesbian friend
column7: no Geminis.

column1: The process afterwards seems logical too: you carry on conversations on whatever photos or small excerpts of your life you chose to share on your profile

column3: to either come to a natural end and start over in the process
column4: or

column2: ‚ÄúHow to Find the One for You‚Äù or ‚ÄúWhy Dating is a Necessity‚Äù on a weekly basis

column3: and then in real life
column4: and hope for something. Anything.

column1: The process is quite mechanical and the app hopping never stops; I don‚Äôt like hook-ups
column2: and soon found Tinder to not be the app for me. I‚Äôm not great at initiating conversations
column3: so Bumble was no-go either. My friend suggested the League; I did not find the appeal of a dating platform built to have an exclusive user base
column4: and didn‚Äôt have much interest. Finally a guy who sits near me at work suggested Hinge for more serious dating
column5: and that was my last dating app hop.

column1: I‚Äôm not sure if it‚Äôs myself personally or it‚Äôs just that everyone is in on the joke and I‚Äôm out of it ‚Äî but I have never hated any process more than that of online dating.
The frustrations seem so endless. For one
column2: you are
column3: in the end
column4: an easily replaceable being that exists on a non-physical medium to individuals who examine your profile. There‚Äôs often no sense of responsibility to you
column5: and this lack of responsibility extends to even when you finally meet each other in the physical presence. It is far too easy to lose someone in a large city
column6: someone who has no other connection to your circle than the tangential line of the dating app match
column7: free to extend to nothingness in your world. ‚ÄúGhosting‚Äù is too easy for you and the other person
column8: and even though you know it hurts
column9: you will do it too.

column1: All the good conversations that seem to die right on your phone; all the people you have had the pleasure or displeasure of meeting
column2: the period written by unmatching
column3: deleting
column4: or even blocking. The ease that allows one to terminate the fleeting connection right away
column5: because in the pool of open access to anyone
column6: it means that your time and presence is easily replaced by the next best option. And it isn‚Äôt just the person on the other end doing this; it is also myself
column7: looking at the messages that I have yet to reply to
column8: and feeling all too tired to think of another witty response
column9: and waiting for the next match that would inevitably come with time.

column1: Is online dating really that much less personal and impactful? I think about the individuals that I did develop feelings for. I met them through friends or some other random encounters
column2: and with repeated interactions I would have those moments ‚Äî those moments when I see them shine
column3: when I see them in their most tender form
column4: and felt myself fell for them. These were moments in contexts that I would have never really achieve with ease through someone I have met online. It‚Äôs through classrooms discussions
column5: through hanging out in a big group
column6: through the random moments when their presence become more than just a friend. In truth
column7: those people I developed feelings for
column8: I‚Äôd unlikely even match with them on dating apps. Because those prospects that matter most on the online platforms: physical appearance
column9: weird one-liners about your personality
column10: all of them rarely matter when I see the whole picture of the person.

column1: And maybe it is my fault that I feel like I‚Äôm walking to my personal guillotine each time I go on a date; I can‚Äôt seem to stop dreading the conversations
column2: and my own inability to be genuine. It‚Äôs difficult to not try to please the person on the other end. After all
column3: I know I am being assessed in that space
column4: for how suitable I may be as a romantic partner to them. So around when do I let them know all the details that may be important to them but not something I‚Äôm comfortable sharing right away ‚Äî like the fact that I‚Äôm pansexual
column5: still trying to come out to my parents
column6: but hey don‚Äôt worry
column7: that‚Äôs more of a just so you know fact
column8: because it doesn‚Äôt matter when I am with you and committed to you?

column1: Or the odd feeling of juggling going few dates a week
column2: having to lie when you schedule the next one because all your friends recommend you to ‚Äúkeep your options open‚Äù. Even though I know the other party is probably doing the same
column3: the guilt of dishonesty still catches on to me.

column1: The feeling of knowing you‚Äôre easily replaceable and so is the person in front of you
column2: the feeling of a mechanical routine of swiping left and right
column3: the feeling of a due time to reply to the person with the right message ‚Äî all these assembly line-esque nature of modern dating made me realize that at my core I am still a dumb romantic. That although I have always approached love with logic and sometimes efficiency
column4: which often resulted in stunted romance
column5: I still have difficulties with bringing myself to embrace the idea and act meeting a life partner through online dating.

column1: I don‚Äôt for one second doubt the good that it can do and has bought to many people; when you approach it with a genuine heart open for new possibilities and an attitude of optimism
column2: it is very possible that your one is the next swipe and date away. But for a realist near pessimist who has trouble developing affection easily and feeling genuine when I know I am being assessed every date I go on
column3: taking a break from online dating is a necessity. And perhaps just the realization itself that online dating is not meant for everyone
column4: not even if you‚Äôre a young millennial who grew up in the digital age
column5: and you‚Äôre not that strange for not finding this approach to love to be odd ‚Äî is reassuring enough at the moment.

column4: and are fighting constantly to be recognized as human. Never mind that they are unable to get a good night‚Äôs rest or a nourishing meal for weeks or months on end. Never mind that even in my comfortable
column5: easy life
column6: I can‚Äôt go a few days without craving a drink or making an irresponsible purchase. They have to do better.

column1: But they‚Äôre already doing the best they can. I‚Äôve known homeless people who worked full-time jobs
column2: and who devoted themselves to the care of other people in their communities. A lot of homeless people have to navigate bureaucracies constantly
column3: interfacing with social workers
column4: case workers
column5: police officers
column6: shelter staff
column7: Medicaid staff
column8: and a slew of charities both well-meaning and condescending. It‚Äôs a lot of fucking work to be homeless. And when a homeless or poor person runs out of steam and makes a ‚Äúbad decision‚Äù
column9: there‚Äôs a damn good reason for it.

column1: If a person‚Äôs behavior doesn‚Äôt make sense to you
column2: it is because you are missing a part of their context. It‚Äôs that simple. I‚Äôm so grateful to Kim and their writing for making me aware of this fact. No psychology class
column3: at any level
column4: taught me that. But now that it is a lens that I have
column5: I find myself applying it to all kinds of behaviors that are mistaken for signs of moral failure ‚Äî and I‚Äôve yet to find one that can‚Äôt be explained and empathized with.

column1: Let‚Äôs look at a sign of academic ‚Äúlaziness‚Äù that I believe is anything but: procrastination.
People love to blame procrastinators for their behavior. Putting off work sure looks lazy
column2: to an untrained eye. Even the people who are actively doing the procrastinating can mistake their behavior for laziness. You‚Äôre supposed to be doing something
column3: and you‚Äôre not doing it ‚Äî that‚Äôs a moral failure right? That means you‚Äôre weak-willed
column4: unmotivated
column5: and lazy
column6: doesn‚Äôt it?

column1: For decades
column2: psychological research has been able to explain procrastination as a functioning problem
column3: not a consequence of laziness. When a person fails to begin a project that they care about
column4: it‚Äôs typically due to either a) anxiety about their attempts not being ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù or b) confusion about what the first steps of the task are. Not laziness. In fact
column5: procrastination is more likely when the task is meaningful and the individual cares about doing it well.

column1: When you‚Äôre paralyzed with fear of failure
column2: or you don‚Äôt even know how to begin a massive
column3: complicated undertaking
column4: it‚Äôs damn hard to get shit done. It has nothing to do with desire
column5: motivation
column6: or moral upstandingness. Procastinators can will themselves to work for hours; they can sit in front of a blank word document
column7: doing nothing else
column8: and torture themselves; they can pile on the guilt again and again ‚Äî none of it makes initiating the task any easier. In fact
column9: their desire to get the damn thing done may worsen their stress and make starting the task harder.

column1: The solution
column2: instead
column3: is to look for what is holding the procrastinator back. If anxiety is the major barrier
column4: the procrastinator actually needs to walk away from the computer/book/word document and engage in a relaxing activity. Being branded ‚Äúlazy‚Äù by other people is likely to lead to the exact opposite behavior.

column1: Often
column2: though
column3: the barrier is that procrastinators have executive functioning challenges ‚Äî they struggle to divide a large responsibility into a series of discrete
column4: specific
column5: and ordered tasks. Here‚Äôs an example of executive functioning in action: I completed my dissertation (from proposal to data collection to final defense) in a little over a year. I was able to write my dissertation pretty easily and quickly because I knew that I had to a) compile research on the topic
column6: b) outline the paper
column7: c) schedule regular writing periods
column8: and d) chip away at the paper
column9: section by section
column10: day by day
column11: according to a schedule I had pre-determined.

column1: Nobody had to teach me to slice up tasks like that. And nobody had to force me to adhere to my schedule. Accomplishing tasks like this is consistent with how my analytical
column2: hyper-focused
column3: Autistic little brain works. Most people don‚Äôt have that ease. They need an external structure to keep them writing ‚Äî regular writing group meetings with friends
column4: for example ‚Äî and deadlines set by someone else. When faced with a major
column5: massive project
column6: most people want advice for how to divide it into smaller tasks
column7: and a timeline for completion. In order to track progress
column8: most people require organizational tools
column9: such as a to-do list
column10: calendar
column11: datebook
column12: or syllabus.

column1: Needing or benefiting from such things doesn‚Äôt make a person lazy. It just means they have needs. The more we embrace that
column2: the more we can help people thrive.

column1: I had a student who was skipping class. Sometimes I‚Äôd see her lingering near the building
column2: right before class was about to start
column3: looking tired. Class would start
column4: and she wouldn‚Äôt show up. When she was present in class
column5: she was a bit withdrawn; she sat in the back of the room
column6: eyes down
column7: energy low. She contributed during small group work
column8: but never talked during larger class discussions.

column1: A lot of my colleagues would look at this student and think she was lazy
column2: disorganized
column3: or apathetic. I know this because I‚Äôve heard how they talk about under-performing students. There‚Äôs often rage and resentment in their words and tone ‚Äî why won‚Äôt this student take my class seriously? Why won‚Äôt they make me feel important
column4: interesting
column5: smart?

column1: But my class had a unit on mental health stigma. It‚Äôs a passion of mine
column2: because I‚Äôm a neuroatypical psychologist. I know how unfair my field is to people like me. The class & I talked about the unfair judgments people levy against those with mental illness; how depression is interpreted as laziness
column3: how mood swings are framed as manipulative
column4: how people with ‚Äúsevere‚Äù mental illnesses are assumed incompetent or dangerous.

column1: The quiet
column2: occasionally-class-skipping student watched this discussion with keen interest. After class
column3: as people filtered out of the room
column4: she hung back and asked to talk to me. And then she disclosed that she had a mental illness and was actively working to treat it. She was busy with therapy and switching medications
column5: and all the side effects that entails. Sometimes
column6: she was not able to leave the house or sit still in a classroom for hours. She didn‚Äôt dare tell her other professors that this was why she was missing classes and late
column7: sometimes
column8: on assignments; they‚Äôd think she was using her illness as an excuse. But she trusted me to understand.

column1: And I did. And I was so
column2: so angry that this student was made to feel responsible for her symptoms. She was balancing a full course load
column3: a part-time job
column4: and ongoing
column5: serious mental health treatment. And she was capable of intuiting her needs and communicating them with others. She was a fucking badass
column6: not a lazy fuck. I told her so.

column1: She took many more classes with me after that
column2: and I saw her slowly come out of her shell. By her Junior and Senior years
column3: she was an active
column4: frank contributor to class ‚Äî she even decided to talk openly with her peers about her mental illness. During class discussions
column5: she challenged me and asked excellent
column6: probing questions. She shared tons of media and current-events examples of psychological phenomena with us. When she was having a bad day
column7: she told me
column8: and I let her miss class. Other professors ‚Äî including ones in the psychology department ‚Äî remained judgmental towards her
column9: but in an environment where her barriers were recognized and legitimized
column10: she thrived.

column1: Over the years
column2: at that same school
column3: I encountered countless other students who were under-estimated because the barriers in their lives were not seen as legitimate. There was the young man with OCD who always came to class late
column4: because his compulsions sometimes left him stuck in place for a few moments. There was the survivor of an abusive relationship
column5: who was processing her trauma in therapy appointments right before my class each week. There was the young woman who had been assaulted by a peer ‚Äî and who had to continue attending classes with that peer
column6: while the school was investigating the case.

column1: These students all came to me willingly
column2: and shared what was bothering them. Because I discussed mental illness
column3: trauma
column4: and stigma in my class
column5: they knew I would be understanding. And with some accommodations
column6: they blossomed academically. They gained confidence
column7: made attempts at assignments that intimidated them
column8: raised their grades
column9: started considering graduate school and internships. I always found myself admiring them. When I was a college student
column10: I was nowhere near as self-aware. I hadn‚Äôt even begun my lifelong project of learning to ask for help.

column1: Students with barriers were not always treated with such kindness by my fellow psychology professors. One colleague
column2: in particular
column3: was infamous for providing no make-up exams and allowing no late arrivals. No matter a student‚Äôs situation
column4: she was unflinchingly rigid in her requirements. No barrier was insurmountable
column5: in her mind; no limitation was acceptable. People floundered in her class. They felt shame about their sexual assault histories
column6: their anxiety symptoms
column7: their depressive episodes. When a student who did poorly in her classes performed well in mine
column8: she was suspicious.

column1: It‚Äôs morally repugnant to me that any educator would be so hostile to the people they are supposed to serve. It‚Äôs especially infuriating
column2: that the person enacting this terror was a psychologist. The injustice and ignorance of it leaves me teary every time I discuss it. It‚Äôs a common attitude in many educational circles
column3: but no student deserves to encounter it.

column1: I know
column2: of course
column3: that educators are not taught to reflect on what their students‚Äô unseen barriers are. Some universities pride themselves on refusing to accommodate disabled or mentally ill students ‚Äî they mistake cruelty for intellectual rigor. And
column4: since most professors are people who succeeded academically with ease
column5: they have trouble taking the perspective of someone with executive functioning struggles
column6: sensory overloads
column7: depression
column8: self-harm histories
column9: addictions
column10: or eating disorders. I can see the external factors that lead to these problems. Just as I know that ‚Äúlazy‚Äù behavior is not an active choice
column11: I know that judgmental
column12: elitist attitudes are typically borne out of situational ignorance.

column1: And that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm writing this piece. I‚Äôm hoping to awaken my fellow educators ‚Äî of all levels ‚Äî to the fact that if a student is struggling
column2: they probably aren‚Äôt choosing to. They probably want to do well. They probably are trying. More broadly
column3: I want all people to take a curious and empathic approach to individuals whom they initially want to judge as ‚Äúlazy‚Äù or irresponsible.

column1: If a person can‚Äôt get out of bed
column2: something is making them exhausted. If a student isn‚Äôt writing papers
column3: there‚Äôs some aspect of the assignment that they can‚Äôt do without help. If an employee misses deadlines constantly
column4: something is making organization and deadline-meeting difficult. Even if a person is actively choosing to self-sabotage
column5: there‚Äôs a reason for it ‚Äî some fear they‚Äôre working through
column6: some need not being met
column7: a lack of self-esteem being expressed.

column1: People do not choose to fail or disappoint. No one wants to feel incapable
column2: apathetic
column3: or ineffective. If you look at a person‚Äôs action (or inaction) and see only laziness
column4: you are missing key details. There is always an explanation. There are always barriers. Just because you can‚Äôt see them
column5: or don‚Äôt view them as legitimate
column6: doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre not there. Look harder.

column1: Maybe you weren‚Äôt always able to look at human behavior this way. That‚Äôs okay. Now you are. Give it a try.
If you found this essay illuminating at all

column3: Self-Published Kindling: Memoirs of a Homeless Bookstore Owner. The ebook is $3; the paperback is $15.

column1: Now to be clear

I was able to write my dissertation pretty easily and quickly because I knew that I had to a) compile research on the topic
column6: b) outline the paper
column7: c) schedule regular writing periods
column8: and d) chip away at the paper
column9: section by section
column10: day by day
column11: according to a schedule I had pre-determined.

column1: Nobody had to teach me to slice up tasks like that. And nobody had to force me to adhere to my schedule. Accomplishing tasks like this is consistent with how my analytical
column2: hyper-focused
column3: Autistic little brain works. Most people don‚Äôt have that ease. They need an external structure to keep them writing ‚Äî regular writing group meetings with friends
column4: for example ‚Äî and deadlines set by someone else. When faced with a major
column5: massive project
column6: most people want advice for how to divide it into smaller tasks
column7: and a timeline for completion. In order to track progress
column8: most people require organizational tools
column9: such as a to-do list
column10: calendar
column11: datebook
column12: or syllabus.

column1: Needing or benefiting from such things doesn‚Äôt make a person lazy. It just means they have needs. The more we embrace that
column2: the more we can help people thrive.

column1: I had a student who was skipping class. Sometimes I‚Äôd see her lingering near the building
column2: right before class was about to start
column3: looking tired. Class would start
column4: and she wouldn‚Äôt show up. When she was present in class
column5: she was a bit withdrawn; she sat in the back of the room
column6: eyes down
column7: energy low. She contributed during small group work
column8: but never talked during larger class discussions.

column1: A lot of my colleagues would look at this student and think she was lazy
column2: disorganized
column3: or apathetic. I know this because I‚Äôve heard how they talk about under-performing students. There‚Äôs often rage and resentment in their words and tone ‚Äî why won‚Äôt this student take my class seriously? Why won‚Äôt they make me feel important
column4: interesting
column5: smart?

column1: But my class had a unit on mental health stigma. It‚Äôs a passion of mine
column2: because I‚Äôm a neuroatypical psychologist. I know how unfair my field is to people like me. The class & I talked about the unfair judgments people levy against those with mental illness; how depression is interpreted as laziness
column3: how mood swings are framed as manipulative
column4: how people with ‚Äúsevere‚Äù mental illnesses are assumed incompetent or dangerous.

column1: The quiet
column2: occasionally-class-skipping student watched this discussion with keen interest. After class
column3: as people filtered out of the room
column4: she hung back and asked to talk to me. And then she disclosed that she had a mental illness and was actively working to treat it. She was busy with therapy and switching medications
column5: and all the side effects that entails. Sometimes
column6: she was not able to leave the house or sit still in a classroom for hours. She didn‚Äôt dare tell her other professors that this was why she was missing classes and late
column7: sometimes
column8: on assignments; they‚Äôd think she was using her illness as an excuse. But she trusted me to understand.

column1: And I did. And I was so
column2: so angry that this student was made to feel responsible for her symptoms. She was balancing a full course load
column3: a part-time job
column4: and ongoing
column5: serious mental health treatment. And she was capable of intuiting her needs and communicating them with others. She was a fucking badass
column6: not a lazy fuck. I told her so.

column1: She took many more classes with me after that
column2: and I saw her slowly come out of her shell. By her Junior and Senior years
column3: she was an active
column4: frank contributor to class ‚Äî she even decided to talk openly with her peers about her mental illness. During class discussions
column5: she challenged me and asked excellent
column6: probing questions. She shared tons of media and current-events examples of psychological phenomena with us. When she was having a bad day
column7: she told me
column8: and I let her miss class. Other professors ‚Äî including ones in the psychology department ‚Äî remained judgmental towards her
column9: but in an environment where her barriers were recognized and legitimized
column10: she thrived.

column1: Over the years
column2: at that same school
column3: I encountered countless other students who were under-estimated because the barriers in their lives were not seen as legitimate. There was the young man with OCD who always came to class late
column4: because his compulsions sometimes left him stuck in place for a few moments. There was the survivor of an abusive relationship
column5: who was processing her trauma in therapy appointments right before my class each week. There was the young woman who had been assaulted by a peer ‚Äî and who had to continue attending classes with that peer
column6: while the school was investigating the case.

column1: These students all came to me willingly
column2: and shared what was bothering them. Because I discussed mental illness
column3: trauma
column4: and stigma in my class
column5: they knew I would be understanding. And with some accommodations
column6: they blossomed academically. They gained confidence
column7: made attempts at assignments that intimidated them
column8: raised their grades
column9: started considering graduate school and internships. I always found myself admiring them. When I was a college student
column10: I was nowhere near as self-aware. I hadn‚Äôt even begun my lifelong project of learning to ask for help.

column1: Students with barriers were not always treated with such kindness by my fellow psychology professors. One colleague
column2: in particular
column3: was infamous for providing no make-up exams and allowing no late arrivals. No matter a student‚Äôs situation
column4: she was unflinchingly rigid in her requirements. No barrier was insurmountable
column5: in her mind; no limitation was acceptable. People floundered in her class. They felt shame about their sexual assault histories
column6: their anxiety symptoms
column7: their depressive episodes. When a student who did poorly in her classes performed well in mine
column8: she was suspicious.

column1: It‚Äôs morally repugnant to me that any educator would be so hostile to the people they are supposed to serve. It‚Äôs especially infuriating
column2: that the person enacting this terror was a psychologist. The injustice and ignorance of it leaves me teary every time I discuss it. It‚Äôs a common attitude in many educational circles
column3: but no student deserves to encounter it.

column1: I know
column2: of course
column3: that educators are not taught to reflect on what their students‚Äô unseen barriers are. Some universities pride themselves on refusing to accommodate disabled or mentally ill students ‚Äî they mistake cruelty for intellectual rigor. And
column4: since most professors are people who succeeded academically with ease
column5: they have trouble taking the perspective of someone with executive functioning struggles
column6: sensory overloads
column7: depression
column8: self-harm histories
column9: addictions
column10: or eating disorders. I can see the external factors that lead to these problems. Just as I know that ‚Äúlazy‚Äù behavior is not an active choice
column11: I know that judgmental
column12: elitist attitudes are typically borne out of situational ignorance.

column1: And that‚Äôs why I‚Äôm writing this piece. I‚Äôm hoping to awaken my fellow educators ‚Äî of all levels ‚Äî to the fact that if a student is struggling
column2: they probably aren‚Äôt choosing to. They probably want to do well. They probably are trying. More broadly
column3: I want all people to take a curious and empathic approach to individuals whom they initially want to judge as ‚Äúlazy‚Äù or irresponsible.

column1: If a person can‚Äôt get out of bed
column2: something is making them exhausted. If a student isn‚Äôt writing papers
column3: there‚Äôs some aspect of the assignment that they can‚Äôt do without help. If an employee misses deadlines constantly
column4: something is making organization and deadline-meeting difficult. Even if a person is actively choosing to self-sabotage
column5: there‚Äôs a reason for it ‚Äî some fear they‚Äôre working through
column6: some need not being met
column7: a lack of self-esteem being expressed.

column1: People do not choose to fail or disappoint. No one wants to feel incapable
column2: apathetic
column3: or ineffective. If you look at a person‚Äôs action (or inaction) and see only laziness
column4: you are missing key details. There is always an explanation. There are always barriers. Just because you can‚Äôt see them
column5: or don‚Äôt view them as legitimate
column6: doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre not there. Look harder.

column1: Maybe you weren‚Äôt always able to look at human behavior this way. That‚Äôs okay. Now you are. Give it a try.
If you found this essay illuminating at all

column1: When I was first building JotForm
column2: I was a lot like the young crocodile ‚Äî believing that I always had to be doing something to get results.

column1: Back then
column2: if someone would have told me that I would see greater results by spending more time doing nothing
column3: I would have rolled my eyes and continued to chip away at my 16 hour day of work.

column1: I thought that in order to be successful
column2: I had to constantly be building
column3: working
column4: growing and developing the next thing ‚Äî whatever that ‚Äúthing‚Äù was.

column1: All of us have a problem with busyness. But being busy and being successful are not one in the same. And
column2: I think if we were to make ‚Äúdoing nothing‚Äù more of a priority
column3: we might find ourselves catching more wildebeests versus measly catfish.

column1: It worked for me
column2: and I hope it can work for you
column3: too.

column1: But
column2: doing less or nothing at all is easier said than done
column3: especially in a society that suffers from extreme busyness. Let‚Äôs take a closer look at our unhealthy obsession with staying busy...

column1: Mankind has struggled with busyness since the beginning of time ‚Äî or at least since 425 BC when Homer walked the Earth.
The Odyssey tells the tale of the Lotus-eaters ‚Äî a strange people that slothed around all day long eating lotus and doing nothing. And
column2: what was stranger than fiction was that these people were content with their lives.

column1: Homer wrote that after some of Odysseus‚Äôs crew ate the Lotus-eaters Lotus fruit (say that three times fast)
column2: they became like the Lotus-eaters ‚Äî content
column3: relaxed and a bit lethargic.

column1: Terrified that if all of his men ate the lotus fruit they would be unmotivated to return home
column2: Odysseus ordered the affected men to be tied to the ship benches and for the ship to set sail immediately.

column1: It ‚Äôs interesting
column2: Odysseus‚Äôs reaction to this feeling of ‚Äúdoing nothing‚Äù sounds similar to the Corporate CEO
column3: the Startup Founder and the collegiate football coach we know today ‚Äî hardcore workaholics that despise anything that might allude to a sense of complacency.

column1: Though
column2: they of course are just the tip of a much larger societal iceberg that feels frozen with fear at the thought of doing nothing.

column1: The world as a whole now measures value in terms of busyness versus quality of work. In many ways
column2: it has become something of a status symbol to be ‚Äúbusy‚Äù.

column1: How many times have you heard or had a conversation like this...
We‚Äôve grown to subconsciously measure a person‚Äôs worth based off how many hours they work
column2: how much is on their plate and put simply ‚Äî whether or not they are running around like a chicken with their head cut off.

column1: In Tim Ferriss‚Äôs 4-Hour Work Week
column2: he pokes fun at this idea by facetiously saying that if you want a promotion
column3: you should appear to be more busy by working longer hours
column4: scrambling around and constantly answering emails.

column1: But
column2: sooner or later
column3: all of us have to ask ourselves what our mission is ‚Äî is it to be the busiest or is it to make the most impact?

column1: And
column2: what‚Äôs fascinating is that when we look at some of the greatest minds to grace planet Earth
column3: we see an interesting commonality ‚Äî they all make time for doing nothing.

column1: Making time in your life to do nothing can be challenging ‚Äî especially during the work week where we are constantly pummeled and bombarded with meetings
column2: notifications and an ever growing list of tasks.

column1: Busy founders have started implementing ‚ÄúThink Weeks‚Äù into their annual schedules ‚Äî week long periods they spend reflecting
column2: reading
column3: thinking and living outside the all-encapsulating world that is running a business.

column1: While young founders like Skillshare‚Äôs Mike Karnjanaprakorn have adopted this practice
column2: as well as big names like Steve Jobs
column3: Mark Zuckerberg and Tim Ferriss
column4: it was Bill Gates who originally made the Think Week famous.

column1: For many years while running Microsoft
column2: Gates would retreat into week long Think Weeks twice a year ‚Äî not vacations
column3: but actual periods of time dedicated to doing nothing.

column1: Gates was so adamant about his Think Weeks that family
column2: friends and Microsoft employees were banned. Today
column3: Gates attributes much of Microsoft‚Äôs success to the big ideas and concepts he stumbled upon while doing nothing.

column1: You don‚Äôt necessarily have to ban family and friends to retreat into a Think Week
column2: though. Take me as an example.

column1: Every year
column2: I take at least a full week off from my company and head back to my hometown to help my parents with the olive harvest.

column1: All thoughts of startup growth or conversion rates slip away when you‚Äôre picking olives. It‚Äôs meditative and calming.

column2: but it‚Äôs a personal measure of success. And somehow
column3: some of my best ideas come to me during this period.

column1: For someone who can‚Äôt take an entire week off of work once a year to do nothing
column2: I recommend taking a slightly different approach ‚Äî embracing the digital sabbath.

column1: On either Saturday or Sunday
column2: force yourself to step away from all forms of technology ‚Äî a practice known as a digital sabbath.

column1: Shut off your smartphone and hide it in your closet. Powerdown the laptop and slide it under your bed. And
column2: try with all your might to refrain from binge-watching Netflix.

column1: Give your brain space to think by stepping away from the daily grind and doing nothing. Your mind will have time to stumble upon new ideas and further process old ones.
You may find the success that results from this practice to be similar to that of the old crocodile at the beginning of this article.

How we respond to Facebook today will inform the startups of tomorrow
Credit: LOIC VENANCE/AFP/Getty Images
Credit: LOIC VENANCE/AFP/Getty Images
I deleted my Facebook a few weeks ago
column2: but it started scaring me last March.

column1: A friend and I ran into one of his investors in a cafeÃÅ in San Francisco
column2: and the investor asked if we‚Äôd heard of a Soylent competitor
column3: Ample. He was curious what we thought of it
column4: and of meal replacement companies in general.

column1: I hadn‚Äôt heard of Ample
column2: but I shared my concerns with Soylent
column3: and why I personally would never put my money into one of those companies. My friend
column4: for the most part
column5: agreed.

column1: The conversation ended and we left. I didn‚Äôt think about Ample again
column2: look it up
column3: or talk about it online with anyone. But less than 24 hours later
column4: there were ads for it in my Instagram feed.

column1: It was spooky
column2: to say the least. I was used to getting ads for products whose sites I‚Äôd visited
column3: and for products I‚Äôd mentioned on Facebook
column4: but products that I‚Äôd only talked about? That was weird.

column1: After a bit of digging
column2: I discovered I wasn‚Äôt alone. There were dozens of stories online about people getting freaked out by ads that seem like they only could have come from Facebook eavesdropping on their conversations.

column1: Now to be clear
column2: this probably isn‚Äôt happening. It would be a massive amount of work and data processing for marginally better ad targeting. Like the Wired article says
column3: Facebook doesn‚Äôt need to listen to your conversations.

column1: They can target you well enough without it.
That‚Äôs meant to be reassuring: they‚Äôre not listening to you because they don‚Äôt have to. But if anything
column2: that should be even scarier. Facebook knows so much about you they can make you believe they‚Äôre listening to your personal conversations. They have so much data about you they can send you ads that have an uncanny relevance to what is going on in the real world.

column1: Imagine
column2: for a moment
column3: that you had a friend with this level of knowledge about you. Someone who knows everywhere you go
column4: what you like
column5: what you fear
column6: what you want
column7: who you hang out with
column8: how happy you are at any given moment.

column1: They could be an amazing boon to your life. Or they could be a nightmare. It all depends on what they do with the information
column2: and how well you can trust them with it.

column1: Now imagine the friend can use their information about you to make money
column2: say by manipulating your decisions to benefit them. And imagine they‚Äôre the kind of morally bankrupt person who would take advantage of their friend this way.

column1: What would their incentives look like?
Since they can make money by manipulating your decisions
column2: they‚Äôll try to manipulate your decisions. And since they can better manipulate your decisions by learning more about you
column3: the more they‚Äôll want to learn. If they want the greatest success for themselves
column4: they will necessarily have to manipulate you as much as possible and collect as much data on you as possible.

column1: This seems to be the situation Facebook has gotten itself into:
Facebook‚Äôs product is not the platform
column2: it‚Äôs us. If the product is what a business sells to make money
column3: then Facebook‚Äôs product is our attention and data. We are the product. And Facebook‚Äôs customers are the companies buying ads based on that attention and data.

column1: If our time and our attention are Facebook‚Äôs true product
column2: then their long-term goal becomes clear: to influence (and tax) how we communicate in the 21st century. Every product they‚Äôve launched and company they‚Äôve acquired is related to this goal in some way:

column1: Facebook wants to own how we communicate because it means more data and more attention
column2: which means more ads revenue. Simple enough.

column1: But that idea should be a little frightening: a company wants to control how you interact with other humans so that they can make money off of you. This isn‚Äôt some secret
column2: evil motivation driving the company behind closed doors. It‚Äôs a necessary consequence of the incentives that shape it.

column1: Compare this model to Netflix. You pay Netflix a flat monthly fee
column2: and in return
column3: you get unlimited streaming movies and TV shows from their platform. Netflix doesn‚Äôt make more money the more time you spend on it (they make less
column4: actually)
column5: so they have no incentive to addict you to the platform (beyond keeping you from switching to a competitor). With Netflix
column6: we‚Äôre the customers.

column1: This isn‚Äôt to say that all free
column2: ad-financed apps are bad and all pay-to-play apps are good. I‚Äôve used Foursquare and Swarm consistently for 7+ years. These are apps where I volunteer my location
column3: travel
column4: eating
column5: and shopping habits
column6: and I‚Äôve never had the slightest sense that Foursquare was using this data in a way that made my life worse.

column1: The ads in Foursquare tend to be useful. Their goal for the product is to be the place consumers go to find the next restaurant or cafeÃÅ to try. They don‚Äôt need you to spend tons of time in the app
column2: and they don‚Äôt need you to buy products from vendors unrelated to your in-app goals. They just want you to stay in the habit of checking in places and finding places through them
column3: so they serve you ads related to the kinds of foods and stores you tend to like.

column1: If Foursquare started using that data in a way that made me uncomfortable
column2: I‚Äôd stop using it. If every time I checked into a restaurant I started getting emails from them afterwards
column3: I‚Äôd know Foursquare was selling my email address to places I checked in and I wouldn‚Äôt be cool with that. I‚Äôd delete it
column4: and switch to an app I had more trust in.

column1: The problem with Facebook is that its managed to gain such a monopoly on our digital presence that we worry about quitting it. Switching from Foursquare to Yelp doesn‚Äôt give anyone anxiety
column2: but deleting Facebook does.

column1: How did Facebook get so ingrained in our lives that people who lived without it for thirty years are suddenly concerned about losing it?
Partially for the same reason people joined in the first place: information. We want to know what‚Äôs going on in the lives of our friends and acquaintances
column2: and Facebook has become the go-to source for doing that.

column1: But in the process
column2: Facebook has changed friendship from an active to a passive process. You can sit back and wait for some update to appear from a friend or acquaintance and then respond to it. You don‚Äôt have to put in any effort to reach out and ask what‚Äôs going on
column3: you get it fed to your by the magical friend algorithms.

column1: How often do you reach out to your friends to ask them how it‚Äôs going? Or to see if there are any big updates in their lives? There‚Äôs hardly any need anymore
column2: since Facebook has automated the process. We don‚Äôt have to put in the work
column3: the information comes to us
column4: and so we‚Äôve lost the muscles we used to use for staying updated on our social circle.

column1: It‚Äôs similar to the problem I outlined in my article on the switch from search to social. As we moved away from actively looking for things on the Internet
column2: having them fed to us instead
column3: we became more passive informational consumers. And as we move more towards passive Facebook-style friendships
column4: we lose our old abilities to stay in touch with people.

column1: This would be fine if Facebook relationships were as meaningful as in-person ones
column2: but they aren‚Äôt. Conversations through chat apps and getting up to date on your friends through the newsfeed is the relationship equivalent of Soylent. A technological pseudo-improvement over an ancient human process
column3: and one that falls dramatically short of the value it‚Äôs trying to recreate.

column1: And since we‚Äôve been sipping the Facebook friend juice for so long
column2: it‚Äôs legitimately scary to quit. How will you know what events are going on? How will you know if something big happens in your friend‚Äôs life? How will you stay in touch with people?

column1: The simple answer is... all the ways we did for the last 100
column2: 000 years. Talking to people. Being an active consumer of information and knowledge about your friends‚Äô lives instead of letting it passively wash over you.

column1: But it would still be fair to ask: why bother. Yes
column2: quitting Facebook does make it more likely that you‚Äôll miss events
column3: updates
column4: and messages
column5: since other people are on it. And yes
column6: it can be a little inconvenient to not have it at times
column7: depending on your friend group.

column1: So why is it worth it to delete the social network instead of begrudgingly continuing to use it?
Someone observing the digital landscape a couple years from now could see Facebook continuing its dominance and deduce that it‚Äôs fine to play fast and loose with customer data in the name of growth
column2: to optimize your product around addictiveness
column3: and to sell information on your users.

column1: Or
column2: in a couple years
column3: they could see the massive consequences Facebook faced for behaving that way. They could see people chose to give their attention to products they trust
column4: and left Facebook in droves.

column1: Which is why quitting Facebook matters: it sends the message that companies can‚Äôt
column2: and shouldn‚Äôt
column3: try to have that much power over our lives. That if other companies try in the future
column4: they‚Äôll get punished for it.

column1: If someone in our social circle deceives us or lies to us
column2: we tell our friends. We use gossip to spread information about who is and isn‚Äôt trustworthy
column3: partially so there are consequences for not being trustworthy. If businesses aren‚Äôt subject to the same consequences for not being trustworthy
column4: they‚Äôll have no motivation to think before they do something that could break their users‚Äô trust.

column1: If Facebook thinks they can keep focusing on addiction
column2: ad revenue
column3: and data collection with no consequences
column4: they‚Äôll keep doing it.

column1: Reflecting on how Facebook has become such a dominant force in our lives the last five to ten years
column2: and the consequences of that dominance
column3: I think there are a few key lessons from it that we can apply to other technologies:

column1: Facebook can‚Äôt replace socialization and face-to-face communication. Soylent can‚Äôt replace food. Porn can‚Äôt replace sex. Tinder can‚Äôt replace dating. It‚Äôs tempting to try to technologize everything in our lives
column2: but it won‚Äôt work for these more old-school processes
column3: and we should stop believing that four guys in their Harvard dorm room can really make a better social network than the one we have IRL.

column1: Opt for services you pay for instead of services that sell your information. Pay to remove ads whenever possible. When you‚Äôre using a product for free
column2: you‚Äôre still paying for it in some way
column3: typically through the data and attention you‚Äôre giving it. Watch out for the incentives of companies and products you use
column4: and don‚Äôt expect that they‚Äôll all be benevolent masters of your information.

column1: If a company can‚Äôt be trusted
column2: ditch them
column3: and let them feel the consequences. If a product can get away with mistreating its users to make money
column4: it will keep doing it until they feel the consequences.

column1: Facebook has become the abusive partner in many people‚Äôs lives. They‚Äôve carved out such a seemingly important role in your life that even though you want to leave
column2: you‚Äôre scared of the consequences.

column1: But I can‚Äôt stress enough how little impact quitting has on your life. I was almost entirely off it for a year before deleting it
column2: and in that time I‚Äôve never missed it. Have I missed an event or two? Probably
column3: but that‚Äôs a small price to pay.

column1: And as for staying up to date on my friends lives... well I just do it the old fashioned way. Talking to them. Which is wonderful since we actually have something to talk about when we meet in person
column2: instead of sitting on our phones looking at Facebook to get up to date on all our other friends‚Äô lives.

column1: Imagine going back 10 years and being told that if you signed up for Facebook
column2: they were going to collect a disturbing amount of information on you
column3: manipulate your emotions
column4: store your conversations
column5: and try to control how you communicate with people online. Would you sign up? Would you let your kid sign up?

column1: I wouldn‚Äôt
column2: and I don‚Äôt think you would either.

column1: Here‚Äôs how to quit when you‚Äôre ready.
