column1: Some experts argue that early praise can leave the individual receiving the praise feeling like he or she has already won... in turn causing them to be less likely to follow through with their goals.
For example
column2: in Peter Gollwitzer‚Äôs research article
column3: When Intentions Go Public

column1: ‚ÄúOther people‚Äôs taking notice of one‚Äôs identity-relevant intentions apparently engenders a premature sense of completeness regarding the identity goal.‚Äù
In English
column2: what Gollwitzer found was that when individuals set a goal that is closely tied to their identity and then share their intentions with others
column3: they are less likely to achieve the goal.

column1: For example
column2: if your goal is to start drinking more water and you tell your friends and family that you‚Äôre going to start drinking more water
column3: this would probably have little to no impact on whether or not you actually drink more water.

On the other hand
column2: if your goal is to lose 40 lbs and drop 2‚Äì3 waist sizes
column3: it might not be the best idea to post about it all over Facebook. Your appearance is something you very much so identify with. So
column4: if you tell people you plan to lose weight and everyone tells you how awesome you are and how great you‚Äôre going to look
column5: you might be less likely to lose the weight.

column1: This finding is a bit counterintuitive

column3: share our goals

column1: Entrepreneur

column1: In addition to fear-setting

column1: A study published two years ago in the journal Preventive Medicine Reports

column1: The study put 800 undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Pennsylvania through an 11-week exercise program where each person was assigned to work out alone or in a team.

column1: By the end of the study

column1: When you surround yourself with competition

column4: but there are also problems that come with spending an entire life living goal to goal.

column1: For one
column2: it attempts to predict an unpredictable future. Who is to say that what you want tomorrow or the year after is the same thing you want right now? More critically
column3: what if what you want right now isn‚Äôt even oriented in the right direction over the long-term and you‚Äôre actually going the wrong way? Life changes
column4: we change
column5: and none of this is evident without hindsight.

column1: Secondly
column2: and just as importantly
column3: it creates an anchor: You bind your expectations of happiness and contentment onto something so singular that you often forget that other things in your life are capable of adding just as much joy to your experience than the thing you‚Äôre so fixated on.

column1: Everybody knows that the ultimate reward is the process
column2: not the goal
column3: but what we forget is that the virtue of even having goals makes it very hard to stay honest to a process that often deviates day to day.

column1: This creates a strange tension: On one end
column2: goals of some sort are necessary
column3: and giving the future its due attention is the right thing to do; on the other hand
column4: the act of creating these goals and worshiping them
column5: as we often do
column6: leads to a conflict that we can‚Äôt easily get away from.

column1: To solve this tension
column2: we have to move towards something more nebulous.

column1: The really fascinating
column2: and even admirable
column3: thing about Feynman was that if he ever had a goal
column4: it was simply this: to learn as much as possible in any direction that his innate curiosity took him.

column1: For brief periods of his time
column2: working on one problem or the other
column3: he may have had more specific goals
column4: sure
column5: and he certainly took the time to focus on them as he needed without distractions. But broadly
column6: his orientation was pointed towards the most interesting thing he could find.

column1: The pursuit of interestingness
column2: I think
column3: solves the predicament that is inherent in goal-setting. It‚Äôs vague and nebulous enough to be honest about the unpredictability of the future
column4: without being hopelessly lost in the chaos of pure luck and randomness.

column1: Throughout life
column2: we all see things
column3: learn things
column4: and pursue things. This process is different for each of us
column5: but as we do so
column6: we also develop a very strong intuition of what we
column7: personally
column8: find fascinating about the world ‚Äî something that aligns with our deeper nature while respecting that we change over time as human beings
column9: letting us adapt accordingly.

column1: Interestingness isn‚Äôt hedonism or materialism or the chase of anything new and shiny that seeks to distract us. It‚Äôs deeper than that. It‚Äôs taking on that random project you had no plan to take on because you have a feeling that you might just learn something you didn‚Äôt know about yourself. It‚Äôs seeing a person you just met not as a potential partner or someone who can do something for you but simply as an individual who may open up a new
column2: unknown
column3: and unique dimension in your life.

column1: The great thing about pursuing this kind of interestingness is that it has a far shorter feedback loop than specific goals. You keep doing something for as long as it‚Äôs interesting
column2: but if you were mistaken about your initial impulse
column3: you move on
column4: without too much lost.

column1: Naturally
column2: not everything or everyone is interesting all the time
column3: but generally speaking
column4: if something maintains its interest over a period of time
column5: it‚Äôs likely worth dedicating some energy to.

column1: By making interestingness the goal
column2: you give your actual goals a fluidity
column3: one that can better accommodate new information. This also better amalgamates the goal with the process
column4: rather than the goal being a distinct thing that battles to keep your attention off of the process.

column1: More than anything
column2: however
column3: the pursuit of interestingness honors a simple truth about the human experience: The best things in life are by-products. They come when they come
column4: as you commit yourself honestly to a process
column5: not when you spend time striving for imagined perfection.

column1: The future demands attention
column2: and while focusing all of our energy on it is self-defeating
column3: we do need to be intentional about directing some of our effort towards it as we orient ourselves in the world.

column1: Goals are one way to do that. They give us a way to make concrete what is otherwise uncertain so that we can make progress without losing ourselves to anxiety. The problem
column2: however
column3: is that they often mistake what exists to provide orientation as a thing of value in itself.

column1: The best way out of this trap is to pursue what is interesting ‚Äî to use our intuition for what it is that we find novel in this world to make the process and the goal one and the same thing; to continually update our sense of what is worth pursuing without being confined to false certainty.
Interestingness seeks out the riddle of life. It gives us a reason to turn the next page
column2: to see the next scene
column3: to give form to the unknown.

column1: Feynman embodied this
column2: but he also once said something that captures what it is that differentiates such a pursuit from mere goals and certainties:

column1: Goals
column2: incorrectly
column3: assume that we already know what it is that we want. Interestingness is more humble. It makes up its mind as it moves
column4: slowly blowing from one thing to another
column5: until it eventually grasps something that lies beyond prediction.

column1: Looking ahead
column2: imagining scenarios that we think may be worth our time
column3: has a place
column4: but at the end of the day
column5: what is most relevant is unfolding around us right now
column6: and it doesn‚Äôt care what we thought about it yesterday.

column1: If you are a software developer and you‚Äôre like me

column3: which have a device pixel ratio greater than one). I wanted more text characters
column4: not slightly smoother looking ones. A 4K display has a resolution of 3840 by 2160
column5: more than the number of pixels on two 30-inch monitors. My question was
column6: in order to ensure that the pixels would have the same PPI

column1: I calculated that the proper size for a 4K monitor was around 43 inches (diagonal). I quickly found one

column1: I had been worried that a 43-inch monitor might feel too huge. I used to own a 42-inch 1080p HDTV set (we gave it away before moving into the condo). I couldn‚Äôt imagine sitting close enough to use it as a monitor

column1: My 43-inch monitor is around 70% of the physical width of two 30-inch monitors placed side-by-side

column3: smaller desk). And my eyes don‚Äôt have to move left or right as far anymore.

column1: I quickly found other advantages to this setup. The MacOS feature of having multiple desktop spaces became easier to use with a single large monitor. I can put my social media pages in a separate space so they don‚Äôt distract me while I‚Äôm working.
The only thing I don‚Äôt like about the Dell monitor are that its HDMI inputs are version 1.4
column2: which can only do a 30Hz refresh rate at full resolution. But it also has DisplayPort inputs
column3: which can do 60Hz
column4: so I use DisplayPort (or mini-DisplayPort) to connect to my computer. DisplayPort and mini-DisplayPort are well supported on Apple
column5: Windows
column6: and Linux computers.

column1: The next problem was that I liked it so much that I wanted the same setup at work (where I still used two 30-inch monitors). Just about that time

column1: How do these two monitors compare?

column1: I‚Äôve been using them for a few months
column2: and I like using one 43-inch 4K monitor far better than using two 30-inch monitors. As a programmer
column3: I can have a large IDE window
column4: program output
column5: debugging window
column6: github
column7: gitter
column8: terminals
column9: logs

column1: And through the miracle of mass production for the consumer 4K TV market

column1: By the time you read this
column2: there might be other 43-inch 4K monitors available. You should check them out too. I just noticed the LG 43UD79-B
column3: which even has a USB-C video input (Thunderbolt 3 or DisplayPort over USB-C)
column4: but I haven‚Äôt tried it. It too appears to use the same panel as the Dell and Viewsonic monitors.

column1: If you are looking at other monitors
column2: note that I would avoid buying a display sold mainly for home viewing of TV and movies. They usually don‚Äôt have the inputs you want
column3: and are usually less sharp because you don‚Äôt typically sit two feet away from them. You may pay slightly more for a real computer monitor
column4: but it is worth it. As a bonus
column5: a large computer monitor will work great for watching movies (although depending on the monitor
column6: you may need to get some good self-powered speakers). If you want to watch TV you will need to plug it into a cable box or a streaming box of some kind (HDMI inputs will come in handy for that).

column1: Your computer must be able to drive the required resolution and scan rate (3840 by 2160 at 60Hz). In fact
column2: I had to upgrade one of my work computers (a 2014 MacBook Air; my employer traded it for a used 2015 one that works fine). Your computer‚Äôs video connectors should be:

column1: I‚Äôve seen a couple of cases on the internet where people could not get a 4K monitor to work
column2: even though the computer should have been able to drive it. According to them
column3: the problem turned out to be old or bad cables. Unfortunately
column4: most monitor cables are not labeled so it is difficult to know if they are the proper DisplayPort 1.2 or HDMI 2.0 (or higher). If you have problems
column5: trying buying a new cable of the right version. One person I read about even found that the cable that came with their monitor was the wrong version
column6: and wouldn‚Äôt work at 60Hz. And don‚Äôt even think about using DVI or VGA.

column1: Finally
column2: keep the number of adapters between your computer and monitor to a minimum: a single cable with no adapters if possible. My work computer has Thunderbolt 3 with USB-C connectors for video (the new Apple standard)
column3: so I bought a USB-C to DisplayPort cable. My home computer is mini-DisplayPort (the old Apple standard)
column4: so I use a mini-DisplayPort to DisplayPort cable. Both work great
column5: which should be no surprise because the Thunderbolt 3 video signal is the same as DisplayPort
column6: and mini-DisplayPort is just a smaller connector for DisplayPort.

column1: I also bought a DisplayPort KVM so I can use one keyboard
column2: video (monitor)
column3: and mouse with two different computers. It works fine with two computers that have mini-DisplayPort outputs
column4: but when I tried to use it with my computer that has Thunderbolt 3 (USB-C) output
column5: it would not work. Apparently
column6: having a Thunderbolt 3 to mini-DisplayPort adapter followed by the KVM was just too much. My workaround was to use a USB-C to DisplayPort cable
column7: skip the KVM and plug it directly into a separate input on the monitor. If anyone has figured out how to use a KVM with Thunderbolt 3
column8: let me know in the comments.

column1: tl;dr 43-inch 4K computer monitors should be the new hotness for people who like big monitors. And they should work well with almost any computer made in the last couple of years
column2: as long as you use the proper cables.

column1: Use the Performance-Values Matrix to build an Outstanding Culture
Every time I walk into a new company I‚Äôm advising
column2: I invariably encounter a set of noble values prominently displayed on the walls. The first thing I‚Äôve trained myself to do is to not take them as gospel
column3: and instead carefully observe how people really behave
column4: which will tell me the actual values I need to know.

column1: It‚Äôs not that most companies are disingenuous about the values they espouse. One of Enron‚Äôs ‚Äúaspirational values‚Äù was integrity
column2: which may have genuinely expressed who they wanted to be at the beginning. But over time
column3: this proclaimed value didn‚Äôt reflect their ‚Äúpracticed values‚Äù which were revealed when they committed fraud.

column1: Why does a gap usually exist between a company‚Äôs aspirational and practiced values? You would think that to alleviate cognitive dissonance
column2: most employees would feel an inherent need to practice what they preach ‚Äî or are preached at to do. But to truly close the gap
column3: you have to attack the problem at its root: The issue is that aspirational values almost always come from
column4: and must be rectified at
column5: the top.

column1: According to the theory of behaviorism
column2: no behavior will persist long term unless it is being perpetuated by either a positive reinforcer (providing a reward
column3: such as a promotion or praise) or a negative reinforcer (removing a punishment
column4: such as a probationary period or undesirable tasks). Thus
column5: when companies start
column6: leaders set the company‚Äôs values not by what they write on the walls
column7: but by how they actually act. For example
column8: do they stay late and burn the midnight oil? Or do they leave early to be with their families? According to social learning theory
column9: these behaviors become socialized
column10: and rank-and-file employees who take their cues from these leaders act
column11: and react
column12: accordingly. These are what‚Äôs called trickle-down behaviors.

column1: As the company grows and senior leadership is not always readily observable
column2: employees begin to act according to what their managers either actively reinforce through praise and promotion or passively reinforce by allowance. Over time
column3: employees become aware of which colleagues are being hired
column4: fired
column5: or promoted
column6: and why. Did Joe get hired because his references praised his incredible work ethic? Did Jill get fired because she wasn‚Äôt considered a team player? Did Jamie get promoted because he spent a lot of time socializing with company leadership? Hence
column7: employees quickly learn the ‚Äúrules of the game‚Äù to survive and thrive at their company
column8: and act accordingly
column9: which may have nothing to do with what aspirational values are plastered on the walls.

column1: Instead of letting your company become a corporate version of The Hunger Games
column2: leadership should actively prioritize behavior that‚Äôs congruent with company values.

column1: First
column2: you must ensure that all final candidates live up to your company‚Äôs values. For example
column3: I‚Äôve created an interview template to evaluate candidates on seven key traits: grit
column4: rigor
column5: impact
column6: teamwork
column7: ownership
column8: curiosity
column9: and polish. (I recommend you replace these with your own company‚Äôs aspirational values.)

column1: Another key trait (or the lack thereof) has been popularized by Professor Bob Sutton at the Stanford Graduate School of Business. The ‚ÄúNo Asshole Rule‚Äù dictates that no matter how great a candidate may be
column2: being an asshole is an automatic deal breaker. The way this can be implemented is through what I call the ‚ÄúOne Red Flag Rule
column3: ‚Äù which is based on the observation that pathological traits are sporadically
column4: not continually
column5: expressed ‚Äî except in severe cases.

column1: For example
column2: a narcissistic candidate may not act arrogant all the time
column3: but may express arrogant comments 10 times more
column4: on average
column5: than someone who doesn‚Äôt have this issue (e.g. a few times a day versus a few times a month). Thus
column6: if a candidate can‚Äôt suppress making an arrogant comment during a 30‚Äì60 minute interview
column7: they are likely to do this even more often when employed full-time.

column1: Drawing on best practices espoused by a leading investing firm
column2: Andreessen Horowitz
column3: I conduct up to six reference checks per candidate to evaluate ‚Äúvalues fit.‚Äù

column1: Nevertheless
column2: evaluating these traits during a brief interview can be challenging and lead to an inaccurate assessment. This is why I recommend conducting thorough reference checks
column3: based on research findings dictating that the best predictor of future behavior is past behavior.

column1: A 300-employee San Francisco startup
column2: Weebly
column3: goes so far as to invite job candidates to work an onsite trial week
column4: paid at fair market value. The reason is simple: It‚Äôs very hard to suppress values-incongruent behaviors when working closely with others for that amount of time. As Weebly‚Äôs CEO David Rusenko said:

column1: No matter how good your interviewers are
column2: any screener will result in false positives (people who you thought fit your values
column3: but don‚Äôt once they‚Äôre hired) and false negatives (people who you thought would not fit your values
column4: but would have if you had hired them). Companies that prioritize culture are willing to accept some false negatives in order to avoid false positives. If you get some false positives anyway
column5: the solution
column6: as entrepreneur and president of Y Combinator Sam Altman said
column7: is to ‚Äúfire quickly.‚Äù Few people have the psychological wherewithal to resign of their own accord if they still want the job
column8: but know they aren‚Äôt the right fit. That‚Äôs why baseball coaches have to pull starting pitchers out of the game when their performance declines
column9: and substitute a relief pitcher instead. In the same way
column10: it‚Äôs a manager‚Äôs job to be a good coach and pull people out
column11: compassionately
column12: so they can find a better fit in another role or company.

column1: The major issue that I‚Äôve seen with startups is that even if they claim to have a ‚ÄúNo Asshole Rule
column2: ‚Äù they hardly ever practice it. Rationales I‚Äôve heard include: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve decided that we‚Äôre not going to fire him because he‚Äôs a high performer‚Äù or ‚Äúfor that one bad trait
column3: he has four good traits going for him
column4: ‚Äù and
column5: of course
column6: the ‚Äú[data scientists/engineers/product managers] are hard to replace
column7: so we‚Äôll make do.‚Äù

column1: The best way to avoid this pitfall is to make values-congruent behavior a formal and prioritized part of your company‚Äôs performance management process. I‚Äôll share the system I designed and helped implement at my company. It starts with evaluating each employee on the Performance-Values Matrix. Whatever employee evaluation system you use ‚Äî whether that‚Äôs a formal annual review or regular one-on-ones ‚Äî employees should be evaluated on both their performance-based behavior and values-based behavior. Both should be quantified on a spectrum (e.g. a 1‚Äì10 point scale)
column2: but I‚Äôve simplified into a 2x2 matrix for illustrative purposes. (Note: I use gender-neutral language throughout this piece
column3: but I use ‚Äúguys‚Äù in the matrix due to space constraints. I also usually use more PC terms
column4: but the colorful language helps me cheekily make my point here.)

column1: Incompetent assholes are not only low-performers
column2: but their behavior is incongruent with company values. In this matrix
column3: they are in the lower-left quadrant and thus can only earn 25 percent of the maximum employee evaluation score. Hopefully
column4: there should be very few of these folks at your company
column5: but occasionally a few will slip through the hiring cracks
column6: or something may have happened that caused performance and values-congruent behavior to permanently degrade over time. Nevertheless
column7: they sap overall employee motivation by not contributing equally to the workload and are toxic to company morale. Needless to say
column8: incompetent assholes should be identified and fired as fast as possible.

column1: Competent assholes are high-performers
column2: but exhibit behavioral tendencies that are incongruent with company values. Given that ‚Äúasshole‚Äù is not a clinical term
column3: I will define it here as someone who lacks empathetic behavior to the point that it causes interpersonal issues. The biggest mistake that I see companies make is that they retain competent assholes because they are seen as critical to the company or difficult to replace. However
column4: by doing so
column5: they not only passively reinforce the competent asshole‚Äôs behavior by tolerating and promoting them
column6: but they implicitly send the message to the rest of the company that you can basically get away with murder so long as leadership believes you to be indispensable. You can imagine what kind of culture this creates over time. In contrast
column7: using the Performance-Values Matrix
column8: an employee who‚Äôs competent but a complete asshole can only earn 50 percent of the maximum employee evaluation score
column9: given that the other 50 percent of their evaluation is based on their values-congruent behavior.

column1: There‚Äôs a reason Professor Sutton called it the ‚ÄúNo Asshole Rule.‚Äù It‚Äôs because exceptions shouldn‚Äôt be made
column2: otherwise it shows your values are merely aspirational. The solution for competent assholes is a tactic that I call ‚Äúremediate or separate.‚Äù Despite the fact that these folks are strong performers
column3: it should be made clear that value-incongruent behavior is not tolerated and they will need to remediate their behavior in a measurable way within a given period of time.

column1: Thus
column2: competent assholes should be put on what I call a ‚ÄúValues Improvement Plan‚Äù (VIP). For this
column3: 360-degree reviews ‚Äî from an employee‚Äôs manager
column4: peers and direct reports ‚Äî are a great way to assess improvement
column5: or else be separated from the company. The reason I like giving these folks a chance is that sometimes employees that aren‚Äôt entirely inflexible (or pathological) can improve when they realize that their job depends on it. Often times
column6: this requires entering therapy or executive coaching with a skilled psychologist
column7: which is worth its weight in gold if the employee is willing to change.

column1: Incompetent nice guys and gals are the exemplars of your culture and are well-liked by almost everyone
column2: but unfortunately are not high-performers. Like competent assholes
column3: completely incompetent nice guys and gals also can only earn a 50 percent maximum possible employee rating. That‚Äôs because it is nearly as much of a sin to tolerate incompetent people as it is to tolerate assholes. Giving free license to someone to underperform just because they are kind or likeable sends the message that your company is not a meritocracy
column4: and that it‚Äôs more important to be socially skilled (or at worst
column5: be a brown noser). However
column6: the solution here is different than with component assholes
column7: in that the best solution is to manage or move them.

column1: Incompetent nice guys and gals should be put on a traditional performance improvement plan (PIP)
column2: and skillfully managed in order to give them training and feedback to improve their abilities. When their incompetence stems from a fundamental disconnect between their strengths and their current role‚Äôs demands (e.g. mediocre social skills in a client-facing role) one solution I‚Äôve seen prove fruitful is to move them into a different role. (The person may be an analytical whiz if moved to a more technical role). Of course
column3: if that is not possible or does not work out
column4: they should also be separated from the company. Encouraging incompetent nice guys and gals find a position that‚Äôs a better fit for their strengths is
column5: ironically
column6: the nicest thing you can do for them.

column1: Hopefully most of the employees at your company are both competent and nice; you must exhibit both behaviors in order to be in the top-right quadrant of the Performance-Values Matrix. Competent nice guys and gals earn up to 75 percent of the maximum employee evaluation score
column2: and should be both praised and given the opportunity for advancement. But in order to set the bar high
column3: employees should only earn the full 100 percent score if they exhibit both outstanding performance and value-congruent behavior. They are what Sarah Tavel of venture capital firm Greylock Partners calls the ‚Äúmitochondria‚Äù of startups
column4: because they are the company‚Äôs power plants ‚Äî adding value beyond their job description by asking and doing what is best for the company.

column1: Given how rare these individuals are
column2: founders should go out of their way to attract and retain them. By building this designation directly into the evaluation matrix
column3: outstanding nice guys and gals should be formally recognized and rewarded with raises and promotions. These are the current or future leaders of your company
column4: and need to be nurtured and cherished given that they are the foundation for your company‚Äôs performance and morale.

column1: Of note
column2: while I distinguish between competent and outstanding nice guys [and gals] in the matrix
column3: I do not do so for assholes. That‚Äôs because I believe it is nearly impossible to be an outstanding asshole. For example
column4: there is a myth of the ‚Äú10x engineer‚Äù in Silicon Valley
column5: where a truly talented engineer is 10 times as valuable and productive as an average engineer. Even if one engineer could possibly do the work of 10
column6: if they are an asshole ‚Äî especially in a management position ‚Äî they will decrease the performance of the people around them to such an extent that their team‚Äôs net productivity will break even or be at a loss long-term.

column1: When leaders become Machiavellian and hire and retain mercenary employees
column2: they resemble a Hermann Hesse novel reaching ‚Äúthe ‚Äúplace on the journey where everything falls apart‚Äù and the company‚Äôs culture degrades. While company engagement scores typically decline as they scale ‚Äî given they have to hire quickly from a limited talent pool and are too overworked to fire quickly ‚Äî this does not have to be an inevitable outcome.

column1: Culture can only improve when there‚Äôs a baseline of openness
column2: where people feel they can come forward and share concerns or opportunities for people and teams to do better. If people don‚Äôt trust what happens after they give their feedback
column3: then reviews will be ‚Äúpositive‚Äù and not provide any useful information. This requires both anonymous surveys and the promise that aggregate feedback is valued and will be acted upon.

column1: So if you want your company‚Äôs culture to be congruent with those noble aspirations written on your walls
column2: you must continually assess how well your employees are behaving compared to those aspirational values
column3: and develop ways to bridge the gap between aspiration and practice. I believe the best way to do this is to directly reinforce value-driven behavior
column4: including making it an integral part of employee‚Äôs reviews and weighting it as highly as performance.

column2: I‚Äôd like to walk through my inner journey the past few years.

column1: It‚Äôs a journey that‚Äôs left me itching for change ‚Äî and driving down to Los Angeles to set up a new home base is a big one!
I moved to Silicon Valley during the summer of 2012
column2: a little over five years ago. I had just graduated college and serendipitously landed here because of a new job offer. I was eager and anxious to start my career out here and frankly had no idea what to expect.

column1: As it turned out
column2: I lucked out ‚Äî Silicon Valley is one of the best places in the world for entrepreneurs
column3: engineers
column4: and anyone bold enough to try and change the world through technology.

column1: ...This was a stark contrast to life in my New Jersey hometown
column2: where most people went to the community college
column3: pursued 9-to-5 jobs
column4: and settled into comfortable lives by their mid-20s. There was very little space there for thinking big
column5: or taking risks
column6: or creating your own career path.

column1: So
column2: landing in San Francisco was the best kind of culture shock imaginable. Suddenly
column3: I was surrounded by technology and innovation and immersed in a community where challenging yourself was actually encouraged.

column1: The next three years of living in San Francisco had a path-altering impact on my life
column2: as I began to learn that crazy ideas aren‚Äôt ‚Äúcrazy‚Äù for those of us willing to put in the work and take a few risks.

column1: That first post-college job was as an analyst at Goldman Sachs
column2: where I was able to learn how tech company financials work at a fundamental level through working with CEOs and CFOs preparing for IPO rounds and acquisitions. This was hugely beneficial when I later moved on to working with some of those tech companies directly
column3: and planted the seeds of my interest in solving problems with software.

column1: After a year at Goldman Sachs
column2: however
column3: I realized that a career in banking was not what I wanted long term. I wanted to go back to being an engineer as I had been in college. So I decided to go against the grain and say goodbye to a ‚Äúsuccessful‚Äù position. Where was I off to next?

column1: Well
column2: I was on the brink of leaving to join as a systems engineer for a small industrial startup in the middle of the country. But after a random cold email followed by a long series of unexpected events
column3: I got an offer to join Andreessen Horowitz on the deal team. It was an opportunity I couldn‚Äôt pass up ‚Äî and thank God I didn‚Äôt.

column1: I spent the next two years at Andreessen Horowitz
column2: where I worked with and learned from the pioneers of the web
column3: like Marc Andreessen
column4: Ben Horowitz
column5: Chris Dixon
column6: and many others. I saw thousands of companies come through the doors ‚Äî I saw their ideas
column7: their teams

column1: When I left a16z
column2: I made the transition to software engineering. I was young and wanted to go out and just build stuff for the world. You could say that I had ‚Äúentrepreneur envy‚Äù ‚Äî I was eager to build products day to day
column3: and eventually start my own company. I‚Äôve written about my experience extensively in the past.

column1: This transition was nothing short of amazing. I was learning and growing at a break-neck pace. I was passionate and excited by my work. Frankly
column2: I was having so much fun being an engineer that not a single day felt like ‚Äúwork‚Äù.

column1: But beyond just loving my work
column2: I also felt empowered. Empowered to do things I never thought were possible before. Because being an engineer gave me freedom. Freedom to build anything I want
column3: whenever I want and wherever I want. The freedom to learn how everything works at a fundamental level. The freedom to teach and empower new developers. And most importantly
column4: the freedom to be a creator and literally
column5: create something from nothing.

column3: London

column12: technology

column3: for free. And I‚Äôm just one of thousands of learners using the Internet to access information that used to be limited to elite colleges like Stanford
column4: Berkeley

column3: art
column4: cuisines
column5: and activities to offer.

column1: Despite it being the center of tech and innovation for decades
column2: I‚Äôm not the only engineer to notice a degree of homogeny in Silicon Valley culture lately.

column1: What made it homogenous was that everyone seemed to have a similar story ‚Äî whether they were software engineers
column2: product managers
column3: venture capitalists or entrepreneurs. The career paths and goals may have been different from what my home town in New Jersey offered... but within the Valley

column3: $200M exits or their 200% YoY growth. What was once a beautiful thing ‚Äî the like-mindedness ‚Äî was no longer beautiful to me. I started to notice a lot of similar thinking ‚Äî group think as they call it.

column1: Silicon Valley is paradoxically a predictable place founded on the idea of being unpredictable.
This isn‚Äôt to say Silicon Valley hasn‚Äôt taught me anything important.
It‚Äôs been a perfect place to learn to take risks. A place to learn the value of creating your own path
column2: and to prove to myself that I can do it.

column1: While living here
column2: I‚Äôve made a deliberate effort to say yes to my dreams. I wanted the freedom to build anything I want
column3: and I earned that. I wanted to learn and grow as quickly as possible
column4: and I‚Äôve proven that. I wanted to meet people from around the world and learn from them

column2: I wanted to pave a path that is unique to me

column1: Looking back
column2: when I left Andreessen Horowitz to pursue this path
column3: I set out a three-part roadmap for myself:

column1: My fascination with blockchains started when we first made the investment in Coinbase at a16z
column2: and ever since

column4: which helped me further dive deeper into the space. After Coinbase
column5: I continued to tinker and teach myself various aspects of blockchain

column1: Leading the path I want to lead doesn‚Äôt require me to be in Silicon valley anymore. I don‚Äôt need to be here to follow my personal roadmap. Having the freedom of an engineer to learn and grow as an entrepreneur
column2: writer
column3: and speaker has opened me up to a whole new world. It made me realize that I can be an engineer
column4: entrepreneur
column5: writer and speaker from anywhere in the world.

column1: The world is becoming increasingly global. Silicon Valley is just one way of living. One way of thinking. One way of viewing the world. But there‚Äôs so many other ways. Because after all
column2: technology is global
column3: engineering is global
column4: innovation is global and entrepreneurship is global.

column1: It‚Äôs evident by the fact that we now see countries like India and China leap frog generations of western technology and even inventing their own ways ‚Äî take mPesa in Kenya

column1: Beyond this

column4: like New York

column1: So then a crazy idea came to my head. Can I leave Silicon Valley and still pursue my dreams? Can I still build a massive and world-changing company? Can I still make a big impact in this world?
The answer to that increasingly became a clear yes.
Of course
column2: there‚Äôs a strong argument for staying in Silicon Valley. After all
column3: this place has a massive network of entrepreneurs and people who ‚Äúget it‚Äù. This place knows how to breed amazing startups. Moreover
column4: I‚Äôve personally built up a great network in Silicon Valley over the past five years. I could easily stay and lead a very successful life here

column1: But frankly
column2: I don‚Äôt want to. That feels a bit too easy. I‚Äôm young
column3: passionate
column4: and driven ‚Äî I can‚Äôt let inertia

column7: and any other intellectual property.

column1: Practically

column3: all other things equal

column1: So

column1: So liquidation value < book value. Although they both account for tangible assets

column1: If your box works well

column1: Let‚Äôs say you are projecting cash flows over n years. What happens after that ? This is the question addressed by the Terminal Value (TV)

column2: and keep generating indefinite cash flows after the n years period. You can then apply the formula for Terminal Value : : TV = CFn+1/(r- g) with ‚Äúr‚Äù being the discount rate and ‚Äúg‚Äù being the expected growth rate.

column1: Option 2 : you consider an exit after the n year period. First
column2: you want to estimate the future value of the acquisition
column3: for example with the comparable method transaction (see above). Then
column4: you have to discount this future value to get its net present value. TV = exit value/(1+r)^n

column1: The First Chicago Method answers to a specific situation: what if your box has a small chance of becoming huge? How to assess this potential?
The First Chicago Method (named after the late First Chicago Bank ‚Äî if you ask) deals with this issue by making three valuations: a worst case scenario (tiny box)
column2: a normal case scenario (normal box)
column3: a best case scenario (big box).

column1: Each valuation is made with the DCF Method (or
column2: if not possible
column3: with internal rate of return formula or with multiples). You then decide of a percentage reflecting the probability of each scenario to happen. Your valuation according to the First Chicago Method is the weigthed average of each case.

The unpleasant process of calling up a job applicant‚Äôs former boss to gab about the candidate‚Äôs pluses and ‚Äúdeltas‚Äù is just silly. Maybe if we all just agree to stop doing it
column2: the practice will go away

column4: I‚Äôve learned a better way to hire that leverages a universal human attribute ‚Äî namely
column5: the fact that we‚Äôre all lazy.

column1: What‚Äôs my beef with reference checks? They don‚Äôt accomplish the job we intend them to do. In a startup
column2: you can‚Äôt afford to hire B-players. But reference checks
column3: which are intended to do the screening
column4: fail to eliminate these candidates who are just so-so. This happens because the person giving the reference has no incentive to say anything but good things about the candidate. Telling the whole truth
column5: warts and all
column6: could expose the former boss to a defamation lawsuit. But legal action aside
column7: no one likes to speak poorly about an ex-colleague. It‚Äôs bad karma and just feels icky.

column1: Instead of asking a reference to call you and spend an awkward half-hour chitchatting about pretty much nothing
column2: try a technique I‚Äôve come to call it the ‚Äúaverage-need-not-apply‚Äù method. Though I‚Äôm not sure who invented it
column3: the approach was taught to me by Irv Grousbeck at Stanford.

column1: First
column2: send the email below to people who have worked with the candidate. This can include the references he or she provided
column3: but it‚Äôs a good idea to find other people who‚Äôve worked with the candidate as well. I‚Äôd recommend letting the candidate know you may reach out to people they‚Äôve worked with who are not on their list of references and confirm that‚Äôs ok with them. LinkedIn makes finding former co-workers a snap
column4: and the more people you send it to
column5: the better it will work.

column1: After you send this email
column2: one of the following three things will happen:

column1: Scenario A: It‚Äôs most likely that you will hear nothing back from the reference.
Congratulations! You saved yourself from hiring a B-player
column2: or worse. You also saved yourself and the reference from having to conduct an uncomfortable
column3: time-wasting phone call.

column1: Scenario B: You receive an email back from the reference informing you that the candidate was in fact exceptional and they‚Äôd be happy to tell you more.
Congratulations! Looks like you found a star
column2: now it‚Äôs time to have a chat to confirm the candidate is as great as you think they are and learn more about your soon-to-be employee.

column1: Scenario C: You receive a call within 5 minutes of sending your email asking if the candidate is on the market for a new job
column2: and if so
column3: can you have the candidate call the reference back ASAP.

column1: Congratulations! You‚Äôve definitely found a winner. Don‚Äôt let the candidate return the call and make an offer immediately before someone else does. This scenario has actually happened to me a few times. It‚Äôs the best predictor of the quality of candidate I‚Äôve ever seen. We immediately made offers to those candidates and without fail they turned out to be our best hires.

So why does this method work? It leverages the power of choosing a default option. Research by Eric Johnson and Daniel Goldstein demonstrated how opt-in versus opt-out decisions dramatically affect participation in organ donation programs; using a default option in the reference check allows you to affect results in a similar way.
Unlike the traditional reference check method
column2: which elicits an overly positive response in order to preserve social harmony
column3: the ‚Äúaverage-need-not-apply‚Äù method uses the opposite bias. By giving the reference an easy default ‚Äî in this case doing nothing ‚Äî this technique gauges just how great the reference thinks the candidate is.

column1: Those who have a strong positive opinion of a candidate take the time to write back. By using this method
column2: an employer can collect more data points on the potential hire with just a few emails instead of scheduling phone calls. In my experience
column3: the results are binary. Most of the emails yield glowing replies or radio silence; both speak volumes.

column1: By utilizing a bit of behavioral engineering instead of performing the reference check
column2: employers can make better hiring decisions and make the hiring process better for everyone involved ‚Äî except maybe the B-players.

column2: in Portuguese by Raphael Mielle
column3: and in Spanish by Alberto Martinez de Arenaza.

column1: A startup is like a box. A very special box.
The box has a value. The more things you put in the box
column2: the more its value increases. Add a patent in the box
column3: the value increases. Add a kick-ass management team in the box
column4: the value increases. Easy
column5: right?

column1: The box is also magic. When you put $1 inside
column2: it will return you $2
column3: $3 or even $10! Amazing!

column1: Problem is
column2: building a box can be very expensive. So you need to go and see people with money ‚Äî let‚Äôs call them investors ‚Äî and offer them a deal that sounds a bit like this:

column1: But how much should ‚ÄúX‚Äù be?
It depends on the Pre-Money Valuation
column2: e.g. the value of the box at the moment of the investment. But calculating the Pre-Money Valuation is tricky. This article will take you through 9 different valuation methods to better let you understand how to determine Pre-Money Valuation.

column1: The Berkus Method is a simple and convenient rule of thumb to estimate the value of your box. It was designed by Dave Berkus
column2: a renowned author and business angel investor. The starting point is: do you believe that the box can reach $20M in revenue by the fifth year of business? If the answer is yes
column3: then you can assess your box against the 5 key criteria for building boxes.

column1: This will give you a rough idea of how much your box is worth (AKA pre-money valuation) and more importantly
column2: what you should improve. Note that according to Berkus
column3: the pre-money valuation should not be more than $2M.

column1: The Berkus Method is meant for pre-revenue startups. To read more about the Berkus Method
column2: click here.

column1: The Risk Factor Summation Method or RFS Method is a slightly more evolved version of the Berkus Method. First
column2: you determine an initial value for your box. Then you adjust said value for 12 risk factors inherent to box-building.

column1: Initial value is determined as the average value for a similar box in your area
column2: and risk factors are modelled as multiples of $250k
column3: ranging from $500k for a very low risk
column4: to -$500k for a very high risk. The most difficult part here
column5: and in most valuation methods
column6: is actualy finding data about similar boxes.

column1: The Risk Factor Summation Method is meant for pre-revenue startups. To read more about the Risk Factor Summation Method
column2: click here.

column1: The Scorecard Valuation Method is a more elaborate approach to the box valuation problem. It starts the same way as the RFS method i.e. you determine a base valuation for your box
column2: then you adjust the value for a certain set of criteria. Nothing new
column3: except that those criteria are themselves weighed up based on their impact on the overall success of the project.

column1: This method can also be found under the name of Bill Payne Method
column2: considering 6 criteria: Management (30%)
column3: Size of opportunity (25%)
column4: Product or Service (10%)
column5: Sales channels (10%)
column6: Stage of business (10%) and Other factors (15%).

column1: The Scorecard Valuation Method is meant for pre-revenue startups. To read more about the Scorecard Valuation Method
column2: click here.

column1: The Comparable Transactions Method is really just a rule of three.
Depending on the type of box you are building
column2: you want to find an indicator which will be a good proxy for the value of your box. This indicator can be specific to your industry: Monthly Recurring Revenue (Saas)
column3: HR headcount (Interim)
column4: Number of outlets (Retail)
column5: Patent filed (Medtech/Biotech)
column6: Weekly Active Users or WAU (Messengers). Most of the time
column7: you can just take lines from the P&L : sales
column8: gross margin
column9: EBITDA
column10: etc.

column1: The Comparables Transactions Method is meant for pre- and post-revenue startups. To read more about the Comparable Transactions Method
column2: click here.

column1: Forget about how magical the box is
column2: and see how much 1 pound of cardboard is worth.

column1: The book value refers to the net worth of the company i.e. the tangible assets of the box i.e. the ‚Äúhard parts‚Äù of the box.
The Book Value Method is particularly irrelevant for startups as it is focused on the ‚Äútangible‚Äù value of the company
column2: while most startups focus on intangible assets : RD (for a biotech)
column3: user base and software development (for a Web startup)
column4: etc. To read more about the Book Value method
column5: click here.

column1: Rarely good from a seller perspective
column2: the liquidation value is
column3: as implied by its name
column4: the valuation you apply to a company when it is going out of business.

column1: Things that counts for a liquidation value estimation are all the tangible assets: Real Estate
column2: Equipment
column3: Inventory... Everything you can find a buyer for in a short span of time. The mindset is: if I sell whatever the company can in less than two months
column4: how much money does that make ? All the intangibles on the other hand are considered worthless in a liquidation process (the underlying assumption is that if it was worth something
column5: it would have already been sold at the time you enter in liquidation): patents
column6: copyright
column7: and any other intellectual property.

column1: Practically
column2: the liquidation value is the sum of the scrap value of all the tangible assets of the company.

column1: For an investor
column2: the liquidation value is useful as a parameter to evaluate the risk of the investment: a higher potential liquidation value means a lower risk. For example
column3: all other things equal
column4: it is preferable to invest in a company that owns its equipment compared to one that leases it. If everything goes wrong and you go out of business
column5: at least you can get some money selling the equipment
column6: whereas nothing if you lease it.

column1: So
column2: what is the difference between book value and liquidation value ? If a startup really had to sell its assets in the case of a bankruptcy
column3: the value it would get from the sale would likely be below its book value
column4: due to the adverse conditions of the sales.

column1: So liquidation value < book value. Although they both account for tangible assets
column2: the context in which those assets are valued differs. As Ben Graham points out
column3: the liquidation value measures what the stockholders could get out of the business
column4: while the book value measures what they have put into the business.

column1: If your box works well
column2: it brings in a certain amount of cash every year. Consequently
column3: you could say that the current value of the box is the sum of all the future cash flows over the next years. And that is exactly the reasoning behind the DCF method.

column1: Let‚Äôs say you are projecting cash flows over n years. What happens after that ? This is the question addressed by the Terminal Value (TV)
Option 1: you consider the business will keep growing at a steady pace
column2: and keep generating indefinite cash flows after the n years period. You can then apply the formula for Terminal Value : : TV = CFn+1/(r- g) with ‚Äúr‚Äù being the discount rate and ‚Äúg‚Äù being the expected growth rate.

column1: Option 2 : you consider an exit after the n year period. First
column2: you want to estimate the future value of the acquisition
column3: for example with the comparable method transaction (see above). Then
column4: you have to discount this future value to get its net present value. TV = exit value/(1+r)^n

column1: Although technically
column2: you could use it for post-revenue startups
column3: it is just not meant for startup valuation. To read more about the DCF method
column4: click here.

column1: The First Chicago Method answers to a specific situation: what if your box has a small chance of becoming huge? How to assess this potential?
The First Chicago Method (named after the late First Chicago Bank ‚Äî if you ask) deals with this issue by making three valuations: a worst case scenario (tiny box)
column2: a normal case scenario (normal box)
column3: a best case scenario (big box).

column1: Each valuation is made with the DCF Method (or
column2: if not possible
column3: with internal rate of return formula or with multiples). You then decide of a percentage reflecting the probability of each scenario to happen. Your valuation according to the First Chicago Method is the weigthed average of each case.

column1: The First Chicago Method is meant for post-revenue startups. You can read more about the First Chicago Method here.
As its name indicate
column2: the Venture Capital Method stands from the viewpoint of the investor.

column1: An investor is always looking for a specific return on investment
column2: let‚Äôs say 20x. Besides
column3: according to industry standards
column4: the investor thinks that your box could be sold for $100M in 8 years. Based on those two elements
column5: the investor can easily determine the maximum price he or she is willing to pay for investing in your box
column6: after adjusting for dilution.

column1: The Venture Capital Method is meant for pre- and post-revenue startups. To read more about the Venture Capital Method
column2: click here.

column1: Congratulations! If you made it this far
column2: you know 9 valuation methods. So you must be screaming from the inside: what is the best valuation method ?!

column1: First
column2: keep in mind that the only methods really used by VCs are comparables and a rough estimate of how much dilution is acceptable by the founders ‚Äî e.g. giving out 15% to 25% for a seed round comprised between ‚Ç¨300k and ‚Ç¨500k
column3: or making sure that the founders remain majority shareholders after a Series A.

column1: Second
column2: let us remember that valuations are nothing but formalized guesstimates. Valuations never show the true value of your company. They just show two things: (1) how bad the market is willing to invest in your little red box
column3: and (2) how bad you are willing to accept it.

column1: Having said that
column2: I find that the best valuation method is the one described by Pierre Entremont
column3: early-stage investor at Otium Capital
column4: in this excellent article. According to him
column5: you should start from defining your needs and then negotiate dilution:

column1: Valuations are a good starting point when considering fundraising. They help builing up the reasoning behind the figures and objectify the discussion. But in the end
column2: they are just the theoretical introduction to a more significant game of supply and demand.

column1: Use the Performance-Values Matrix to build an Outstanding Culture
Every time I walk into a new company I‚Äôm advising
column2: I invariably encounter a set of noble values prominently displayed on the walls. The first thing I‚Äôve trained myself to do is to not take them as gospel
column3: and instead carefully observe how people really behave
column4: which will tell me the actual values I need to know.

column1: It‚Äôs not that most companies are disingenuous about the values they espouse. One of Enron‚Äôs ‚Äúaspirational values‚Äù was integrity
column2: which may have genuinely expressed who they wanted to be at the beginning. But over time
column3: this proclaimed value didn‚Äôt reflect their ‚Äúpracticed values‚Äù which were revealed when they committed fraud.

column1: Why does a gap usually exist between a company‚Äôs aspirational and practiced values? You would think that to alleviate cognitive dissonance
column2: most employees would feel an inherent need to practice what they preach ‚Äî or are preached at to do. But to truly close the gap
column3: you have to attack the problem at its root: The issue is that aspirational values almost always come from
column4: and must be rectified at
column5: the top.

column1: According to the theory of behaviorism
column2: no behavior will persist long term unless it is being perpetuated by either a positive reinforcer (providing a reward
column3: such as a promotion or praise) or a negative reinforcer (removing a punishment
column4: such as a probationary period or undesirable tasks). Thus
column5: when companies start
column6: leaders set the company‚Äôs values not by what they write on the walls
column7: but by how they actually act. For example
column8: do they stay late and burn the midnight oil? Or do they leave early to be with their families? According to social learning theory
column9: these behaviors become socialized
column10: and rank-and-file employees who take their cues from these leaders act
column11: and react
column12: accordingly. These are what‚Äôs called trickle-down behaviors.

column1: As the company grows and senior leadership is not always readily observable
column2: employees begin to act according to what their managers either actively reinforce through praise and promotion or passively reinforce by allowance. Over time
column3: employees become aware of which colleagues are being hired
column4: fired
column5: or promoted
column6: and why. Did Joe get hired because his references praised his incredible work ethic? Did Jill get fired because she wasn‚Äôt considered a team player? Did Jamie get promoted because he spent a lot of time socializing with company leadership? Hence
column7: employees quickly learn the ‚Äúrules of the game‚Äù to survive and thrive at their company
column8: and act accordingly
column9: which may have nothing to do with what aspirational values are plastered on the walls.

column1: Instead of letting your company become a corporate version of The Hunger Games
column2: leadership should actively prioritize behavior that‚Äôs congruent with company values.

column1: First
column2: you must ensure that all final candidates live up to your company‚Äôs values. For example
column3: I‚Äôve created an interview template to evaluate candidates on seven key traits: grit
column4: rigor
column5: impact
column6: teamwork
column7: ownership
column8: curiosity
column9: and polish. (I recommend you replace these with your own company‚Äôs aspirational values.)

column1: Another key trait (or the lack thereof) has been popularized by Professor Bob Sutton at the Stanford Graduate School of Business. The ‚ÄúNo Asshole Rule‚Äù dictates that no matter how great a candidate may be
column2: being an asshole is an automatic deal breaker. The way this can be implemented is through what I call the ‚ÄúOne Red Flag Rule
column3: ‚Äù which is based on the observation that pathological traits are sporadically
column4: not continually
column5: expressed ‚Äî except in severe cases.

column1: For example
column2: a narcissistic candidate may not act arrogant all the time
column3: but may express arrogant comments 10 times more
column4: on average
column5: than someone who doesn‚Äôt have this issue (e.g. a few times a day versus a few times a month). Thus
column6: if a candidate can‚Äôt suppress making an arrogant comment during a 30‚Äì60 minute interview
column7: they are likely to do this even more often when employed full-time.

column1: Drawing on best practices espoused by a leading investing firm
column2: Andreessen Horowitz
column3: I conduct up to six reference checks per candidate to evaluate ‚Äúvalues fit.‚Äù

column1: Nevertheless
column2: evaluating these traits during a brief interview can be challenging and lead to an inaccurate assessment. This is why I recommend conducting thorough reference checks
column3: based on research findings dictating that the best predictor of future behavior is past behavior.

column1: A 300-employee San Francisco startup
column2: Weebly
column3: goes so far as to invite job candidates to work an onsite trial week
column4: paid at fair market value. The reason is simple: It‚Äôs very hard to suppress values-incongruent behaviors when working closely with others for that amount of time. As Weebly‚Äôs CEO David Rusenko said:

column1: No matter how good your interviewers are
column2: any screener will result in false positives (people who you thought fit your values
column3: but don‚Äôt once they‚Äôre hired) and false negatives (people who you thought would not fit your values
column4: but would have if you had hired them). Companies that prioritize culture are willing to accept some false negatives in order to avoid false positives. If you get some false positives anyway
column5: the solution
column6: as entrepreneur and president of Y Combinator Sam Altman said
column7: is to ‚Äúfire quickly.‚Äù Few people have the psychological wherewithal to resign of their own accord if they still want the job
column8: but know they aren‚Äôt the right fit. That‚Äôs why baseball coaches have to pull starting pitchers out of the game when their performance declines
column9: and substitute a relief pitcher instead. In the same way
column10: it‚Äôs a manager‚Äôs job to be a good coach and pull people out
column11: compassionately
column12: so they can find a better fit in another role or company.

column1: The major issue that I‚Äôve seen with startups is that even if they claim to have a ‚ÄúNo Asshole Rule
column2: ‚Äù they hardly ever practice it. Rationales I‚Äôve heard include: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve decided that we‚Äôre not going to fire him because he‚Äôs a high performer‚Äù or ‚Äúfor that one bad trait
column3: he has four good traits going for him
column4: ‚Äù and
column5: of course
column6: the ‚Äú[data scientists/engineers/product managers] are hard to replace

column1: The best way to avoid this pitfall is to make values-congruent behavior a formal and prioritized part of your company‚Äôs performance management process. I‚Äôll share the system I designed and helped implement at my company. It starts with evaluating each employee on the Performance-Values Matrix. Whatever employee evaluation system you use ‚Äî whether that‚Äôs a formal annual review or regular one-on-ones ‚Äî employees should be evaluated on both their performance-based behavior and values-based behavior. Both should be quantified on a spectrum (e.g. a 1‚Äì10 point scale)
column2: but I‚Äôve simplified into a 2x2 matrix for illustrative purposes. (Note: I use gender-neutral language throughout this piece
column3: but I use ‚Äúguys‚Äù in the matrix due to space constraints. I also usually use more PC terms
column4: but the colorful language helps me cheekily make my point here.)

column1: Incompetent assholes are not only low-performers
column2: but their behavior is incongruent with company values. In this matrix
column3: they are in the lower-left quadrant and thus can only earn 25 percent of the maximum employee evaluation score. Hopefully
column4: there should be very few of these folks at your company
column5: but occasionally a few will slip through the hiring cracks
column6: or something may have happened that caused performance and values-congruent behavior to permanently degrade over time. Nevertheless
column7: they sap overall employee motivation by not contributing equally to the workload and are toxic to company morale. Needless to say
column8: incompetent assholes should be identified and fired as fast as possible.

column1: Competent assholes are high-performers
column2: but exhibit behavioral tendencies that are incongruent with company values. Given that ‚Äúasshole‚Äù is not a clinical term
column3: I will define it here as someone who lacks empathetic behavior to the point that it causes interpersonal issues. The biggest mistake that I see companies make is that they retain competent assholes because they are seen as critical to the company or difficult to replace. However
column4: by doing so
column5: they not only passively reinforce the competent asshole‚Äôs behavior by tolerating and promoting them
column6: but they implicitly send the message to the rest of the company that you can basically get away with murder so long as leadership believes you to be indispensable. You can imagine what kind of culture this creates over time. In contrast
column7: using the Performance-Values Matrix
column8: an employee who‚Äôs competent but a complete asshole can only earn 50 percent of the maximum employee evaluation score
column9: given that the other 50 percent of their evaluation is based on their values-congruent behavior.

column1: There‚Äôs a reason Professor Sutton called it the ‚ÄúNo Asshole Rule.‚Äù It‚Äôs because exceptions shouldn‚Äôt be made
column2: otherwise it shows your values are merely aspirational. The solution for competent assholes is a tactic that I call ‚Äúremediate or separate.‚Äù Despite the fact that these folks are strong performers
column3: it should be made clear that value-incongruent behavior is not tolerated and they will need to remediate their behavior in a measurable way within a given period of time.

column1: Thus
column2: competent assholes should be put on what I call a ‚ÄúValues Improvement Plan‚Äù (VIP). For this
column3: 360-degree reviews ‚Äî from an employee‚Äôs manager
column4: peers and direct reports ‚Äî are a great way to assess improvement
column5: or else be separated from the company. The reason I like giving these folks a chance is that sometimes employees that aren‚Äôt entirely inflexible (or pathological) can improve when they realize that their job depends on it. Often times
column6: this requires entering therapy or executive coaching with a skilled psychologist
column7: which is worth its weight in gold if the employee is willing to change.

column1: Incompetent nice guys and gals are the exemplars of your culture and are well-liked by almost everyone
column2: but unfortunately are not high-performers. Like competent assholes
column3: completely incompetent nice guys and gals also can only earn a 50 percent maximum possible employee rating. That‚Äôs because it is nearly as much of a sin to tolerate incompetent people as it is to tolerate assholes. Giving free license to someone to underperform just because they are kind or likeable sends the message that your company is not a meritocracy
column4: and that it‚Äôs more important to be socially skilled (or at worst
column5: be a brown noser). However
column6: the solution here is different than with component assholes
column7: in that the best solution is to manage or move them.

column1: Incompetent nice guys and gals should be put on a traditional performance improvement plan (PIP)
column2: and skillfully managed in order to give them training and feedback to improve their abilities. When their incompetence stems from a fundamental disconnect between their strengths and their current role‚Äôs demands (e.g. mediocre social skills in a client-facing role) one solution I‚Äôve seen prove fruitful is to move them into a different role. (The person may be an analytical whiz if moved to a more technical role). Of course
column3: if that is not possible or does not work out
column4: they should also be separated from the company. Encouraging incompetent nice guys and gals find a position that‚Äôs a better fit for their strengths is
column5: ironically
column6: the nicest thing you can do for them.

column1: Hopefully most of the employees at your company are both competent and nice; you must exhibit both behaviors in order to be in the top-right quadrant of the Performance-Values Matrix. Competent nice guys and gals earn up to 75 percent of the maximum employee evaluation score
column2: and should be both praised and given the opportunity for advancement. But in order to set the bar high
column3: employees should only earn the full 100 percent score if they exhibit both outstanding performance and value-congruent behavior. They are what Sarah Tavel of venture capital firm Greylock Partners calls the ‚Äúmitochondria‚Äù of startups
column4: because they are the company‚Äôs power plants ‚Äî adding value beyond their job description by asking and doing what is best for the company.

column1: This stage is potentially the most challenging. You still have a relatively small team and few resources
column2: but you‚Äôre being asked to deliver increasingly sophisticated and diverse analytics to the business
column3: and your work can directly impact the success or failure of the company as a whole. No pressure.

column1: It‚Äôs important to make forward progress here while making sure that you continue to lay the groundwork for future phases of your growth. The decisions you make in this phase can cause you to charge straight into a brick wall if you don‚Äôt think hard about the future.
It‚Äôs easy to get carried away with yourself and begin investing in heavy-duty data infrastructure. Don‚Äôt do this. At this stage
column2: major infrastructure investments are still an expensive distraction. Here are some suggestions on how to stay agile:

column1: Avoiding expensive boondoggles will keep you focused on solving real business problems.

This stage is all about creating analytics processes that scale. You need to balance getting answers that you need today with implementing analytics practices that will scale as you continue growing your team.

At 150 employees you‚Äôll probably only have a small team (3‚Äì6) full-time focused on analytics. By the time you have 500 employees you could easily have 30 or more. 3‚Äì6 analysts can operate in a fairly ad-hoc manner
column2: exchanging knowledge (and code) informally. By the time you have 8+ analysts
column3: this begins to break down very quickly.

column1: If you don‚Äôt manage this transition well
column2: you‚Äôll actually perform less well as your team grows: it will take you longer to produce meaningful insights
column3: and your answers will be of lower quality. This is simply a function of non-linear complexity: you‚Äôll have more data being produced and more analysts working with it. In order to combat this
column4: you need processes to keep them working together reliably.

column1: Don‚Äôt accept excuses. Doing analytics right at this level is hard work
column2: and it requires a talented and motivated team that is constantly innovating and improving. Code reviews take time and energy. Analysts aren‚Äôt used to having to test their code. And documentation is painstaking. There will be resistance to doing things this way
column3: especially among your long-term team members who remember the ‚Äúgood old days‚Äù. But as complexity increases
column4: you need to evolve your processes to adapt.

column1: These processes will actually make analytics easier
column2: faster
column3: and more reliable
column4: but implementing them will feel like pulling teeth. If you‚Äôre serious about scaling analytics
column5: you‚Äôll push through.

column1: I‚Äôve come to each one of these recommendations after years of doing it myself within companies and now scaling the approach as a consultant. The opportunity to work with a range of similar clients has made it incredibly clear just how rare it is for companies to do this stuff well.
If you take all of the recommendations in this post
column2: you will literally be one of the highest-functioning analytics organizations in the world. Not a bad competitive advantage.

column2: imagine you‚Äôre out with friends on a Tuesday night and want to keep the conversation going. You open Yelp to find nearby recommendations and see a list of bars. The group turns into a huddle of faces staring down at their phones comparing bars. They scrutinize the photos of each
column3: comparing cocktail drinks. Is this menu still relevant to the original desire of the group?

column1: It‚Äôs not that bars aren‚Äôt a good choice
column2: it‚Äôs that Yelp substituted the group‚Äôs original question (‚Äúwhere can we go to keep talking?‚Äù) with a different question (‚Äúwhat‚Äôs a bar with good photos of cocktails?‚Äù) all by shaping the menu.

column1: Moreover
column2: the group falls for the illusion that Yelp‚Äôs menu represents a complete set of choices for where to go. While looking down at their phones
column3: they don‚Äôt see the park across the street with a band playing live music. They miss the pop-up gallery on the other side of the street serving crepes and coffee. Neither of those show up on Yelp‚Äôs menu.

column3: a prize!) or nothing. Addictiveness is maximized when the rate of reward is most variable.

column1: Taking a quick pause for physical activity can be extremely beneficial ‚Äî and that doesn‚Äôt mean you have to squeeze in a SoulCycle class at lunch.

column1: While Google protected its monopoly on the dying search advertising market

column1: In late 2015

column1: Devices running iOS were responsible for an estimated 75% of Google‚Äôs revenue from mobile search ads
column2: so by making this move
column3: Apple was simultaneously weighing in decisively on the great ad blocking debate of the 2010s and dealing a substantial blow to the future of online advertising.

column1: A year later

column3: so too did ad blocking. The number of people blocking ads on a mobile device grew 102% from 2015 to 2016; by the end of 2016
column4: an estimated 16% of smartphone users globally were blocking ads when browsing the internet on a mobile device. The number was as high as 25% for desktop and laptop users in the United States
column5: a country that accounted for 47% of Google‚Äôs revenue.

column1: The people most likely to block ads were also the most valuable demographic: millennials and high earners.
Internet users had spoken
column2: and they hated ads.

column1: In early 2017
column2: Google announced its plans to build an ad blocker into its popular Google Chrome browser. Google‚Äôs ad blocker would only block ads that were deemed unacceptable by the Coalition For Better Ads
column3: effectively allowing the company to use its dominant web browser to strengthen its already dominant advertising business.

column1: Even after making this desperate and legally questionable move
column2: it would quickly become clear to Google that even though ads were getting better
column3: ad blocking numbers would continue to rise. Google had given even more people a small taste of what an ad-free internet experience could look like.

column1: The company discovered that it wasn‚Äôt just annoying ads that people didn‚Äôt like; it was ads in general.
A key platform where Google served ads was YouTube
column2: which it bought in 2006 and quickly turned into one of its biggest entities. But even with a sixth of the world visiting this video-sharing behemoth every month
column3: YouTube never became profitable. In an attempt to combat the effect of ad blockers
column4: YouTube launched an ad-free subscription model in late 2015
column5: but the subscription numbers were underwhelming.

column1: YouTube‚Äôs already insurmountable problems multiplied in early 2017 as advertisers began to pull out amid ad placement controversies
column2: and huge revenue generators began to leave the site.

column1: Even those who weren‚Äôt blocking ads had trained themselves to ignore them entirely. Researchers dubbed this phenomenon ‚Äúbanner blindness‚Äù. The average banner ad was clicked on by a dismal 0.06% of viewers
column2: and of those clicks
column3: roughly 50% were accidental.

column1: Research showed that 54% of users reported a lack of trust as their reason for not clicking banner ads and 33% found them completely intolerable. These figures painted a pretty grim picture for the sustainability of online advertising
column2: but especially for Google‚Äôs position within the industry.

column1: If losing a major portion of their audience and annoying the rest wasn‚Äôt bad enough
column2: Google also failed to get ahead of one of the biggest shifts in technology‚Äôs history. They recognized the importance of artificial intelligence but their approach missed the mark. Since Google‚Äôs search pillar had become unstable
column3: a lot was riding on the company‚Äôs strategy for artificial intelligence.

column1: Google‚Äôs then-CEO Sundar Pichai famously predicted in 2016 that ‚Äúthe next big step will be for the very concept of the ‚Äòdevice‚Äô to fade away‚Äù and that ‚Äúover time
column2: the computer itself ‚Äî whatever its form factor ‚Äî will be an intelligent assistant helping you through your day. We will move from mobile first to an AI first world.‚Äù

column1: Google‚Äôs ability to acknowledge the coming trend and still fail to land in front of it reminded many observers of its catastrophic failures in the booming industries of social media and instant messaging.
Meanwhile
column3: Amazon released a product called Amazon Echo
column4: a small speaker that could sit in your home and answer questions
column5: perform tasks
column6: and buy things online for you. The Echo was a smash success. Google released its copycat product

column1: Alexa ‚Äî the assistant that lived inside the Echo ‚Äî on the other hand
column2: was quickly integrated into several products and services
column3: and its monetization model was clear
column4: viable
column5: and most importantly future-friendly. The Echo made it easy to order products through Amazon
column6: and every time someone used an Echo to purchase something
column7: Amazon made money.

column1: Google extended the reach of their virtual assistant by building it into Android
column2: but doing so still didn‚Äôt provide an answer for how the technology would generate enough revenue to sustain Google‚Äôs expanding repertoire of expensive innovations.

column1: Google‚Äôs ads relied on screens
column2: yet voice interaction subverted screens entirely. Google briefly tried playing audio ads with the Google Home
column3: but consumers were far from receptive. Investors started to voice their concerns in 2017
column4: but Sundar Pichai told them not to worry
column5: leaving them to assume that Google would use their age-old strategy and analyze users‚Äô voice searches so that users could be shown more suitable ads on devices with screens.

column1: Headlines in early 2017 proclaimed that ‚ÄúAlexa Just Conquered CES. The World is Next.‚Äù Amazon then made their technology available to third party manufacturers
column2: putting even more distance between the two companies. Amazon had already beaten Google once before
column3: holding 54% of the cloud computing market (compared to Google‚Äôs 3%) in 2016
column4: and they were just getting started.

column1: By early 2017
column2: Amazon had begun closing in on the entire retail industry.

column1: At its peak
column2: Google had a massive and loyal user-base across a staggering number of products
column3: but advertising revenue was the glue that held everything together. As the numbers waned
column4: Google‚Äôs core began to buckle under the weight of its vast empire.

column1: Google was a driving force in the technology industry ever since its disruptive entry in 1998. But in a world where people despised ads
column2: Google‚Äôs business model was not innovation-friendly

column1: In a few short years

column1: Bitcoin was designed

column1: How does it do this? In short
column2: by emulating gold‚Äôs production digitally. Gold is physically mined out of the ground. Bitcoin is also ‚Äòmined‚Äô
column3: but digitally. The production of bitcoin is controlled by code that dictates you must find a specific answer to a given problem in order to unlock new bitcoins.

column1: In technical terms
column2: bitcoin utilizes the same proof-of-work system that Hashcash devised in 1997. This system dictates that one must find an input that when hashed
column3: creates an output with a specific number of preceding zeros

column2: incidentally
column3: in cryptocurrency comes from. Cryptographic hash functions are fundamentally necessary for the functioning of bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies
