column5: but near impossible to calculate the original input given the output. Hence
column6: cryptographic one-way hash functions enable bitcoin‚Äôs proof of work system
column7: as it ensures that it is nigh-impossible for someone to just see the output required to unlock new bitcoins
column8: and calculate in reverse the input that created that output.

column1: Instead
column2: one must essentially brute-force the solution
column3: by trying every single possible input in order to find one that creates an output that satisfies the specified requirements.

column1: Bitcoin is further ingeniously devised to guarantee that on average
column2: new bitcoins are only found every 10 minutes or so. It guarantees this by ensuring that the code that dictates the new creation of bitcoin automatically increases the difficulty of the proof-of-work system in proportion to the number of computers trying to solve the problem at hand.

column6: 000 values

column9: 000 values.

column5: 000 random tries of hashing values to find one that would fulfill the requirements of the specified output required to unlock the next block of bitcoins.

column1: Sure

column3: has only ~5 cents worth of actual paper value behind it

column1: It turns out these gaps in value between the worth of the ‚Äòtangible‚Äô thing itself and the actual value of the currency as it stands on the market today is just as much conjured up out of thin air as a mere concept as bitcoin‚Äôs perceived value is.
This ‚Äòintangible‚Äô worth that we ascribe to currency
column2: which accounts for the vast majority of the value of all currencies
column3: not just bitcoin
column4: is ultimately what makes money work. Yuval Noah Harari captures this fact very well in Sapiens
column5: where he lays out the case that the value of a given form of money is essentially an indication of trust in that form of money. It is our shared collective trust and belief in a currency that gives it value
column6: not its intrinsic tangible utility or anything else.

column1: Gold holds its value well because we trust that we will all collectively continue to trust it as a store of value forever
column2: predominantly due to its scarcity and lack of centralized control. Fiat currencies hold their value well when they do because people trust that everyone else trusts the currency as well
column3: and that it is deserving of trust. The moment that collective trust collapses
column4: so too does the currency
column5: no matter what its intrinsic ‚Äòtangible‚Äô value.

column1: This is why no fiat currency has ever stood the test of time over a long enough timescale
column2: whereas gold has to date always stood the test of time and retained its value well. Collective trust for gold has never collapsed because of its inherent scarcity and immunity to the vicissitudes fiat currencies must endure at the hands of capricious centralized governing powers
column3: whereas collective trust in every historical fiat currency has inevitably failed to date
column4: and collective trust in many present-day fiat currencies continues to fail as we speak.

column1: With this in mind

column6: as well as to introduce for the first time a number of characteristics that make it even better than all previously extant currencies.

column1: Expected value is a useful concept frequently employed in poker that also serves to provide utility here. In short
column2: expected value is a way to decide when an outcome is not certain
column3: but a set of outcomes are probabilistically determinable
column4: if a given action is going to be net positive or net negative
column5: and to what degree.

column1: The simplest example is flipping a coin. This will yield heads 50% of the time
column2: and tails 50% of the time. Expected value of betting on the coin yielding heads
column3: hence
column4: is 0. This is because in any one given flip
column5: the coin has exactly a 50% chance of coming up heads. Hence
column6: if you bet $100 on the coin coming up heads an infinite number of times
column7: your expected gain
column8: or value
column9: from such an action
column10: is to be $0.

column1: Conversely
column2: if you bet at even odds that a six sided dice roll would come up 3 or higher
column3: your expected value would be positive
column4: as you would be correct 2/3 times. Hence
column5: if you repeated this bet an infinite number of times
column6: you would be guaranteed to be earning more money than you lost.

column1: Similarly
column2: if you were able to bet at 1:2 odds (meaning if you bet $100 and win
column3: you get $200) that a coin would yield heads
column4: this would also be very +EV (positive expected value). The coin would still yield heads half the time
column5: but that half of the time
column6: you would earn $200
column7: and the other half of the time
column8: you would only lose $100. Hence
column9: repeating this bet an infinite number of times would allow you to dramatically earn more money than you lost yet again.

column1: There are far too many variables and unknowns to take into consideration with most speculative bets
column2: and cryptocurrency in particular
column3: to be able to hope for anything so nice and clean as an exact mathematical probability of how + or -EV a given bet on a given cryptocurrency might turn out
column4: just as there are far too many unknowns to calculate the precise fundamental present and future potential value of a cryptocurrency for the purpose of value investing analysis
column5: but regardless
column6: holding both principles at large as a general guiding strategy in determining one‚Äôs actions here and elsewhere is a good bet.

column1: Here is a simple checklist you can follow to see if your content is optimized.

‚òê Your keyword is in the first <h1> tag (and your page has an <h1> tag)

column3: etc) your keyword or synonyms are in most of them

column1: ‚òê Any images on the page have an <alt> tag that contain your chosen keyword
‚òê Your keyword is in the meta description (and there is a meta description)
‚òê There is at least 300 words of text on the page
‚òê Your keyword appears in the URL (if not the homepage)
‚òê Your keyword appears in the first paragraph of the copy
‚òê Your keyword (or synonyms ‚Äî Google recognizes them now) is used other times throughout the page
‚òê Your keyword density is between .5% and 2.5%
‚òê The page contains dofollow links to other pages (this just means you‚Äôre not using nofollow links to every other page)
‚òê The page is original content not taken from another page and dissimilar from other pages on your site

If you have all of that in place you should be pretty well set from an on-page perspective. You‚Äôll likely be the best-optimized page for your chosen keyword unless you‚Äôre in a very competitive space.

column1: Robots.txt

column2: the Issue Tracker (internally called Buganizer System) is a tool used in-house at Google to track bugs and feature requests during product development. Nir Eyal|439|5|https://medium.com/pminsider/abolish-the-reference-check-de55451c84d0?source=tag_archive---------0---------------------|Abolish the reference check ‚Äì Product Management Insider ‚Äì Medium|It‚Äôs time to abolish the reference check. The unpleasant process of calling up a job applicant‚Äôs former boss to gab about the candidate‚Äôs pluses and ‚Äúdeltas‚Äù is just silly. Maybe if we all just agree to stop doing it
column2: the practice will go away
column3: like pay phones and fanny packs. Instead
column4: I‚Äôve learned a better way to hire that leverages a universal human attribute ‚Äî namely
column5: the fact that we‚Äôre all lazy.

column1: What‚Äôs my beef with reference checks? They don‚Äôt accomplish the job we intend them to do. In a startup
column2: you can‚Äôt afford to hire B-players. But reference checks
column3: which are intended to do the screening
column4: fail to eliminate these candidates who are just so-so. This happens because the person giving the reference has no incentive to say anything but good things about the candidate. Telling the whole truth
column5: warts and all
column6: could expose the former boss to a defamation lawsuit. But legal action aside
column7: no one likes to speak poorly about an ex-colleague. It‚Äôs bad karma and just feels icky.

column1: Instead of asking a reference to call you and spend an awkward half-hour chitchatting about pretty much nothing
column2: try a technique I‚Äôve come to call it the ‚Äúaverage-need-not-apply‚Äù method. Though I‚Äôm not sure who invented it
column3: the approach was taught to me by Irv Grousbeck at Stanford.

column1: First
column2: send the email below to people who have worked with the candidate. This can include the references he or she provided
column3: but it‚Äôs a good idea to find other people who‚Äôve worked with the candidate as well. I‚Äôd recommend letting the candidate know you may reach out to people they‚Äôve worked with who are not on their list of references and confirm that‚Äôs ok with them. LinkedIn makes finding former co-workers a snap
column4: and the more people you send it to
column5: the better it will work.

column1: After you send this email
column2: one of the following three things will happen:

column1: Scenario A: It‚Äôs most likely that you will hear nothing back from the reference.
Congratulations! You saved yourself from hiring a B-player
column2: or worse. You also saved yourself and the reference from having to conduct an uncomfortable
column3: time-wasting phone call.

column1: Scenario B: You receive an email back from the reference informing you that the candidate was in fact exceptional and they‚Äôd be happy to tell you more.
Congratulations! Looks like you found a star
column2: now it‚Äôs time to have a chat to confirm the candidate is as great as you think they are and learn more about your soon-to-be employee.

column1: Scenario C: You receive a call within 5 minutes of sending your email asking if the candidate is on the market for a new job
column2: and if so
column3: can you have the candidate call the reference back ASAP.

column1: Congratulations! You‚Äôve definitely found a winner. Don‚Äôt let the candidate return the call and make an offer immediately before someone else does. This scenario has actually happened to me a few times. It‚Äôs the best predictor of the quality of candidate I‚Äôve ever seen. We immediately made offers to those candidates and without fail they turned out to be our best hires.

So why does this method work? It leverages the power of choosing a default option. Research by Eric Johnson and Daniel Goldstein demonstrated how opt-in versus opt-out decisions dramatically affect participation in organ donation programs; using a default option in the reference check allows you to affect results in a similar way.
Unlike the traditional reference check method
column2: which elicits an overly positive response in order to preserve social harmony
column3: the ‚Äúaverage-need-not-apply‚Äù method uses the opposite bias. By giving the reference an easy default ‚Äî in this case doing nothing ‚Äî this technique gauges just how great the reference thinks the candidate is.

column1: Those who have a strong positive opinion of a candidate take the time to write back. By using this method
column2: an employer can collect more data points on the potential hire with just a few emails instead of scheduling phone calls. In my experience
column3: the results are binary. Most of the emails yield glowing replies or radio silence; both speak volumes.

column1: By utilizing a bit of behavioral engineering instead of performing the reference check
column2: employers can make better hiring decisions and make the hiring process better for everyone involved ‚Äî except maybe the B-players.

column1: Scrutinize any joint project carefully and qualify the person you‚Äôre collaborating with (even if they are your friend and have higher social media stats than you). Get everything in writing before you embark on the project

column4: and the number you would like to make. Set the first financial deadline early so that you both have the freedom to walk away if the project isn‚Äôt going to be profitable. Have a transition strategy in mind so in case that happens and one of you wants to continue on with the project

Once you have figured out your marketing personality

column1: I love connecting personally with my clients. In this area of business

column3: I:

column2: forget everything you know about the ‚Äúright way‚Äù to run a business and run it like a neighborhood lemonade stand. Do not price your offerings around your personal ability to pay for it ‚Äî you are not your ideal customer. Work out perplexing issues in your business
column3: and it will resolve problems in other areas of your life. Connect with other entrepreneurs and set up a Skype brainstorming session (with wine). Take a walk around the block every day at lunch. And lastly

column1: Product Management is the by-product of two exponential forces being exerted on a company.
Speed is an exponential force because with every period of time
column2: more change is occurring than in the last. Similarly with scale; every extra feature
column3: employee
column4: or user is adding more complexity to the system than the last.

column1: The reason product management as a career has been popularized in predominantly software companies
column2: is because software is inherently fast and scalable.

column1: The internet changed how software products were delivered to the market. Long gone are the days of annual releases and cardboard boxes on shelves. For the last two decades
column2: teams have been writing code
column3: deploying it
column4: and giving updates to all their customers instantaneously.

column1: Software development itself has a lowered bar of entry. Approachability of high level programming languages
column2: and the prevalence of open source libraries has super charged developers with unprecedented productivity. At the same time
column3: the infrastructure costs of building a functional product and deploying it has dropped to basically zero.

column1: In this way
column2: speed has two meanings: both how quickly you can get something to market with software development
column3: and (critically) how competition forces companies to go faster to survive.

column1: The reason why sub 50-person startups rarely have product managers is that the complexity is still manageable. The CEO and co-founders are still able to coordinate the company towards a focused problem and unleash the power of a scrappy startup upon it.
But as the company grows
column2: complexity emerges as more features are added
column3: customers become more diverse
column4: and the team grows. And that complexity grows exponentially.

column1: For example
column2: how many meetings do you think a 20-person startup can have?

column1: The answer shows why we suck at conceptualizing the exponential.
The problem the company solves grows in complexity as well. As teams solve high level problems
column2: they spawn hundreds of derivative problems
column3: all begging to be solved. The catch is the company can‚Äôt solve them all. Faced with hundreds of problems to solve
column4: choosing where to focus quickly becomes the most important decision a company makes.

column1: When you consider the simultaneous impacts of speed and scale on a company
column2: it‚Äôs easy to conceptualize how things will eventually derail without someone thinking holistically about the company. Ultimately
column3: that role is for the CEO
column4: but when they‚Äôve reached their multi-tasking limits
column5: who else can fill the void?

column1: Sure
column2: products need some oversight - got it. Why not just train everyone to be able to manage the product
column3: why hire a specific role?

column1: The short answer is that it‚Äôs harder than you think to manage a product
column2: and it takes years of experience to become capable. Here‚Äôs the long answer:

column1: The core competency of a product manager is truly understanding product development. That is
column2: how to identify which problem to solve and how to work with a team to solve it.

column1: Anyone who‚Äôs been through a few launches knows that despite the textbooks
column2: a linear product development process like the one below is a fairy tale.

column1: Even if you included feedback loops between the steps
column2: the idea of neat and tidy sequential steps
column3: where functional teams work together through a checklist is flawed. It simply does not fit into a world where technology is progressing exponentially.

column1: I view modern product development as a system of interconnected disciplines
column2: working in a network
column3: to deliver on a user‚Äôs desire. Product managers are the API that facilitates communication in this network.

column1: Each node represents a broad bucket of domain expertise
column2: each with enough depth that people dedicate careers to master them. This is an important quality of product development in a company where speed and scale have reached critical mass: there‚Äôs too much to know
column3: so only a team can effectively deliver a product.

column1: The process of product development is how this system moves through time.
Product managers shepherd this system from problem identification through to product launch
column2: ensuring that each node in the network is aware of the progression of the others
column3: and that users increasingly want what is being developed.

column1: Finally
column2: organizational scale brings with it multiple teams. And an effective product development system coordinates and focuses those teams towards the company‚Äôs vision.

column1: As the product development APIs
column2: product managers support company wide efficiency by ensuring no duplication of effort
column3: and sharing infrastructure to enable other teams to go faster.

column1: Product managers spend years to develop the skills required to be responsible for this system. It‚Äôs a multidisciplinary
column2: breadth over depth approach to learning.

column1: In my career
column2: I‚Äôve done all of: programming
column3: UI design
column4: UX research
column5: financial modelling
column6: business development
column7: support
column8: copy-writing
column9: accounting
column10: legal

column12: reporting
column15: FAQs

column1: I‚Äôve been an expert in none
column2: and achieved borderline competence in some. I knew just enough of each to be useful as an API
column3: but never enough to be dangerous (in a good way). That‚Äôs the quintessential quality of a product manager‚Äôs skill set
column4: one that makes it hard for builder types to grok exactly what value they bring.

column1: A product manager‚Äôs multidisciplinary awareness enables them to communicate in whatever language is necessary to effectively deliver information across the team.
They‚Äôre also in the best position to assess the impact of change across the system. A recent conversation I had with Shopify‚Äôs CEO
column2: expressed this pretty succinctly to me.

column1: Exactly right.
In a world where speed is king and the world is changing exponentially
column2: having time to develop consensus before action is often a luxury. Teams need critical decisions made on a daily basis in order to maintain speed
column3: and those decisions have major trade offs and/or conflicting interests among stakeholders.

column1: Driving those decisions is no one else‚Äôs job but the product manager‚Äôs.
Whereas the work of engineers and designers are easier quantified
column2: because it‚Äôs difficult to observe a PMs impact over the short run
column3: the ambiguity around Product Management will remain for some time.

column1: One day

column3: but not today. Until then
column4: companies will continue to scale
column5: the world will continue to get faster

column1: If you‚Äôre a PM

column8: ability
column9: or patience to do it the conventional way. We solve their problem.

column1: Not only do we solve their problem
column2: we do it in way that is easier and cheaper than anything else they can do. Take ghostwriting for example. To hire a ghostwriter
column3: you‚Äôre going to pay at least $40k (and usually much more for a good one). You have no guarantees of quality or process with them
column4: and they don‚Äôt do anything but help you write the book manuscript‚Äîno publishing

column1: But as great as this is
column2: you know what my overwhelming emotion is right now

column1: I feel embarrassed.
I feel embarrassed because people have been asking the question ‚ÄúHow do I get a book‚Äù for almost a decade
column2: and my answer that whole time has been some version of elitist sneering at their lack of work ethic. I wasn‚Äôt thinking like an entrepreneur
column3: I was thinking like the type of person I always claim to hate‚Äîthe one who says the status quo is the only way
column4: that you have to do it ‚Äúthe way it‚Äôs always been done.‚Äù

column1: It‚Äôs really embarrassing
column2: at least to me
column3: that it took me this long to see what has been right in front of my face for years. The technology existed to do this from the first day I was asked that question
column4: almost a decade ago
column5: and I was too arrogant and fixed in my notions of what a ‚Äúwriter‚Äù had to be in order to see it.

column1: SEO is simply not as hard as people pretend like it is; you can get 95% of the effort with 5% of the work

column1: Of all the channels we‚Äôll be discussing
column2: SEO is the one that there is the most misinformation about. Some of it is subtle
column3: but some of it is widely spread and believed by so-called SEO consultants who actually don‚Äôt know what they‚Äôre doing.

column1: SEO is very simple
column2: and unless you‚Äôre a very large company it‚Äôs probably not worth hiring somebody else to do.

column1: In order to understand what we need to do for SEO let‚Äôs look back at how Google started
column2: how it‚Äôs evolving today
column3: and develop a groundwork from which we can understand how to get ranked on Google.

column1: The idea for PageRank ‚Äî Google‚Äôs early ranking algorithm ‚Äî stemmed from Einstein. Larry Page and Sergei Brin were students at Stanford
column2: and they noticed how often scientific studies referred to famous papers
column3: such as the theory of relativity. These references acted almost like a vote ‚Äî the more your work was referenced the more important it must be. If they downloaded every scientific paper and looked at the references
column4: they could theoretically decide which papers were the most important
column5: and rank them.

column1: They realized that because of links
column2: the Internet could be analyzed and ranked in a similar way
column3: except instead of using references they could use links. So they set about attempting to ‚Äúdownload‚Äù (or crawl) the entire Internet
column4: figuring out which sites were linked to the most. The sites with the most links were
column5: theoretically
column6: the best sites. And if you did a search for ‚Äúuniversity
column7: ‚Äù they could look at the pages that talked about ‚Äúuniversity‚Äù and rank them.

column1: Google works largely the same way today
column2: although with much more sophistication and nuance. For example
column3: not all links carry the same weight. A link from an authoritative site (as seen by how many links a site has pointing at it) is much more valuable than a link from a non-authoritative site. A link from the New York Times is probably worth about 10
column4: 000 links from sites that don‚Äôt have much authority.

column1: At the end of the day the purpose of Google is to find the ‚Äúbest‚Äù (or most popular) web page for the words you type into the search bar.
All this means is we need to make it clear to google what our page is about
column2: and then make it clear that we‚Äôre popular. If we do that we win. In order to do that
column3: we‚Äôll follow a very simple process that works every single time with less effort than you probably think is required.

column1: Google is a very smart company. The sophistication of the algorithms they write is incredible; bear in mind that there are currently cars driving themselves around Silicon Valley powered by Google‚Äôs algorithms.
If you get too far into the SEO rabbit hole you‚Äôll start stumbling upon spammy ways to attempt to speed up this process. Automated software like RankerX
column2: GSA SER
column3: and Scrapebox
column4: instructions to create spam or spin content
column5: linkwheels
column6: PBNs
column7: hacking domains
column8: etc.

column1: Some of that stuff works very short term
column2: but Google is smart and it is getting smarter. It gets harder to beat Google every day
column3: and Google gets faster at shutting down spammy sites every day. Most don‚Äôt even last a week before everything you‚Äôve done disappears and your work evaporates. That‚Äôs not the way you should do things.

column1: Instead of Internet-based churn and burn we‚Äôll be focusing on building equity in the Internet. So if you see some highly-paid SEO consultant telling you to use software and spun content to generate links
column2: or when you see some blackhatter beating the system
column3: just know that it‚Äôs not worth it. We‚Äôre going to build authority and get traffic fast
column4: but we‚Äôre going to do it in a way that doesn‚Äôt disappear or cripple your site in the future.

column1: The first step in getting our site ready to rank is making it clear to Google what our site is about.

For now we‚Äôre going to focus our home page (our landing page) on ranking for one keyword that isn‚Äôt our brand or company name. Once we do that and get that ranking we can branch out into other keywords and start to dominate the search landscape
column2: but for now we‚Äôll stay laser focused.

column1: The first thing we need to do is to figure out what that keyword is. Depending on how popular our site is and how long it‚Äôs been around
column2: the level of traffic and difficulty we‚Äôll get from this effort may vary.

column1: There‚Äôs a concept we need to be familiar with known as the ‚Äúlong tail.‚Äù
If we were to graph ‚Äúpopularity‚Äù of most things with ‚Äúpopularity‚Äù being the Y axis and the rank order being the X axis
column2: we‚Äôd get something like a power law graph:

column1: There are some big hits that get the majority of attention
column2: and after a few hits the graph falls sharply. The long-tail theory says that as we become more diverse as a society the yellow end of the above graph will stretch forever and get taller.

column1: Think of Amazon. They probably have a few best-selling products
column2: but the majority of their retail revenue comes from a wide variety of things that aren‚Äôt bought anywhere nearly as often as their best-selling products. Similarly
column3: if we were to rank the popularity of the songs played in the last 10 years
column4: there would be a few hits that would garner the majority of plays
column5: and an enormous number of songs that have only a few plays. Those less popular products and songs are what we call the long tail.

column1: In SEO this matters because
column2: at least in the beginning
column3: we‚Äôre going to go after long tail keywords ‚Äî very exact
column4: intention-driven keywords with lower competition that we know can win
column5: then gradually we‚Äôll work our way to the left.

column1: Our site isn‚Äôt going to outrank ultra-competitive keywords in the beginning
column2: but by being more specific we can start winning very targeted traffic with much less effort.

column2: we need to make sure Google knows what our site is about. This is as simple as making sure the right keywords are in the right places. Most of this has to do with html tags
column3: which make up the structure of a webpage. If you don‚Äôt know html or understand how it works

column1: Here is a simple checklist you can follow to see if your content is optimized.
‚òê Your keyword is in the <title> tag
column2: ideally at the front (or close to the front) of the tag

column1: ‚òê Your keyword is close to the beginning of the <title> tag (ideally the first words)
‚òê The title tag contains less than the viewable limit of 65 characters (optional but recommended)
‚òê Your keyword is in the first <h1> tag (and your page has an <h1> tag)
‚òê If your page contains additional header tags (<h2>
column3: etc) your keyword or synonyms are in most of them

column1: ‚òê Any images on the page have an <alt> tag that contain your chosen keyword
‚òê Your keyword is in the meta description (and there is a meta description)
‚òê There is at least 300 words of text on the page
‚òê Your keyword appears in the URL (if not the homepage)
‚òê Your keyword appears in the first paragraph of the copy
‚òê Your keyword (or synonyms ‚Äî Google recognizes them now) is used other times throughout the page
‚òê Your keyword density is between .5% and 2.5%
‚òê The page contains dofollow links to other pages (this just means you‚Äôre not using nofollow links to every other page)
‚òê The page is original content not taken from another page and dissimilar from other pages on your site

If you have all of that in place you should be pretty well set from an on-page perspective. You‚Äôll likely be the best-optimized page for your chosen keyword unless you‚Äôre in a very competitive space.
All we have left now is off-page optimization.
Off-Page SEO is just a fancy way to say links. (Sometimes we call them backlinks
column2: but it‚Äôs really the same thing.)

column1: Google looks at each link on the web as a weighted vote. If you link to something
column2: in Google‚Äôs eyes you‚Äôre saying
column3: ‚ÄúThis is worth checking out.‚Äù The more legit you are the more weight your vote carries.

column1: SEOs have a weird way to describe this voting process; they call it ‚Äúlink juice.‚Äù If an authoritative site
column2: we‚Äôll say Wikipedia for example
column3: links to you
column4: they‚Äôre passing you ‚Äúlink juice.‚Äù

column1: But link juice doesn‚Äôt only work site to site ‚Äî if your homepage is very authoritative and it links off to other pages on your site
column2: it passes link juice as well. For this reason our link structure becomes very important.

column1: There are a number of tools that let you check how many links are pointing to a site and what the authority of those pages are. Unfortunately none of them are perfect ‚Äî the only way to know what links are pointing to your site is to have crawled those pages.
Google crawls most popular pages several times per day
column2: but they don‚Äôt want you manipulating them
column3: so they update their index pretty slowly.

column1: That said
column2: you can check at least a sample of Google‚Äôs index in the Google Search Console (formerly known as Webmaster Tools). Once you navigate to your site
column3: In the left-hand side select ‚ÄúSearch Traffic‚Äù then ‚ÄúLinks to your site.‚Äù There‚Äôs a debate raging over whether or not this actually shows you all of the links Google knows about (I‚Äôm 99% convinced it‚Äôs only a sample)
column4: but it‚Äôs at least a representative sample.

column1: To see all of your links
column2: click on ‚ÄúMore‚Äù under ‚ÄúWho links to you the most‚Äù then ‚ÄúDownload this table.‚Äù This
column3: again
column4: seems to only download a sample of what Google knows about. You can also select ‚ÄúDownload latest links‚Äù which provides more recent links than the other option.

column1: Unfortunately this doesn‚Äôt let us see much a to the value of the links
column2: nor does it show us links that have dropped or where those links are from.

column1: To use those there are a wide variety of tools: If you have a budget I‚Äôd go with ahrefs.com as they have the biggest index
column2: followed by Moz‚Äôs Open Site Explorer (most of the data you can get with a free account
column3: if not then it‚Äôs slightly cheaper than ahrefs)
column4: and finally SEMrush
column5: which is free for most purposes we need. MajesticSEO uses a combination of ‚Äútrust flow‚Äù and ‚Äúcitation flow‚Äù which also works fairly well to give you an idea as to the overall health and number of links pointing to your site.

column1: All of these use different internal metrics to determine the ‚Äúauthority‚Äù of a link
column2: but using them to compare apples to apples can be beneficial.

column1: HTML links look something like this:
Anchor text
Where http://www.somesite.com is the place the link directs you to
column2: the title is largely a remnant of time gone by
column3: and the linked text ‚Äî think the words that are blue and you click on ‚Äî is called the ‚Äúanchor text.‚Äù

column1: In addition to the amount of link juice a page has
column2: the relevance of the anchor text matters.

column1: Generally speaking you want to use your keyword as the anchor text for your internal linking whenever possible. External linking (from other sites) shouldn‚Äôt be very heavily optimized for anchor text. If 90% of your links all have the same anchor text Google can throw a red flag
column2: assuming that you‚Äôre doing something fishy.

column1: If you‚Äôre ever creating links (like we‚Äôll show you in the future) I only ever use something generic like the site name
column2: ‚Äúhere‚Äù or the full URL.

column1: Generally speaking you don‚Äôt want orphan pages (those that aren‚Äôt linked to by other pages)
column2: nor do you want an overly-messy link structure.

column1: Some say the ideal link structure for a site is something like this:
That‚Äôs close
column2: but it gets a couple things wrong. First
column3: you‚Äôll never have a structure that organized
column4: and second
column5: in an ideal world every page would link to every other page on its same level. This can easily be done with a footer that feels like a sitemap or ‚Äúrecommended‚Äù pages. That allows you to specify anchor text
column6: and pass link juice freely from page to page.

column1: Unfortunately it‚Äôs impossible to draw such a web without it becoming a mess
column2: so you‚Äôll just have to imagine what that actually looks like.

column1: We have just one more thing to go over before we start getting those first links pointing to our site.
Most of SEO is managing stuff that can go wrong. There is a lot of that
column2: but we‚Äôll go over what will cover 99% of needs
column3: and you can Google if there‚Äôs something really crazy.

column1: Robots.txt
Almost every site has a page at url.com/robots.txt ‚Äî even google has one.
This is just a plain text file that lets you tell search engine crawlers what to crawl and not to crawl. Most are pretty good about listening
column2: except the Bingbot
column3: which pretty much does whatever it wants no matter what you tell it. (I‚Äôm mostly kidding.)

column1: If you don‚Äôt want Google to crawl a page (maybe it‚Äôs a login page you don‚Äôt want indexed
column2: a landing page
column3: etc.) you can just ‚Äúdisallow‚Äù it in your robots.txt by saying disallow: /somepage.

column1: If you add a trailing / to it (e.g. disallow: /somepage/) it will also disallow all child pages.
Technically you can specify different rules for different bots (or user agents)
column2: but it‚Äôs easiest to start your file with ‚ÄúUser-agent: *‚Äù if you don‚Äôt have a need for separate crawling rules.

column1: Disavow
Google will penalize spammy sites
column2: and unfortunately this causes some bad behavior from bad actors. Say
column3: for example
column4: you wanted to take out a competitor. You could send a bunch of obviously spammy links to their site and get them penalized. This is called ‚Äúnegative SEO
column5: ‚Äù and is something that happens often in highly contested keywords. Google generally tries to pretend like it doesn‚Äôt happen.

column1: In the case that this does happen
column2: however
column3: you can ‚ÄúDisavow‚Äù links in the Search Console
column4: which is pretty much saying
column5: ‚ÄúHey Google
column6: don‚Äôt count this one.‚Äù I hope you‚Äôll never have to use it
column7: but if you hire (or have hired) a bad SEO or are being attacked by a competitor
column8: that is how you combat it.

column1: Nofollow
A link can have a property called ‚Äúnofollow‚Äù such as this:
Anchor text.
If you want to link to somebody but you don‚Äôt want it to count as a vote (you don‚Äôt want to pass link-juice)
column2: or you support user-generated content and want to deter spammers
column3: you can use a nofollow link. Google says it discounts the value of those links. I‚Äôm not convinced they discount them heavily
column4: but other SEOs are so they seem to deter spammers if nothing else.

column1: Redirects
If you‚Äôre going to change a URL
column2: but you don‚Äôt want its link juice to disappear
column3: you can use a 301 redirect. A 301 will pass a majority of the link juice.

column1: Canonical URLs
If you have two pages that are virtually the same
column2: you can add something like <link rel=‚Äùcanonical href=‚Äùhttps://www.someurl.com/somepage‚Äù> to say ‚Äúhey
column3: treat this page as if it were that page instead
column4: but I don‚Äôt want to 301 it.‚Äù

column1: And with that
column2: we‚Äôre ready to build our first links.

column1: Link building is where SEO really starts to matter
column2: and where a lot of people end up in a world of hurt.

column1: The best way to build links is to not build links. I‚Äôve worked for companies in the past that don‚Äôt have to ask for them

column3: customer blogs

column2: and I can‚Äôt even count the number of times I‚Äôve seen that take down a site.

column1: The easiest way to build high quality links are what SEOs call ‚Äúweb 2.0s.‚Äù That‚Äôs just a way to say ‚Äúsocial sites‚Äù or sites that let you post stuff. Now tweeting a link into the abyss won‚Äôt do you anything

Wordpress (yes

Tumblr

column1: Another way to get link juice is by purchasing an expired domain. This is more difficult to do
column2: but there are a lot of options such as expireddomains.net. (Google ‚Äúexpired domains‚Äù and you‚Äôll find dozens of sites monitoring them.)

column1: You‚Äôll want to purchase a domain that has expired and restore it as closely as you can to its original form using an archive. These sites likely have some link juice to pass on and you can pass it to yourself.
Another way to find places you can build links is by using a link intersection tool. These find sites that link to ‚Äúcompetitor a‚Äù and ‚Äúcompetitor b‚Äù but not to you. Theoretically
column2: if they link to both of your competitors
column3: they should be willing to link to you. Moz
column4: Ahrefs
column5: LunaMetrics and others have link intersection tools that work quite well.

column1: Now that we have a few basic links flowing
column2: we‚Äôre going to work on some strategies that will send continual links and press
column3: eventually getting to a point where we don‚Äôt have to build any more links.

column1: Awesome ‚Äî you have a site that converts well

This section takes a lot of time and effort
column2: and in the beginning you‚Äôll likely wonder if you‚Äôre doing anything at all. Remember that class in college that is so difficult it‚Äôs the point where most people give up

It‚Äôs the trademarked slogan that defined the mobile world since 2008. Surely
column2: apps seemed to be the way to go. Coding bootcamps that claimed to teach you app development chops within weeks popped up everywhere; products used commercials to go out of their way and show off their new apps; heck
column3: even that family restaurant around the block got its own menu app built.

column1: With the release of the App store in 2008
column2: Apple was the first to popularize the idea of nicely packaged
column3: downloadable applications on your phone. However
column4: this concept of centralized software distribution isn‚Äôt actually new. Many handheld and desktop devices already had some form of application store built in years before Apple‚Äôs App Store debut. The reason why Apple succeeded
column5: in retrospect
column6: is a combination of timing and technology. By 2008
column7: the iOS (then ‚ÄúiPhone OS‚Äù) platform was able to offer access to a maturing 3G network
column8: a well-documented development environment
column9: great handheld graphics
column10: and most importantly
column11: the backing of a technology giant. Mobile apps made sense. They were the most efficient way to deliver the newest content and services with native experience and performance.

column1: People don‚Äôt care how it all works
column2: they just want to throw birds at pigs and show off their #nofilter selfies. The ability to download and run cool apps was the iPhone‚Äôs winning feature for a short while. Android soon followed suit. Smartphones became cheaper; networks became faster; handheld processing power quadrupled; apps prevailed.

column1: Nothing. But we can do better now. ‚ÄúBetter than this app that lets me feed and play with cute cats?‚Äù Yep.
You see
column2: mobile apps succeeded because of the right combination of fast network and capable handheld processors. Technologies have progressed much further than that in the meantime
column3: and the world of apps has grown beyond a healthy size. Among all of the headaches that follow the impenetrable mobile market today
column4: the two most urgent would be the delivery and discoverability of content.

column1: Everyone with a smartphone has experienced this at some point: ‚ÄúWow
column2: this restaurant/shop is offering 20% off the special entree...oh
column3: but only if you have this app
column4: ‚Äù or ‚ÄúWait
column5: I have to download an app for this? I just to want to see what my friend posted.‚Äù You probably heard from a friend or saw in a billboard about this really cool app that‚Äôll transform your life
column6: but hesitated to install it
column7: or worse
column8: pay for it.

column1: The problem is twofold. Let‚Äôs start with the first: delivery. Your average digital couch potato now has a shorter attention span and less patience. Paying for and installing an app
column2: what was once a magical
column3: fast
column4: and smooth experience
column5: is an act of commitment for many nowadays. You won‚Äôt believe how many people demand a convincing reason
column6: your heartfelt speech
column7: and your first-born child just to get them to try out a new app. Just think about that one friend who still refuses to download the Messenger app (seriously just get it already). Companies want to deliver content and services to customers as fast and easily as possible
column8: but the increasing reluctance for the perceived installation-barrier is putting up a delivery obstacle. Our home screens are the new San Francisco ‚Äî space is at a premium.

column1: The second problem
column2: discoverability
column3: is a little bit more subtle
column4: but was well articulated by a few tech journalists in the past. Many popular apps
column5: such as Instagram and The Daily
column6: began as mobile-only apps that surfaced great content only within a closed platform. You had to download and register for Instagram in order to see your friends‚Äô Instagram photos. I‚Äôm sure that there are many more apps out there today that I‚Äôm not aware of with useful content that are not searchable or viewable on your browser. A fragmented Internet where creative and original content are locked up in proprietary platforms is not the Internet we know and love.

column1: Now that we understand the problems
column2: let‚Äôs take a look at the current solutions. The word ‚Äúapp linking‚Äù may not sound familiar to you
column3: but every time you tap on a YouTube link in another app and the YouTube app opens up to play the video
column4: you‚Äôre experiencing it. Google
column5: Apple
column6: and Facebook have all implemented variations of this technology. App linking brings you to the app that best presents the content you want. Great.

column1: The other half of our existing solution to compliment app linking is app indexing. Google and Apple have provided ways for third-party content providers to show their own in-app content in a search query
column2: allowing previously locked away content to surface on Google and iOS Spotlight.

column1: Perfect. That seems to have solved our delivery and discoverability problems. User searches for something
column2: in-app content shows up in the results
column3: user clicks the link and gets brought into the app.

column1: You might have already noticed the problems here. What if the app doesn‚Äôt support app linking and indexing? App indexing requires the content provider to actively put effort into implementing it
column2: so by default
column3: your content is not visible to the world wide web
column4: exactly opposite of how most web-based content work. And only until recently
column5: in order for your app to be indexed by Google
column6: developers had to build mirroring web versions. Just imagine the troubles. On the consumer side
column7: what if I don‚Äôt have that app to begin with? What if I don‚Äôt want to install that app just to read an article? The list goes on.

column1: Think about that one time when you tried to check out something and it redirected you into App Store instead. Very annoying. And no
column2: no one wants to install your app.

column1: I don‚Äôt want to maintain a walled garden of apps. I want to consume and create content.
‚ÄúSo then
column2: what is the solution?‚Äù

column1: Just get rid of ‚Äúapps.‚Äù Let‚Äôs see how we might be able to do this.
Google‚Äôs approach to the delivery and discoverability problem has relied on app indexing and linking. If the developer puts in the effort
column2: users can see previously mobile-only content surfacing on Google search results. This is great for Google to stay relevant in a mobile market that is increasingly reliant on native app content instead of web search. But in countries like China and India
column3: where mobile phones are the first computers for millions of people and mobile-only content is king
column4: where does a search engine provide their links to begin with? Suddenly
column5: ‚Äúeverything is just a Google search away‚Äù loses its magic.

column1: Roughly four months ago
column2: Google rolled out an impressive technology that almost no one remembers ‚Äî App Streaming. It does exactly what it sounds like; instead of installing applications like we‚Äôre used to
column3: you tap a link to the content and Google will stream the right parts of the app to you on-demand. No need to install it
column4: ‚Äôcause you‚Äôre already running it. It might be Google‚Äôs first pilot experiment of their cloud platform
column5: but the idea of streaming applications onto your phone is not new. In fact
column6: the very technology itself was bought by Google from Agawi a few years back.

column1: Combine App Streaming and App Indexing
column2: suddenly you remove the two barriers to all information previously locked away in mobile apps.

column1: While Google‚Äôs fantastic solution is still in an experimental stage
column2: Apple is nudging its developers in more or less the same direction
column3: albeit characteristic of Apple
column4: in a less obvious or more incremental way.

column1: On-Demand Resources (ODR) is a technology released with iOS 9 that downloads a small core application only on installation
column2: and then downloads extra parts and content as needed. ODR currently is being used mostly in games
column3: where a user only downloads the assets (graphics
column4: videos
column5: etc.) for a few beginning levels. iOS will then download more levels as the user progresses
column6: and delete assets for completed levels to make space.

column1: How does this mirror Google‚Äôs approach? It doesn‚Äôt. However
column2: if ODR becomes commonplace and the supporting infrastructure is flexible enough
column3: you can reasonably imagine Apple extending the framework to a more general use case. In any case
column4: they got this wonderful tool under the belt that will potentially blossom into a form of install-free applications.

column1: While we‚Äôre on Apple
column2: I want to bring up Steve Jobs‚Äôs vision of the first iPhone. You might still remember fondly that the first iPhone was a closed platform with no developer environment or third-party apps. His solution? Web apps.

column1: Web apps don‚Äôt need to be installed. They run (relatively) securely in closed browser environment. They are web friendly
column2: meaning they can be indexed and surfaced by search engines. Oh wait
column3: isn‚Äôt that exactly what we want today? Probably.

column1: I‚Äôm still leaning on the belief that web apps were simply Steve Jobs‚Äôs transitional plan to native apps
column2: but even so
column3: I think he was (at least accidentally) onto something. If we had in 2008 the powerful Javascript frameworks we have today
column4: perhaps web apps would have taken off. Feel free to paint the story into one where Jobs the Visionary foresaw the discoverability and delivery problem
column5: because perhaps he did predict this.

column1: A lot of what app streaming offers competes with other sophisticated web app technologies (React Native
column2: etc.) that are quickly closing the gap between native and web. However
column3: one decisive differentiating factor would still be the native look and feel or possibly performance that web apps sorely lack. There is just no perfect solution yet.

column1: On top of it all
column2: what we really need is a platform-agnostic solution to app streaming that truly overcomes content delivery and discoverability problems. We want something akin to Java applets on browsers (yikes) on mobile. Imagine the possibilities: regardless of the OS or the brand of supercomputer you have in your pocket
column3: you will be able to run an app and view its content with zero friction and with native feel and performance. As for developers
column4: you can write an app once and stream it to all devices and browsers.

column1: With Google streaming apps to your phone and Apple nudging developers to store parts of their apps in the cloud
column2: we may have just entered the beginning of a future where installation becomes obsolete and the border between ‚Äúwebsite‚Äù and ‚Äúnative app‚Äù is blurred. This is a future without apps. And it‚Äôs wonderful.

column1: The user forefront of all these insanely complex
column2: powerful
column3: and cool technologies is one of ultimate simplicity and elegance.

column1: Welcome to a future without apps.

column1: Now back to our regularly scheduled programming:
If You Love Writing Code
column2: You‚Äôre Going to Hate Running a SaaS Business

column1: Since most people wanting to start a SaaS business are developers
column2: we need to get this out of the way ‚Äî and fast.

column1: Building and running a SaaS business has nothing to do with your ability to write code.
Too many developers have the following thought process:
Yeah
column2: that would be great. Except it doesn‚Äôt work that way. Unless you relish doing failed startup postmortems.

column1: This might be going a little too far
column2: but at the same time it‚Äôs probably not going far enough: Code is the least important thing about a SaaS business.

column1: In fact
column2: most startup codebases are dismal abysses of darkness
column3: pain
column4: and the cause for much wailing and gnashing of teeth. They are the furthest thing from the pristine green fields you imagine them to be.

column1: The reason for this is simple: A business‚Äôs software serves one purpose and one purpose only: To make the business money.
You want comprehensive unit tests for your entire codebase? How does that make the business money?
You want to use DI and IoC? How does that make the business money?
You want to use that shiny new framework? How does that make the business money?
Contrast that with the following:
This customer is requesting this feature. How fast can we build that so we can get them to buy?
We think making this change will get more signups. How fast can we make that happen?
This thing is completely broken right now and we have customers cancelling! How fast can we get a fix in?
If you try to build your SaaS app like you build enterprise software
column2: you will most likely fail. Not because your software isn‚Äôt good enough (in fact
column3: I‚Äôll bet you it would be downright awesome). But because you took too long working on things that don‚Äôt contribute to the business making money. And so you just simply run out of time and/or money. Game over.

column1: Now don‚Äôt misread me here. We‚Äôre talking about code
column2: not your product. Your product still has to be good. It still needs to be solid. It still needs to do what your customers expect it to do. Customers care about your product. You‚Äôre the only one who cares about your code.

column1: The other thing you need to be aware of is that you‚Äôre going to spend very little time actually writing code running a SaaS business.
How little?
There‚Äôs times that I don‚Äôt write a line of code for months on end.
Instead of coding
column2: the vast majority of your time is going to be spent marketing
column3: selling
column4: optimizing funnels
column5: and providing support. Those are the things that get (and keep) customers. Those are the things that you do when you run a business. Not writing code.

column1: Getting Your Idea Off The Ground
Now that we‚Äôve gotten all of that out of the way
column2: let‚Äôs get to the good stuff: How to actually build a SaaS business from nothing.

column1: First off
column2: you should know that your idea probably sucks.

column1: Dude
column2: what‚Äôs with all of this negativity? Oh yeah
column3: I forgot to tell you that I don‚Äôt kid glove when it comes to this stuff. If you want to feel good about yourself
column4: go listen to one of the startup gurus out there that will be more than happy to spoon feed you some entreporn. We‚Äôre busy building a business here.

column1: Now
column2: back to your idea.

column1: The reason your idea probably sucks is because it‚Äôs your idea.
Meaning: Your idea is only worth something if other people care about it. It doesn‚Äôt matter what you think. Chances are you‚Äôre not Elon Musk (hello if you are!). We‚Äôre building a business
column2: not our ego.

column1: So really
column2: your SaaS business idea is just a guess.

column1: You‚Äôre guessing that this is something that people are interested in. You‚Äôre guessing that this is something people would want to use. You‚Äôre guessing that this is something that people will give you money for. You‚Äôre guessing that this is something that can scale into an actual business that can replace your income.
So Elon ‚Äî going forward
column2: we‚Äôre not going to refer to your precious game-changing idea as ‚Äúyour idea‚Äù anymore. We‚Äôre going to refer to it as ‚Äúyour guess‚Äù.

column1: This will help you disassociate your emotions from the process. And believe me
column2: you‚Äôre going to need to do just that.

column1: Finding the Right Words
If you‚Äôve heard about value propositions
column2: USPs
column3: elevator pitches
column4: etc. and think you can just skip this section ‚Äî you‚Äôre doing so at your own peril. Getting your messaging right is perhaps one of the most important things you need to nail. Pretty much everything down stream depends on this. And don‚Äôt think you‚Äôll just do this once and be done. You‚Äôll probably get it wrong the first few times. Plus you‚Äôll need to continually come back to this as you try to grow your market.

column1: Now that we have our hunch or guess (not idea!)
column2: we need to answer three important questions:

column1: We need to do this for two reasons.
First
column2: we need to sanity check our guess to make sure that it‚Äôs actually valuable to people and that we‚Äôre thinking in terms of what it enables people to do. Your guess shouldn‚Äôt be about software. Your guess should be about the types of superpowers or beneficial outcomes people will get as a result of using your service.

column1: Second
column2: we need a way to quickly explain our guess to people to see how they react to it.

column1: It‚Äôs simple (but infuriatingly difficult).
Let‚Äôs play fill in the blank:
For example:
I believe that people want to send automated drip email campaigns to their email list signups so that they can automatically nurture leads and convert them into paying customers
column2: and they would pay good money for that because trying to convert leads by manually sending emails or by using something like MailChimp is hard and takes forever.

column1: Perfect. This becomes our business hypothesis.
Now we need to rearrange the jigsaw pieces a little bit for when we put the message in front of people. One more time:
If you have been trying to convert leads by manually sending emails or by using something like MailChimp and think it‚Äôs hard and takes forever
column2: you can send automated drip email campaigns to your email list signups with MailZoo so that you can automatically nurture leads and convert them into paying customers.

column1: Awesome.
Now ‚Äî are your messages compelling?
You did do this
column2: right?

column1: Need more prodding? When I first started out building online businesses
column2: I didn‚Äôt do this exercise and would just jump in and start coding. Most of those projects would wind up failing miserably. When I started doing this exercise (and got it right)
column3: my projects stopped failing.

column1: Now. Are your business hypothesis and customer-facing message believable? Do you really think people would give you good money for the ability you‚Äôre giving them? Is the outcome you came up with plausible and something that people actually want to achieve? If not
column2: go back to the drawing board until it sings. This can take minutes
column3: hours
column4: days
column5: weeks
column6: or even months to get right. And if you can never get it right
column7: chances are your guess was wrong and you‚Äôll need to come up with a new one.

column1: There are no sacred cows when it comes to building a business. I don‚Äôt care how much you love your ‚Äúidea‚Äù. If it doesn‚Äôt scream ‚Äúbuy me!‚Äù when you put it into this format
column2: slaughter it and start over with something new.

column1: Let‚Äôs Make Some Friends
Now
column2: let‚Äôs take the underlying reason that people would pay money for our service from the exercise above. Just for reference
column3: our example is that people would be willing to pay good money for our solution because converting leads by manually sending emails or by using something like MailChimp is hard and takes forever.

column1: Our job now is to find people that meet this criteria. In our example
column2: we‚Äôre looking for people that have been trying to convert leads by manually sending emails or by using something like MailChimp and think it‚Äôs hard and takes forever. (See why I told you that was important?)

column1: We need to test some very important things here that will make or break our business:
So now it‚Äôs time to hurt our heads a little bit.

Go and brainstorm 20 different and specific places you can find the kinds of people that would want to give you money for the value statement you‚Äôre offering. These need to be super specific. You can‚Äôt say something like ‚Äúpeople who participate in online forums where they talk about email marketing‚Äù. No. You need to name those forums. And they can only count as one way out of the 20 we‚Äôre talking about here.
You‚Äôll ultimately need to figure this out for yourself
column2: but here‚Äôs some ideas based on our ongoing example: People following MailChimp on Twitter
column3: people who hang out on inbound.org
column4: people that have blogs with a newsletter signup box
column5: people listening to the Smart Passive Income podcast
column6: people who have retweeted any of Ramit Sethi‚Äôs articles
column7: people who like HubSpot on Facebook
column8: etc.

column1: You‚Äôll probably find that this is harder than it seems. That‚Äôs okay. It is.
As a side note: If you can‚Äôt come up with 20 good places
column2: chance are you don‚Äôt know who your customer actually is. Believe me
column3: it‚Äôs better you find this out now rather than after you‚Äôve spent 5‚Äì6 months heads down around the clock coding your app. Either educate yourself or pick a customer you understand better.

column1: Alright
column2: it‚Äôs about time we put ourselves out there. Like I said before
column3: all you have right now is a guess ‚Äî not an idea. You‚Äôre guessing that some solution you‚Äôve concocted in your head is actually going to be useful to people. So we‚Äôre going to find out if people care about what you have to say.

column1: But here‚Äôs the kicker ‚Äî we‚Äôre not going to tell them anything about our solution. Nothing. Nada. Zilch.
Instead
column2: we‚Äôre going to see if they care about the reason we think they‚Äôd want to give us money. You‚Äôll see why in a few.

column1: So now
column2: we‚Äôre going to research 10 individual people from each of the 20 places we identified. Yes. If you‚Äôre good at math
column3: you just realized that we‚Äôre going to be going after 200 people. I kid you not. You‚Äôll also see why in a few.

column1: Let‚Äôs take our running example. Let‚Äôs say we think that people that have blogs with a newsletter signup box would care about what we‚Äôre talking about. Great. Let‚Äôs go find 10 blogs that we think would give us money based on the premise that we identified. Find out how you can get in touch with the person running the blog. Ideally
column2: you want an email address. You can settle for a contact form. But don‚Äôt just leave some comment spam and walk away thinking you did your job.

column1: Now
column2: let‚Äôs send them a personalized message like the following:

column1: The text in bold is just my emphasis to call out where we‚Äôre slipping in the part we think they would care enough about to pay money for ‚Äî don‚Äôt bold your own text like that.
Also: Never say you like something if you don‚Äôt
column2: express interest in something you could care less about
column3: or mislead them in any way. It will come back to bite you. Tenfold.

column1: If you do everything right
column2: you should probably get a handful of responses from the 200 people you sent detailed
column3: thoughtful
column4: well researched messages to. Yep
column5: you read that right. A handful of responses for 200 messages.

column1: If you work in a corporate environment
column2: this will probably mess with you. Think about it. You‚Äôre used responding to emails you receive
column3: and you‚Äôre used to getting responses from people you‚Äôve sent emails to. It‚Äôs common office courtesy. If you don‚Äôt respond to an email
column4: you‚Äôre ostrisized. The internet doesn‚Äôt work that way. Indifference is the rule. We‚Äôll talk more about how to handle rejection later on.

column1: Because of this
column2: you may be tempted to just blast people with a template. Don‚Äôt. People will see right through it. Plus that‚Äôs just spammy and wrong.

column1: Okay
column2: so let‚Äôs say we get some responses. You‚Äôd honestly be surprised by how much information you can get from people when you just ask them about what they‚Äôre doing. Maybe they read like this:

column1: I had a dog and BINGO was his name-o.
If you don‚Äôt get any responses
column2: or if you don‚Äôt get any responses that reinforce your hypothesis
column3: you have a couple of options:

column1: For those of you still playing along at home
column2: we‚Äôre not done ‚Äî nowhere near close. But if you are getting responses like this
column3: you‚Äôve gotten some confirmation that the underlying reason people would give you money does exist. Now it‚Äôs time to find out if they think your solution is worth any salt.

column1: Time To See If Our Solution Sticks
Now it‚Äôs time to see what happens when we actually put our idea out in front of those people who responded in a way that confirms our money-generating hypothesis.
Something as simple as this would suffice (bold is my own ‚Äî don‚Äôt bold your stuff):
You can see that here
column2: we use the ability and outcome from our earlier messaging exercise. (See why I told you to do that?)

column1: Now
column2: one of the following is going to probably happen:

column1: Chances are
column2: you‚Äôre going to get responses #1‚Äì3 far more often than #4.

column1: So what do you do?
If you don‚Äôt get a response
column2: you should follow up until you do or they tell you to bugger off.

column1: If their response is ‚ÄúNo
column2: it‚Äôs not a problem‚Äù
column3: ask them under what circumstances it would become a problem or make sense for them to try what you‚Äôre offering. If you get enough of these types of responses

column1: If their response is ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a bunch of companies already doing that‚Äù
column2: don‚Äôt scrap your idea! Just because someone else is already doing what you thought was a revolutionary concept doesn‚Äôt mean you should give up. In fact

column4: you should ask them what they mean by ‚Äúexpensive‚Äù and what they would like to see in the market as an alternative to the companies they mentioned. See if adjusting your offering in light of these insights will get you to ‚ÄúHeck yes‚Äù.

column1: If they‚Äôve said ‚ÄúHeck yes‚Äù
column2: you‚Äôre nailing it.

column1: After you get those ‚ÄúHeck yeses‚Äù
column2: tell them that you‚Äôre going to look into what you can do for them and ask them if they‚Äôd be interested to look at what you come up with.

column1: The goal here is to get to 20 ‚ÄúHeck yeses‚Äù that are interested in hearing about what you come up with. You‚Äôll need to refine your message
column2: listen to feedback
column3: adjust your message again
column4: try different approaches
column5: different places
column6: different people
column7: etc.

column1: Make no mistake
column2: it‚Äôll most likely suck.

column1: If you can‚Äôt get to 20
column2: you might want to reconsider what you‚Äôre doing.

column1: A startup is like a box. A very special box.
The box has a value. The more things you put in the box
column2: the more its value increases. Add a patent in the box
column3: the value increases. Add a kick-ass management team in the box

column1: But how much should ‚ÄúX‚Äù be?
It depends on the Pre-Money Valuation
column2: e.g. the value of the box at the moment of the investment. But calculating the Pre-Money Valuation is tricky. This article will take you through 9 different valuation methods to better let you understand how to determine Pre-Money Valuation.

column1: The Berkus Method is a simple and convenient rule of thumb to estimate the value of your box. It was designed by Dave Berkus
column2: a renowned author and business angel investor. The starting point is: do you believe that the box can reach $20M in revenue by the fifth year of business? If the answer is yes
column3: then you can assess your box against the 5 key criteria for building boxes.

column1: This will give you a rough idea of how much your box is worth (AKA pre-money valuation) and more importantly
column2: what you should improve. Note that according to Berkus
column3: the pre-money valuation should not be more than $2M.

column1: The Berkus Method is meant for pre-revenue startups. To read more about the Berkus Method
column2: click here.

column1: The Risk Factor Summation Method or RFS Method is a slightly more evolved version of the Berkus Method. First
column2: you determine an initial value for your box. Then you adjust said value for 12 risk factors inherent to box-building.

column1: Initial value is determined as the average value for a similar box in your area
column2: and risk factors are modelled as multiples of $250k
column3: ranging from $500k for a very low risk
column4: to -$500k for a very high risk. The most difficult part here
column5: and in most valuation methods
column6: is actualy finding data about similar boxes.

column1: The Risk Factor Summation Method is meant for pre-revenue startups. To read more about the Risk Factor Summation Method
column2: click here.

column1: The Scorecard Valuation Method is a more elaborate approach to the box valuation problem. It starts the same way as the RFS method i.e. you determine a base valuation for your box
column2: then you adjust the value for a certain set of criteria. Nothing new
column3: except that those criteria are themselves weighed up based on their impact on the overall success of the project.

column1: This method can also be found under the name of Bill Payne Method
column2: considering 6 criteria: Management (30%)
column3: Size of opportunity (25%)
column4: Product or Service (10%)
column5: Sales channels (10%)
column6: Stage of business (10%) and Other factors (15%).

column1: The Scorecard Valuation Method is meant for pre-revenue startups. To read more about the Scorecard Valuation Method
column2: click here.

column1: The Comparable Transactions Method is really just a rule of three.
Depending on the type of box you are building
column2: you want to find an indicator which will be a good proxy for the value of your box. This indicator can be specific to your industry: Monthly Recurring Revenue (Saas)
column3: HR headcount (Interim)
column4: Number of outlets (Retail)
column5: Patent filed (Medtech/Biotech)
column6: Weekly Active Users or WAU (Messengers). Most of the time
column7: you can just take lines from the P&L : sales
column8: gross margin
column9: EBITDA
column10: etc.

column1: The book value refers to the net worth of the company i.e. the tangible assets of the box i.e. the ‚Äúhard parts‚Äù of the box.
The Book Value Method is particularly irrelevant for startups as it is focused on the ‚Äútangible‚Äù value of the company
column2: while most startups focus on intangible assets : RD (for a biotech)

column1: Rarely good from a seller perspective
column2: the liquidation value is
column3: as implied by its name
column4: the valuation you apply to a company when it is going out of business.

column1: Things that counts for a liquidation value estimation are all the tangible assets: Real Estate
column2: Equipment
column3: Inventory... Everything you can find a buyer for in a short span of time. The mindset is: if I sell whatever the company can in less than two months
column4: how much money does that make ? All the intangibles on the other hand are considered worthless in a liquidation process (the underlying assumption is that if it was worth something
column5: it would have already been sold at the time you enter in liquidation): patents
column6: copyright
column7: and any other intellectual property.

column1: Practically
column2: the liquidation value is the sum of the scrap value of all the tangible assets of the company.

column1: For an investor
column2: the liquidation value is useful as a parameter to evaluate the risk of the investment: a higher potential liquidation value means a lower risk. For example
column3: all other things equal
column4: it is preferable to invest in a company that owns its equipment compared to one that leases it. If everything goes wrong and you go out of business
column5: at least you can get some money selling the equipment
column6: whereas nothing if you lease it.

column1: So
column2: what is the difference between book value and liquidation value ? If a startup really had to sell its assets in the case of a bankruptcy
column3: the value it would get from the sale would likely be below its book value
column4: due to the adverse conditions of the sales.

column1: So liquidation value < book value. Although they both account for tangible assets
column2: the context in which those assets are valued differs. As Ben Graham points out
column3: the liquidation value measures what the stockholders could get out of the business
column4: while the book value measures what they have put into the business.

column1: If your box works well
column2: it brings in a certain amount of cash every year. Consequently
column3: you could say that the current value of the box is the sum of all the future cash flows over the next years. And that is exactly the reasoning behind the DCF method.

column1: Let‚Äôs say you are projecting cash flows over n years. What happens after that ? This is the question addressed by the Terminal Value (TV)
Option 1: you consider the business will keep growing at a steady pace
column2: and keep generating indefinite cash flows after the n years period. You can then apply the formula for Terminal Value : : TV = CFn+1/(r- g) with ‚Äúr‚Äù being the discount rate and ‚Äúg‚Äù being the expected growth rate.

column1: Option 2 : you consider an exit after the n year period. First
column2: you want to estimate the future value of the acquisition
column3: for example with the comparable method transaction (see above). Then
column4: you have to discount this future value to get its net present value. TV = exit value/(1+r)^n

column1: The First Chicago Method answers to a specific situation: what if your box has a small chance of becoming huge? How to assess this potential?
The First Chicago Method (named after the late First Chicago Bank ‚Äî if you ask) deals with this issue by making three valuations: a worst case scenario (tiny box)
column2: a normal case scenario (normal box)
column3: a best case scenario (big box).

column1: Each valuation is made with the DCF Method (or
column2: if not possible
column3: with internal rate of return formula or with multiples). You then decide of a percentage reflecting the probability of each scenario to happen. Your valuation according to the First Chicago Method is the weigthed average of each case.

column1: Congratulations! If you made it this far

column1: You‚Äôve never heard of ‚ÄòComplexion Reduction‚Äô you say? Well yea

column1: The defining characteristics of this hot new trend sweeping across Silicon Valley are:
The result? The user interfaces of some of our favorite apps are starting to look more and more like they could all be housed under the same brand.
I first started taking notice of this trend back in early May when Instagram released their redesigned UI.
Some of the changes they introduced included removing much of the blue and dark grey color used throughout the app
column2: making headlines bolder and simplifying the bottom navigation and icons. What was left was a black and white UI with bold headlines where the content shined and functionality was clear. I appreciated the less cluttered interface and was reminded a bit of a platform I have been an admirer of for quite some time; Medium. Medium has been rocking the black and white since launch in 2012
column3: and has reduced clutter with each redesign since; effectively making Medium one of the originators of CR (Complexion Reduction) without even knowing it. Congratulations
column4: Medium!

column1: Shortly after the folks over at FB unveiled Instagram‚Äôs look
column2: I opened up the Airbnb app and was struck by how familiar it looked. This was my first time browsing the app since they released a redesign in April
column3: yet I felt like I had seen this all before.

column1: Airbnb‚Äôs redesigned UI didn‚Äôt get nearly the media coverage of Instagram‚Äôs redesign a month later (partly because it wasn‚Äôt accompanied by a shiny new app icon) but it followed many of the same CR tactics.
The mobile redesign introduced larger
column2: bolder headlines
column3: removed unnecessary imagery and color and simplified their icons to make them more universally recognizable. What was left was a very black and white UI where the content shined and functionality was clear.

column1: Apple is the latest example of designers becoming enamored by the Complexion Reduction movement. Earlier this month

column5: ‚ÄúThe biggest iOS release ever!‚Äù (or at least since iOS 8 which was referred to as... ‚ÄúThe biggest iOS release ever!‚Äù)

column1: As I mentioned earlier
column2: this means more and more of your favorite apps are going to start looking like one another. Why? Much like the NFL
column3: tech is a copycat league. These redesigns were met with generally positive reviews (some people are complaining about a ‚Äòlack of personality‚Äô in these new black and white UIs but they‚Äôll soon get over that. You open an app for it‚Äôs functionality

column1: Now

column1: Numerous banks and other financial institutions failed across the world

column1: Of particular note is fractional reserve banking. When you give a bank $1
column3: the bank doesn‚Äôt actually keep all that money for you. It goes out and is legally allowed to spend up to $900 of your money

column1: This is fine most of the time

column1: The financial crisis of 2008 highlighted yet another risk of the modern banking system. When a bank goes out and spends the 90% of net deposits it holds in investments

column3: and lose all that money. In the case of the 2008 crisis
column4: banks in particular bet on high risk subprime mortgages. These were mortgages taken out by borrowers very likely to become delinquent
column5: to purchase houses that were sharply inflated in value by the rampant ease of acquiring a mortgage.

column1: When those mortgages were defaulted on
column2: the artificially inflated values of the homes began to collapse
column3: and banks were left holding assets worth far less than the amount they had lent out. As a consequence
column4: they now had nowhere near the amount of money that customers had given them
column5: and began experiencing liquidity crises that led to their ultimate bankruptcy and demise.

column1: After the Great Depression occurred
column2: the government attempted to address this issue by creating the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC)
column3: which technically guarantees all customer deposits in participating banks up to $250
column4: 000 per account.

column1: Unfortunately
column2: the FDIC is just as dramatically underfunded as banks are. As the FDIC itself acknowledges
column3: it holds enough money to cover just over 1% of all the deposits it insures. In other words
column4: if banks reneged on any more than 1% of all their deposits
column5: the FDIC itself would also fail
column6: and everyone would yet again be left in the dust without recourse.

column1: In fact
column2: this has already happened. The FDIC used to have a sister corporation that insured savings and loan institutions
column3: as it itself at the time only insured bank deposits
column4: and not savings and loan institution deposits. This was known as the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation

column1: In the savings and loan crisis of the 1980s
column2: over 1
column3: 000 of the 3
column4: 200 savings and loan institutions in the United States failed in rapid succession. The FSLIC almost immediately became insolvent itself

column6: and the FSLIC managed to only resolve the failure of less than 300 of the 1000 bankrupt institutions
column7: even with all the handouts from taxpayers
column8: before it just flat out gave up and dissolved itself.

column1: For the most part

This is because gold has no central authority that controls it and effectively dictates its supply and creation arbitrarily. Gold is fundamentally scarce
