column1: Bitcoin was designed
column2: essentially
column3: as a better ‚Äòdigital gold‚Äô. It incorporates all of the best elements of gold ‚Äî its inherent scarcity and decentralized nature ‚Äî and then solves all the shortcomings of gold
column4: in allowing it to be globally transactable in precise denominations extremely quickly.

column1: How does it do this? In short
column2: by emulating gold‚Äôs production digitally. Gold is physically mined out of the ground. Bitcoin is also ‚Äòmined‚Äô
column3: but digitally. The production of bitcoin is controlled by code that dictates you must find a specific answer to a given problem in order to unlock new bitcoins.

column1: In technical terms
column2: bitcoin utilizes the same proof-of-work system that Hashcash devised in 1997. This system dictates that one must find an input that when hashed
column3: creates an output with a specific number of preceding zeros
column4: among a few other specific requirements.

column1: This is where the ‚Äòcrypto‚Äô
column2: incidentally
column3: in cryptocurrency comes from. Cryptographic hash functions are fundamentally necessary for the functioning of bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies
column4: as they are one-way functions. One-way functions work such that it is easy to calculate an output given an input
column5: but near impossible to calculate the original input given the output. Hence
column6: cryptographic one-way hash functions enable bitcoin‚Äôs proof of work system
column7: as it ensures that it is nigh-impossible for someone to just see the output required to unlock new bitcoins
column8: and calculate in reverse the input that created that output.

column1: Instead
column2: one must essentially brute-force the solution
column3: by trying every single possible input in order to find one that creates an output that satisfies the specified requirements.

column1: Bitcoin is further ingeniously devised to guarantee that on average
column2: new bitcoins are only found every 10 minutes or so. It guarantees this by ensuring that the code that dictates the new creation of bitcoin automatically increases the difficulty of the proof-of-work system in proportion to the number of computers trying to solve the problem at hand.

column1: For instance
column2: in the very beginning of time
column3: it was only the creator of bitcoin who was mining for bitcoins. He used one computer to do so. For simplicity‚Äôs sake
column4: let‚Äôs assume this one computer could try 1000 different values to hash a second. In a minute
column5: it would hash 60
column6: 000 values
column7: and in 10 minutes
column9: 000 values.

column1: The algorithm that dictates the mining of bitcoins
column2: therefore
column3: would ensure that on average
column4: it would take 600
column5: 000 random tries of hashing values to find one that would fulfill the requirements of the specified output required to unlock the next block of bitcoins.

column1: It can do this by making the problem more or less difficult
column2: by requiring more or less zeros at the beginning of the output that solves the problem. The more zeros that are required at the beginning of the output
column3: the more exponentially difficult the problem becomes to solve. To understand why this is
column4: click here for a reasonably good explanation.

column1: In this case
column2: it would require just the right amount of leading zeros and other characters to ensure that a solution is found on average every 600
column3: 000 or so tries.

column1: However
column2: imagine now that a new computer joins the network
column3: and this one too can compute 1000 hashes a second. This effectively doubles the rate at which the problem can be solved
column4: because now on average 600
column5: 000 hashes are tried every 5 minutes
column6: not 10.

column1: Bitcoin‚Äôs code elegantly solves this problem by ensuring that every 2
column2: 016 times new bitcoin is mined (roughly every 14 days at 10 minutes per block)
column3: the difficulty adjusts to become proportional to how much more or less hashing power is mining for bitcoin
column4: such that on average new bitcoin continues to be found roughly every ten minutes or so.

column1: You can see the present difficulty of mining bitcoin here. It should be evident from a half-second glance that the amount of computing power working to mine bitcoin right now is immense
column2: and the difficulty is proportionally similarly immense. As of the time of this writing right now
column3: there are close to 5 billion billion hashes per second being run to try to find the next block of bitcoin.

column1: This system holds a lot of advantages even over gold‚Äôs natural system of being mined out of the ground. Gold‚Äôs mining is effectively random and not dictated by any perfect computer algorithm
column2: and is consequently much more unpredictable in its output at any given moment. If a huge supply of gold is serendipitously found somewhere
column3: it could theoretically dramatically inflate the rate at which gold enters the existing supply
column4: and consequently cause an unanticipated decrease in the unit price of gold.

column1: This isn‚Äôt just theoretical ‚Äî it‚Äôs the reality of gold production. This graph illustrates vividly the fact that gold production has been dramatically increasing over time
column2: and is today over four times higher than just a hundred years ago.

column1: In fact
column2: more than half of all the gold that has ever been mined in the history of humankind has been mined in just the past 50 years. The difficulty of mining gold doesn‚Äôt proportionally increase with the number of people mining it
column3: or with technological innovations that make it significantly easier to locate and mine gold over time.

column1: Bitcoin
column2: on the other hand
column3: will always be mined on a carefully regulated schedule
column4: because it can perfectly adapt no matter how many people begin to mine it or how technologically advanced bitcoin mining hardware becomes.

column1: In fact
column2: it‚Äôs already known for certain that there will only ever be a total of 21 million bitcoins in the world.

column1: On top of this
column2: bitcoin is trivially divisible to any arbitrary degree. Presently
column3: the smallest unit of bitcoin is known as a satoshi

column1: This means that unlike gold
column2: bitcoin is perfectly suited to not only being an inflation-proof store of value
column3: but also a day-to-day transactable currency as well

column1: Moreover
column2: bitcoin can be sent incredibly quickly and remotely over the internet to anyone anywhere in the world. This is because when bitcoin is mined
column3: the miners are actually providing a service in powering the bitcoin network.

column1: What happens when a miner mines bitcoin is actually that they add a ‚Äòblock‚Äô to what is known as the ‚Äòblockchain‚Äô. The blockchain is a ledger that contains a record of every transaction ever made with bitcoins since its inception. When someone decides to mine bitcoin
column2: they must download the entire blockchain as it presently stands.

column1: Then
column2: when they successfully find a solution to the next hash problem and mine a block of bitcoins
column3: something magical happens. They get to add the block they just mined to the end of the existing blockchain ‚Äî and with it
column4: they include every transaction that was initiated on the bitcoin network since the last block was mined. They then propagate this block they just created to the rest of the network of bitcoin miners
column5: who all then update their own blockchains with this new block
column6: and begin working on solving the next hash problem.

column1: As a reward for providing this valuable service
column2: miners are allowed to add a single transaction to the beginning of the block they mined
column3: called the ‚Äòcoinbase transaction‚Äô. This transaction contains the brand new bitcoin that was created when they mined the block
column4: and allows the miner to claim this bitcoin for themselves.

column1: At this point
column2: a particularly shrewd reader might become concerned with the fact that the reward for mining a new block of bitcoin gradually shrinks to zero. Won‚Äôt this cause miners to stop mining bitcoin
column3: and consequently to stop providing the invaluable service that allows the bitcoin network to function and for transactions to be sent?

column1: The answer is no
column2: because miners are not solely rewarded by the new bitcoin that is generated each time they mine a block. Users may also send a transaction fee along with their transactions
column3: which is paid out to any miner who decides to include their transaction in a block they mine. Over time
column4: as the bitcoin network becomes used for more and more transactions
column5: it is expected that transaction fees will be more than sufficient for incentivizing enough miners to continue mining blocks to keep the bitcoin network safe
column6: secure
column7: and robust.

column1: It‚Äôs important that enough miners keep trying to mine blocks because this is another valuable service miners provide the network. Bitcoin
column2: like gold
column3: is powerful as a store of value because it is decentralized and trustless. There is no one central authority who holds all the power over bitcoin
column4: just like no central authority holds power over gold.

column1: No one person or government can decide to conjure up more bitcoin on demand
column2: or to take it away. The only way the rules that govern bitcoin can be changed is if the software bitcoin miners run to mine bitcoin is changed.

column1: Technically
column2: any bitcoin miner could decide to change the software they run to mine bitcoin at any time. However
column3: this still doesn‚Äôt have any impact on changing bitcoin itself. What it would do is cause a ‚Äòhard fork‚Äô
column4: or a divergence in the block chain.

column1: This occurs because any block that the rogue miner who changed their software mines won‚Äôt be accepted by all the other miners who are still running the original software. Consequently
column2: all the other miners will begin mining different blocks
column3: and adding those to their blockchain. This leads to a fork in the road
column4: essentially
column5: where two completely different blockchains are formed ‚Äî one by the rogue miner
column6: and one by all the other miners.

column1: Everything up to the point of the software change remains the same in both blockchains
column2: but after that change
column3: the blockchains diverge. Once diverged
column4: they can never be reconciled and remerged.

column1: This isn‚Äôt a concern
column2: however
column3: because the bitcoin network runs on consensus
column4: and accepts whichever blockchain is the longest. In practice
column5: this means that whichever blockchain has the most computing power behind it is effectively guaranteed to win
column6: as they‚Äôll be able to calculate the solutions to the hash problems and find new blocks faster than their less powerful competitors.

column1: This does mean that in theory
column2: bitcoin is vulnerable to what‚Äôs known as a 51% attack ‚Äî an attack in which if a single entity was able to gain control of at least 51% of the total hashing power being directed at bitcoin mining
column3: it could outpace a legitimate blockchain and temporarily take control of the network.

column1: This is an extraordinarily difficult feat to accomplish
column2: however
column3: as the more people there are mining bitcoin
column4: the harder it is to take over the network. At the current worldwide mining rate of almost 5 billion gigahashes a second
column5: it would be extraordinarily difficult for even the most powerful organizations in the world (e.g.
column6: large-scale governments) to mount a successful 51% attack. It would be enormously costly
column7: and quite possibly more financially detrimental to the attacker than to the network.

column1: Indeed
column2: the only thing a 51% attacker could really accomplish is destroying collective faith in bitcoin. They couldn‚Äôt somehow steal and gain all the value of bitcoins for itself. The attacker wouldn‚Äôt be able to generate new bitcoins on demand arbitrarily
column3: and would still have to mine for them. They also would have no control over taking bitcoins created in the past that didn‚Äôt belong to them. The only thing they could do
column4: really
column5: is repeatedly spend bitcoin they already owned again and again
column6: but even this is limited in its value
column7: because ‚Äòhonest‚Äô miner nodes would never accept these fraudulent payments.

column1: Hence
column2: no rationally self-interested bitcoin miner would ever try to mount a 51% attack
column3: as in all likelihood
column4: they would lose massive amounts of money doing so and gain almost nothing from the effort. The only reason someone would want to conduct a 51% attack is to attempt to destroy faith in bitcoin ‚Äî large governments
column5: for instance
column6: who might one day feel that their fiat currencies that presently provide them great value to them are becoming threatened by bitcoin. However
column7: the likelihood even of these enormous entities to successfully conduct a 51% attack is already becoming vanishingly small
column8: as mining power increases.

column1: Thus
column2: bitcoin has perfectly utilized recent technological advances to create something heretofore impossible: an extremely safe
column3: reliable
column4: decentralized
column5: and globally transactable digital and better version of gold
column6: and possibly of all types of extant currency at large.

column1: The advantages don‚Äôt stop there
column2: however. Bitcoin is also ‚Äòpseudonymous‚Äô

column1: A contract written with and enforced by code

column1: Sure

column1: It turns out these gaps in value between the worth of the ‚Äòtangible‚Äô thing itself and the actual value of the currency as it stands on the market today is just as much conjured up out of thin air as a mere concept as bitcoin‚Äôs perceived value is.
This ‚Äòintangible‚Äô worth that we ascribe to currency
column2: which accounts for the vast majority of the value of all currencies
column3: not just bitcoin
column4: is ultimately what makes money work. Yuval Noah Harari captures this fact very well in Sapiens
column5: where he lays out the case that the value of a given form of money is essentially an indication of trust in that form of money. It is our shared collective trust and belief in a currency that gives it value

column1: Gold holds its value well because we trust that we will all collectively continue to trust it as a store of value forever

column3: and that it is deserving of trust. The moment that collective trust collapses

column5: no matter what its intrinsic ‚Äòtangible‚Äô value.

column1: This is why no fiat currency has ever stood the test of time over a long enough timescale
column2: whereas gold has to date always stood the test of time and retained its value well. Collective trust for gold has never collapsed because of its inherent scarcity and immunity to the vicissitudes fiat currencies must endure at the hands of capricious centralized governing powers
column3: whereas collective trust in every historical fiat currency has inevitably failed to date
column4: and collective trust in many present-day fiat currencies continues to fail as we speak.

column1: Expected value is a useful concept frequently employed in poker that also serves to provide utility here. In short
column2: expected value is a way to decide when an outcome is not certain
column3: but a set of outcomes are probabilistically determinable
column4: if a given action is going to be net positive or net negative
column5: and to what degree.

column1: The simplest example is flipping a coin. This will yield heads 50% of the time
column2: and tails 50% of the time. Expected value of betting on the coin yielding heads
column3: hence
column4: is 0. This is because in any one given flip
column5: the coin has exactly a 50% chance of coming up heads. Hence
column6: if you bet $100 on the coin coming up heads an infinite number of times
column7: your expected gain
column8: or value
column9: from such an action
column10: is to be $0.

column1: Conversely
column2: if you bet at even odds that a six sided dice roll would come up 3 or higher
column3: your expected value would be positive
column4: as you would be correct 2/3 times. Hence
column5: if you repeated this bet an infinite number of times
column6: you would be guaranteed to be earning more money than you lost.

column1: Similarly
column2: if you were able to bet at 1:2 odds (meaning if you bet $100 and win
column3: you get $200) that a coin would yield heads
column4: this would also be very +EV (positive expected value). The coin would still yield heads half the time
column5: but that half of the time
column6: you would earn $200
column7: and the other half of the time
column8: you would only lose $100. Hence
column9: repeating this bet an infinite number of times would allow you to dramatically earn more money than you lost yet again.

column1: There are far too many variables and unknowns to take into consideration with most speculative bets
column2: and cryptocurrency in particular
column3: to be able to hope for anything so nice and clean as an exact mathematical probability of how + or -EV a given bet on a given cryptocurrency might turn out
column4: just as there are far too many unknowns to calculate the precise fundamental present and future potential value of a cryptocurrency for the purpose of value investing analysis
column5: but regardless
column6: holding both principles at large as a general guiding strategy in determining one‚Äôs actions here and elsewhere is a good bet.

column1: Trezor will keep your coins safe because the device itself is immune to hacking by design
column2: and never exposes your private keys (the passwords to your accounts
column3: essentially)
column4: even if your computer is infected by malware and is logging all your typing/passwords
column5: or is specifically scanning for private keys
column6: or is engaging in any other form of sneaky bad behavior.

column1: It does this by signing all transactions on the device itself using your private key
column2: and only transmitting the signature to your computer
column3: and never your private key. As a general rule
column4: this is very good
column5: because a good rule of thumb is to never expose your private keys to the internet
column6: under the assumption that the internet is inherently insecure
column7: and if you ever have your private keys interact in any direct way with a computer that has been connected to the internet
column8: you should consider the addresses those private keys correspond to to be compromised and vulnerable to being hacked.

column1: A Trezor also allows you to set multiple passwords that open secret vaults to different wallets on your device
column2: such that even if in some crazy scenario someone just kidnaps you and threatens to beat you with a wrench until you give them your coins (not too crazy actually ‚Äî I‚Äôve been abducted before and had to ransom myself for thousands of dollars in Africa)
column3: you can just give them a second password to another wallet that holds say $500 in cryptocurrency instead of $10 million
column4: and there‚Äôs no way for them to know that that‚Äôs not all the money you had on your Trezor.

column1: If someone steals your Trezor
column2: they won‚Äôt be able to find your coins either
column3: as they‚Äôre protected by a PIN that only you know (plus a password if you want to use that feature I mentioned above). You can also recover the coins yourself with the recovery seed the Trezor will give you the first time you use it
column4: which you should store in a super safe location like a safe deposit box somewhere. If you don‚Äôt use utilize the password feature
column5: however
column6: keep in mind that anyone who discovers this recovery seed instantly has access to all your coins
column7: and all your other forms of security are for naught. If you enable the password feature
column8: however
column9: they will need your password as well as the recovery seed in able to access your cryptocurrency
column10: which makes it significantly more secure.

column1: Another benefit of holding coins yourself
column2: in a hardware wallet or elsewhere
column3: is that you know that you 100% own all of your money. Exchanges are just like banks
column4: in the sense that you trust them to hold your money for you. If they end up losing that money to hackers or stealing it themselves
column5: you‚Äôre out of luck. This isn‚Äôt just a scary bedtime story ‚Äî countless cryptocurrency exchanges have been embezzled or hacked (an enormous percentage
column6: actually)
column7: and hundreds of millions of dollars have been lost.

column1: Moreover
column2: in the event of a hard fork
column3: whereby two blockchains are created
column4: and consequently
column5: two sets of coins that you technically should own
column6: only some exchanges will actually give you access to both sets of coins. Most notably
column7: Coinbase has explicitly stated that they will only give you access to the dominant blockchain that emerges from a hard fork
column8: no matter how much value the market assigns the non-dominant chain. They may or may not give you access to the other coins in the future
column9: but there is no guarantee either way. In any event
column10: with any exchange you are fundamentally agreeing to trust them to give you access to both sets of your coins
column11: even if they say they will. If you own your coins yourself in your own wallet
column12: however
column13: you need to trust no one. You will automatically own both sets of coins by default in the event of any fork.

column1: This
column2: too
column3: is not merely a theoretical matter. Ethereum did indeed hard fork after the DAO hack
column4: and split off into ETH (the current dominant blockchain for ethereum) and ETC (the ‚Äòclassic‚Äô
column5: or original blockchain for ethereum). As of this time
column6: ETC is worth over $20 a coin ‚Äî more
column7: in fact
column8: than all of ethereum was worth before the hack. Had I kept my ethereum on Coinbase or another exchange like it at the time of the hard fork
column9: I personally would have lost 5 figures in ETC (at present values) merely because the exchanges wouldn‚Äôt give me access to these coins that I rightfully owned.

column1: Finally
column2: my personal preference is to avoid keeping all my eggs in one basket. Despite the fact that a hardware wallet like Trezor is technically one of the most secure options for keeping your coins safe with a fair amount of redundancy in recovery options
column3: the fact remains that one day I might somehow lose access to my coins held within Trezor. I might suffer a concussion
column4: for instance
column5: that causes me to forget the password or the PIN required to access the Trezor
column6: or perhaps I lose my Trezor and am unable to locate or decipher my recovery seed.

column1: Because of this
column2: I actually personally keep my cryptocurrency distributed in several reasonably safe baskets. For instance
column3: despite Coinbase being an exchange that fundamentally requires some trust
column4: they are more trustworthy than almost any other exchange on a technical level (their customer service
column5: however
column6: leaves something to be desired)
column7: and it is virtually impossible for their coins to be hacked to any significant degree
column8: and all those at risk of being hacked are fully insured. As a consequence
column9: I leave some of my coins with them
column10: merely because in many ways
column11: I trust their technical security measures more than I trust my own. Before GBTC started trading at such an absurd premium
column12: I also kept some of my funds with them
column13: both in part to diversify across multiple platforms to reduce the risk of losing all my coins with one bad black swan event
column14: and also because it was the only immediately easy way to put some of my retirement funds into bitcoin
column15: short of creating a self directed IRA.

column1: Okay ‚Äî so that‚Äôs about it for investing in the dominant cryptocurrencies available today. If you want to invest in other more speculative altcoins

column2: particularly people who design products. Day after day
column3: I see companies break this rule
column4: and it is 100% of the time to their detriment. In this article I will explain what that rule is
column5: and what it means to product and service design. I‚Äôll also raise the possible implications of this phenomenon on organizational management
column6: collaboration
column7: and general performance. The psychological phenomenon I will be discussing in this article is known as Miller‚Äôs Law. Rather than just tell you what Miller‚Äôs Law is
column8: I ask you to take part in this exercise for a more immersive learning lesson.

column1: Read the italicized instructions before starting. Grab a pen and paper. This is an exercise where you will try to recall words you‚Äôve just read
column2: off memory.

column1: Below is a list of 20 words. Read them to comprehension
column2: and try to memorize as many as possible. Try to keep the words ‚Äòin your head‚Äô. Do not write the words. Spend about a minute. After you are done reading
column3: scroll down until you see the word ‚ÄòSTOP‚Äô. Then
column4: read step 2.

column1: Now
column2: use your pen and paper to write down as many words as you can remember from the list. Think hard
column3: but do not scroll back up to view the words. If you scroll up

column5: scroll back up and check how many you got right.

column1: If you are like the vast majority of human beings
column2: you will have remembered 5‚Äì9 of the words. Hundreds of experiments prove universality of this limitation on memory. When I first discovered this phenomenon
column3: I knew it had huge implications on product design
column4: because of the degree to which this limitation affects day to day tasks. This capacity for keeping ~7 bits of information ‚Äòin the head‚Äô short term
column5: is known as Miller‚Äôs Law.

column1: In 1956 there was a paper written that became one of the most highly cited papers in psychology. Titled
column2: The Magical Number Seven
column3: Plus or Minus Two: Some Limits on Our Capacity for Processing Information
column4: it was published in 1956 by the cognitive psychologist George A. Miller of Princeton University‚Äôs Department of Psychology in Psychological Review. The crux of the paper suggests that the number of perceptual ‚Äòchunks‚Äô an average human can hold in working memory (a component of short-term memory) is 7 ¬± 2. This is frequently referred to as Miller‚Äôs law. Here is a summary of the article
column5: sourced from wikipedia:

column1: Moreover
column2: the human mind can remember ~7 bits of information when completing a task that requires cognitive effort. This is critical
column3: because humans are constantly performing tasks
column4: and trying to juggle various stimuli in the mind when doing so. One of the key concepts behind Miller‚Äôs Law is ‚Äòchunking‚Äô
column5: which basically means assembling various bits of information into a cohesive gestalt. For example
column6: the word ¬∑ p e n c i l ¬∑ is actually a ‚Äòchunk‚Äô of letters
column7: organized into a perceptual gestalt. If the letters were rearranged ¬∑ c n l i p e ¬∑ it would be six separate chunks of information. Chunking is a critical element of information organization
column8: and is the basis for our UX and organizational rule.

column1: Always organize elements of information in categories no larger than 9
column2: but preferably ~5 chunks.

column1: The more chunks of information you add to an ‚Äòinterface‚Äô
column2: the more difficult it becomes to ‚Äòwork‚Äô
column3: using the information at hand. This is especially critical for first time users
column4: because they haven‚Äôt had the ‚Äòpractice‚Äô needed to encode the interface into long term memory
column5: or
column6: for the behaviour to become habitual. I constantly see this rule being broken by giants like Facebook
column7: Google
column8: and Wordpress. Don‚Äôt even get me started on automobile interface design. The ~5 bit chunk rule also compliments minimalism as a rigorous design philosophy. To expound
column9: due to the limitations of working memory
column10: as a product becomes more feature-full it inevitably becomes more difficult to use
column11: because the user has to manage more information while operating the product. This makes good information design so critical.

column1: Millers Law also highlights the importance of foresight and proper planning in the design process
column2: because as you add more features to a product ‚Äî your interface must be able to accommodate those new features without breaking the visual foundation of what you built. Rebuilding a foundation takes immense time and resources.

column1: Another perceptual phenomenon observed in relation to Miller‚Äôs Law is known as the primacy
column2: and recency effect. These terms are used respectively to describe how we remember items sensed at the beginning and end of an experience
column3: more than ones in the middle. For example
column4: if I were to show you a list of words
column5: you would more likely remember the words at the beginning of the list
column6: and the end. This is also known as the serial position effect. From wikipedia:

column1: This observation raises huge questions in business and design. If people remember more at the beginning and end of an experience
column2: how do we enhance the positives
column3: and mitigate the negatives at these respective times? When does an experience truly begin and end? Should we be organizing more important elements at the beginning and end of lists due to their increased retention? These are all valid questions that UX designers and executives should ask when inventing or developing their product.

column1: Millers Law can be applied to any aspect of your life that involves performing a mildly complex task. By reducing the amount of elements in your reach/access ‚Äî and keeping them organized by relevant chunks not exceeding 9 bits
column2: your brain will be able to remember exactly where things are so you can access its functionality. When lists of items grow too large
column3: they become very difficult to mentally map them
column4: requiring the user to do more cumbersome searching.

column1: The adherence to Miller‚Äôs Law is especially relevant in the light of lean methodologies and recent trends in tech and UX. Users want and need a trial before they purchase something ‚Äî it‚Äôs that simple. If they don‚Äôt experience the value within the first day or week of using it ‚Äî they won‚Äôt buy. Since new users do not have lengthly time to learn where everything is ‚Äî information design needs to be planned and well thought out before development happens.
We live in a world with an exponentially increasing amount of information. By not organizing it properly
column2: or eliminating some completely
column3: it ultimately degrades our ability to complete critical tasks for the purposes of survival (navigation/gaining income). That is why it‚Äôs so useful to omit items
column4: products
column5: and services from your life that aren‚Äôt giving a quality return on investment. This falls in line with the Pareto principle
column6: the idea that 80% of your outcomes comes from 20% of your investments. Are you juggling too many tasks per day to be efficient? Is your team using too many tools to collaborate? Do you have too many members on your team? Are you overloading your new employees with information
column7: leading to confusion?

column1: Millers law teaches us that humans have a finite amount of information they can process
column2: and that information overload will lead to distraction that negatively affects performance. Companies should look for ways to organize information in a way that is much more digestible for their customers and employees. This could be by eliminating tools or applications that are producing cognitive overload
column3: reducing the amount of members on a team
column4: or even organizing your departments based on our knowledge of working memory.

column1: This is especially true in new science of the concept of flow
column2: made famous by psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi. Flow is a word Mihaly coined to describe a state of concentration or ‚Äòabsorption‚Äô with a specific task that humans ultimately find rewarding
column3: pleasurable
column4: and fulfilling. He describes it as an optimal state where we perform at our best and truly live ‚Äòin the moment‚Äô. One sure way to kill flow is by increasing distractions in the workplace. So
column5: do you think that by giving your employees more tools
column6: that it actually enhances performance? Miller‚Äôs Law teaches us time and time again this is not the case. When it comes to completing tasks
column7: less is more.

column1: Turn off your desktop slack notifications. Get rid of the things you never use. Stop checking your various inboxes. Master one tool
column2: not many. Now start focusing.

From 2008 to 2015
column2: Volkswagen produced more than 10 million ‚Äúclean diesel‚Äù cars. Many engineers were amazed that diesel engines could produce so much less emissions than standard unleaded cars
column3: and still have such high mileage. Well
column4: their doubts were vindicated in 2014
column5: when researchers discovered that these cars were using ‚Äúdefeat devices.‚Äù

column1: Executives at Volkswagen had ordered their software engineers to figure out a way to trick the Environmental Protection Agency during their emissions tests. They knew that during these tests
column2: regulators would use specific parameters. So they wrote logic that ‚Äî if those parameters were selected ‚Äî the engine would run in a special mode.

column1: This ‚Äúdefeat device‚Äù masked the fact that ‚Äúclean diesel‚Äù Volkwagen engines were actually producing much greater nitrogen-oxide (NOx) emissions than were legally allowed. Up to 40 times the federal limit.
And this stuff causes lung cancer. MIT scientists estimate that these emissions will ultimately cause 60 people to die prematurely. And that‚Äôs just in America.
That‚Äôs right ‚Äî the software these developers wrote kills innocent people.
Volkswagen ultimately paid out a $14.7 billion settlement in 2016.
This will remain one the greatest environmental tragedies of our time ‚Äî all brought on by a few developers who were just following orders.
The world is increasingly dependent on the code that developers create. As such
column2: developers are quickly becoming some of the most powerful people in the world.

column1: Coding is a superpower. With it

column1: You may be able to fool the regulators
column2: the police
column3: the judges. You may be able to fool the general public. And you may be able to go on doing this indefinitely without being caught.

column1: But that doesn‚Äôt make it right.
Developers have great power. And they must use this power responsibly.
If you‚Äôre a developer
column2: or working toward becoming one

column1: And if someone asks you to build something that is clearly illegal ‚Äî or downright evil ‚Äî go to the press. The developers in all three of these cases could have done this and saved the world a lot of heart ache.

V8 is an open source runtime engine written in C++.
JavaScript -> V8(C++) -> Machine Code
V8 implements a script called ECMAScript as specified in ECMA-262. ECMAScript was created by Ecma International to standardize JavaScript.
V8 can run standalone or can be embedded into any C++ application. It has hooks that allow you to write your own C++ code that you can make available to JavaScript.
This essentially lets you add features to JavaScript by embedding V8 into your C++ code so that your C++ code understands more than what the ECMAScript standard otherwise specifies.

Kris Gage|55K|7|https://medium.com/@krisgage/8-things-i-learned-reading-50-books-a-year-for-7-years-cb11c4acffb1?source=tag_archive---------3---------------------|8 Things I Learned Reading 50 Books A Year For 7 Years|I‚Äôve read over 300 books since the beginning of 2011
column2: not counting the many I started but didn‚Äôt finish and the endless content we all read online.

column1: I‚Äôve read about topics ranging from Buddhism to business
column2: philosophy to physics
column3: and writers ranging from feminists to pick-up artists (and even Trump‚Äôs ‚ÄúArt of The Deal.‚Äù) I‚Äôve read old books
column4: new books
column5: books with illustrations and fancy charts
column6: a lot of books from which I got nothing and a handful of books I still love. 90% of this was non-fiction.

column1: Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned in all that reading time ‚Äî and some of my favorite books from my 20‚Äôs.
There are two camps of ‚Äúgood books‚Äù and both of them are rare.
(Writing that offers both
column2: it should be said
column3: is the incredibly rare and precious gem indeed.)

column1: When it comes to choosing between them
column2: as we must
column3: I prefer the former over the latter. I‚Äôm not here to be romanced.

column1: (That being said
column2: some of my favorite ‚Äúgood craft‚Äù writing is by way of essays and/or out of writers such as Barnes
column3: Keegan
column4: and Solnit.)

column1: Here‚Äôs one such excerpt. You obviously don‚Äôt have to read it.
Regardless of which direction you go
column2: though
column3: the truly good book is a thing to cherish.

column1: My least favorite books are what I call ‚Äúbullshit business books‚Äù ‚Äî the theoretical fluff written by people who have never directly done the thing.
The authors have read about others doing the thing
column2: they‚Äôre consultants on the thing
column3: they‚Äôre academics of the thing. They‚Äôre professors
column4: or ‚Äúentrepreneurs‚Äù of nothing
column5: or heads of ‚Äúorganizations
column6: ‚Äù and they make it their business to compile all the notes they‚Äôve seen from other people‚Äôs actual businesses and pawn it off as ‚Äúexpertise
column7: ‚Äù like some armchair anthropologist reporting on ‚Äúlife in the Congo‚Äù because he visited once
column8: so now he ‚Äúknows.‚Äù

column1: In other words: most of the shit sold in airport book stores.
I read a truly unfortunate number of these books before I got fed up enough to swear them off forever
column2: like dumping that big-talk lover who promises you the moon but just leaves dirty laundry everywhere.

column1: And if you learn only one thing from this post
column2: make it that.

column1: Sure
column2: there are studies about how it makes our brain smarter. And how all the most successful people read voraciously.

column1: And then we get people who are only trying to be successful ‚Äî and maybe even making a business out of talking about ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù‚Äî and they take up reading because they hear it‚Äôs clutch
column2: and then regurgitate it on down the chain.

column1: It disappoints me that we perpetuate this nonsense.
I‚Äôm not saying successful people don‚Äôt read ‚Äî many of them do
column2: I‚Äôm sure
column3: and they might even chalk their success up this
column4: in part. But reading isn‚Äôt the secret to success.

column1: I started and built my own business in late 2015. I had read dozens of books on marketing and entrepreneurship and customer segmentation and sales and product and design and everything else under the sun.
But when it came to decision-making
column2: the biggest impact was just doing it ‚Äî my own experience. At some point
column3: ‚Äúresearch‚Äù is just a distraction from real tasks. And you‚Äôll get a lot farther bumping along on your own without any books than you ever will reading and not actually doing anything else.

column1: Entrepreneur Gary Vaynerchuk wrote a fantastic piece on this
column2: pointing out:

column1: From books for healing to engineering books to resolve a design question
column2: books are an excellent resource for specific questions

column1: My favorite book last year was The Will To Change (hooks) because I was coming off a breakup. I may not have gotten as much out of it two years ago.
Once you get enough of an answer to act on
column2: stop reading and start doing. Otherwise it becomes
column3: as one cofounder of two companies once put it
column4: ‚Äúan academic exercise.‚Äù

column1: My favorite types of books are autobiographies and memoirs from people I admire ‚Äî with top slots going to Zero to One (Thiel)
column2: Big Magic(Gilbert)
column3: Fashion is Spinach (Hawes)
column4: The Hard Thing About Hard Things(Horowitz)
column5: and Man‚Äôs Search for Meaning (Frankl)
column6: and honorable mentions going to all of the dozens of autobiographical pieces I‚Äôve read (Vaynerchuk included.)

column1: I‚Äôll take any autobiography over any biography. I want to get to know the person. I want their thought process. I‚Äôll take a firsthand account with mediocre writing over flowery garbage that says nothing any day.
Some of my favorite non-autobiographical pieces are still-solid firsthand thought pieces like Rework (and pretty much any thing else Fried and/or Hansson put out) and The Law of Success (Hill)
column2: the latter of which includes a chapter on leadership that is by far one of my favorite pieces on management philosophy.

column1: As an aside: the only few pieces I hold in the same tier as firsthand accounts are well-researched and rich books on the human mind
column2: such as Flow: The Psychology of Optimal Experience (Csikszentmihalyi) and Blink (Gladwell).

column1: Maybe we‚Äôd eventually like a certain book
column2: but we‚Äôre just ‚Äúnot ready for it
column3: ‚Äù or right now‚Äôs not the right time.

column1: A guy I dated once let me borrow his copy of Sartre‚Äôs Nausea but warned me ‚Äúthat might not be where you‚Äôre at right now.‚Äù He was right. I didn‚Äôt finish. Maybe someday it might offer something
column2: but it didn‚Äôt then.

column1: This was also true of philosophy overall. When I first tried to wander in through its unlocked side door in my early 20‚Äôs
column2: I felt like I‚Äôd walked into the middle of a heated debate with big words and no context ‚Äî and philosophy isn‚Äôt a conversation where many are willing to pause to get you up to speed.

column1: But when I came back to philosophy a few years later
column2: with very specific questions I wanted answers
column3: I had a much more fruitful experience.

column1: Writers are people. Be careful what you read.
No matter your viewpoints
column2: you can find a writer who agrees. There are feminist writers
column3: there are man-hating writers
column4: and there are self-sabotaging writers who use big words like ‚Äústrong women‚Äù while simultaneously cutting themselves down with the task of ‚Äúwinning a man.‚Äù

column1: You can find angry writers
column2: sexist writers
column3: delusional writers
column4: depressed writers
column5: writers from all walks of life. So if you‚Äôre looking for someone to make you feel validated
column6: you can.

column1: That doesn‚Äôt make any opinion ‚Äî yours included ‚Äî right. And we have to remember this while reading
column2: especially when we‚Äôre looking for ‚Äúanswers to questions‚Äù and already have an idea of what answer we want.

column1: Similarly
column2: it might be tempting to forget that any single piece of work is only the viewpoint of a single person. It‚Äôs not everything ‚Äî only their lived experience (or
column3: at worst
column4: what they‚Äôre trying to sell you regarding yours.)

column1: One person‚Äôs bargain bin find is another person‚Äôs salvation.
One of my dear friends became enraptured with Rupi Kaur‚Äôs Milk and Honey
column2: and recommended it to me with that zeal with which we always throw beloved books at other people. I read through half a dozen pieces and
column3: much to the disappointment I could see fill her previously-eager eyes
column4: they just didn‚Äôt do anything for me.

column1: Some of it‚Äôs personality and values and individuality. Some of it‚Äôs just context
column2: and where we‚Äôre at in our journey.

column1: Reading can be an enjoyable escape
column2: if that‚Äôs what we want. It can also be intellectually rewarding ‚Äî but only if approached in a way that supports
column3: rather than distracts us from
column4: our growth.

column1: Because this is always the first question people ask (even after I tell them that reading is personal and it depends on what you‚Äôre looking for
column2: see above.)

column2: starting with no relevant background experience or degree. I used only self-directed study while working full-time and spending next to nothing.

column1: I wrote those excited words a few months ago as I was getting ready to start my first day at my new job. Come along with me as I share with you my journey of how I got here.
When I first started thinking about becoming a developer
column2: I would read articles like this one with a bit of skepticism. I kept on looking for something in the writer‚Äôs background that made them ‚Äúspecial‚Äù. That made them suited for this job. Something that I didn‚Äôt have.

column1: I have since come to understand that this is not how it works. There aren‚Äôt any ‚Äúspecial‚Äù requirements to becoming a developer. I‚Äôm not going to tell you it‚Äôs easy
column2: because it isn‚Äôt. But the good news is that all the requirements are things that are in everyone‚Äôs reach. You have to be willing to work hard
column3: learn a lot
column4: and be consistent. You need to persist when things get tough. Talk yourself out of the moments of desperation when you feel like you are not cut out for this. That‚Äôs all it takes
column5: and everyone can do these things with a bit of practice.

column1: I started with no related background study. I had no money to spend on expensive courses
column2: no time in my already busy day
column3: and I was already almost middle aged. Everyone‚Äôs circumstances are different
column4: but I learned that if you put your mind to it
column5: you can do it.

column1: On the day I wrote my first line of code
column2: I had never done any programming before or had any contact with it. I had an early career in the restaurant business. Then I got a degree in Music technology
column3: followed by a decade as an ESL teacher in Spain. I wasn‚Äôt even particularly skilled with computers. I did always feel excited by the latest tech ideas. And I considered programmers the modern day superheroes.

column1: I never contemplated doing it myself
column2: though. Partly because I thought coding was some kind of an elite activity. Something for gifted individuals who graduate from top (and expensive) universities. While individuals like this do exist
column3: the majority of developers aren‚Äôt that Hollywood hacker type. Development is far more accessible than I believed.

column1: It all started with an animated conversation with my partner. She was exploring the causes behind the low numbers of women in STEM and especially in tech. She decided to do something about it by becoming a programmer herself. She wanted to be a model for younger girls in our family. And just like that she started learning about it.
That soon excited me too
column2: as we realized that there are plenty of resources available. This wasn‚Äôt some dark art
column3: but a skill that we could learn and master.

column1: Spoiler alert
column2: she also managed a career change from HR and in fact got a developer job a month before I did.

column1: And so
column2: one day we found a children‚Äôs book about programming in a science museum. We went back home
column3: opened Notepad
column4:
wrote

Hello World

opened it in the browser and then changed color: red. We were screaming with excitement! What witchcraft was that!

column1: I was hooked. I wanted to make stuff with code
column2: I wanted computers to do things I said!

column1: At that point I had been working with kids for 8 years. This is not going to be the typical part where one talks about a dead-end job that they didn‚Äôt like. Because I loved my teaching job
column2: enjoyed working with kids
column3: and I was comfortable in my workplace. It was gratifying and enjoyable.

column1: But sometimes
column2: even when you love something
column3: you know in your heart that it is time to move on. It was a new phase in my life and I had a new outlook and new aspirations. And above all
column4: I wanted a new challenge. Something that would push me well out of my comfort zone.

column1: This clearly doesn‚Äôt exist. Three of us started around the same time learning to code for a career change: my partner
column2: myself
column3: and a good friend. All three of us are now working in the field
column4: and there is very little in common between our approaches. Each one followed the material and methods that worked for them. If there is one thing in common between us
column5: it is that we simply did not give up
column6: and kept on going. We all put a lot of hard work and persistence.

column1: So instead of the one true path
column2: I‚Äôm going to tell you a bit about my path. It‚Äôs not the only way
column3: it is not the best way. It is what worked for me.

column1: First
column2: I started reading and watching YouTube videos about programming to understand where to begin. Then I started playing around with HTML and CSS. I followed tutorials and coded along to build some basic web pages. This made me see that it was something I really wanted to get into.

column1: I reached out to two of my friends working in the field for tips and advice. Those early words of encouragement and guidance were vital in getting me going and in focusing my mind on a clear goal.
It took some time to sort through all the options and set realistic objectives that would work for me. I needed a swift career change. I had no alternative source of income
column2: which meant maintaining my job until I could do the switch.

column1: I decided that front-end development was the most accessible and in-demand option. I narrowed it down further by focusing on the skills needed for a job in a startup rather than the freelance route.
Then I set a deadline. I did not want this objective to end up on a to-do list I never see again. It was spring of 2017
column2: so I promised myself that the following school course was going to be my last as a teacher. So by September 2018
column3: a little over a year later
column4: I had to be working in the field.

column1: It would be naive to pretend that at this stage I had everything crystal clear and under control. I didn‚Äôt. Certainty is not a luxury you can have while making such a risky career change. There were all kinds of doubts at that point and throughout the process. The key here was persistence. Once I made the decision
column2: I was going to walk this path to see where it led no matter what.

column1: I knew that the only way forward was to study for it. I had full-time employment
column2: so waiting until ‚ÄúI had time‚Äù was never an option. I had to do it while working
column3: or not at all. I was lucky that my partner was learning at the same time. This helped us organize our days to maximize learning time. At first we would do what we called our ‚Äúweekend boot camps‚Äù where we would dedicate the entire weekend to coding. A typical day looked like this:

column1: 8:00 am: Wake up
column2: breakfast.8:30 am: Start coding12:30 pm: Go to the gym1:30 pm: Have lunch
column3: then a break3:00/4:00 pm: Continue coding8:00/11:00 pm: Finish for the day

column1: Then my summer holiday came and I made the most of it by turning the ‚Äúweekend boot camp‚Äù into the ‚Äúdaily boot camp‚Äù. I stuck to that schedule assiduously despite the temptation to enjoy the summer and kick back a bit.

September came and I was back to work. I had made a conscious decision to reduce my hours at work. I accepted that I would have less income in exchange for having more time to study. It was also another step to make my commitment to the career change more serious.

It is hard to convey how difficult it was to be away from my code. All I wanted to do was to be back at my computer to finish solving this problem or fixing that layout. But then real life kicks in. The start of a school year always requires a lot of time for preparation and organization. As any teacher will tell you
column2: it also takes up a lot of one‚Äôs personal time too.

column1: That was the moment my mission could have been derailed. Despite my best efforts
column2: I had less and less time to code. I started losing my momentum. I tried to keep it up but there were days when I simply didn‚Äôt have time. Even with the best of intentions and good motivation
column3: life can make things complicated.

column1: However
column2: as you can see from my GitHub activity image
column3: I kept trying. I kept putting in the time
column4: even if it was an hour
column5: even if it was reading an article. I did everything I could not to get to the stage of losing all motivation. When you have left something for long enough
column6: it makes it harder to get back to with every passing day.

column1: Then as December approached
column2: seeing the new year looming and my deadline closer
column3: I rallied again and got organized. I started pushing through
column4: putting in those hours no matter how tired I was and how little time I had. Sometimes I would get up early to code
column5: sometimes I would stay up late.

column1: This meant that my life was pretty much reduced to doing the job that was paying the rent
column2: and studying. And little else. And I basically maintained that rhythm all the way until the day I started packing to move to Madrid. That was in the spring of 2018
column3: several months before my deadline.

column1: Over the 10 months leading to my job offer
column2: I immersed myself in everything code related. The most frequent question I get asked on Twitter is about what resources I used. I‚Äôve written another article that answers this question in-depth. However
column3: here is a brief list of the most important tools and resources.

column1: Courses can only take you so far
column2: so I complemented this with other tools to help me learn and get a job.

column1: You can also check out My Learning Tracker GitHub repo. It has a full list of the resources and paths I used those first ten months.
Surprisingly
column2: for me
column3: this part was not overly complex. I didn‚Äôt send masses of CVs
column4: or spend hours looking for jobs. Instead I opted for being selective and focused.

column1: In the end I entered five interview processes. I got rejected from one
column2: and failed to finish the take-home challenge of another. I completed three
column3: and got three out of three offers. One of these was completely inadequate and unattractive. The other two
column4: arriving almost at the same time
column5: were both very interesting offers. One of them is my current job.

column1: I don‚Äôt mean to sound nonchalant about this. It was an intense time. I still had no idea if my skills were anywhere near being employable or not. I entered processes not even sure if I was going to be laughed at for how little experience I had. It was a nerve-racking time
column2: but it was an exciting and hopeful time too. And when I finally found myself with two actual good offers on the table I was elated and could hardly believe it.

column1: I will always be eternally grateful to the individuals who made these decisions and decided to give me a chance.

The interview process in the two companies was very different. One was a series of video calls to talk to various people at the company. It was a small but well-established company hoping to build a new team of front-end developers. After a few weeks of back and forth
column2: they made me my first real offer.

column1: The other was a young startup in the middle of great growth. After a phone interview I got sent a technical challenge to complete within few days. It involved building a component
column2: making API calls
column3: and showing the correct information. Then came a video chat about the code I wrote. Then I got invited to have a drink with the tech team to find out if we click. After which I got an offer to join as a junior front-end.

column1: In the end I had to choose. Which was a luxury I couldn‚Äôt believe I got. But I knew what I wanted
column2: I took the offer with the startup based on one main point: they seemed to be very clear on the importance of mentorship and giving me guidance to grow and learn. That was the key. And it definitely was the right choice.

column1: And so
column2: on that rainy day in Madrid
column3: after finishing my coffee. I walked into an office in the business area
column4: introduced myself as the new front-end developer
column5: and started my new career.

column1: I hope you enjoyed my story. If you did
column2: you would make me happy if you give it some of those tasty claps. And you could even make my day by sharing it so more people can read it and learn they too can make it. I want to keep writing more of these articles. So if there is any particular aspect of this process you would like to know more about
column3: I would love to hear about it. Come and say hi on Twitter @Syknapse

column1: Wait! We missed something.

column2: Blockchain is a particular type of decentralized system that has a unique property. Which property? Let‚Äôs talk about it.

column1: Let‚Äôs revisit our distributed parking example and make a small change. Let‚Äôs assume that the lock to a particular garage is generated when a car is parked inside it (we assume that the same car goes to the same parking everyday). Also
column2: assume that we have numbered all the distributed garages in serial order. The lock-key pair of garage #50 is based on the lock-key pair of garage #49 and also on the features (like color
column3: weight
column4: engine number etc.) of the car parked inside garage #50 and this process starts from garage #1 and moves till garage #200 or even more.

column1: Therefore
column2: if a thief tries to break into garage #49 and modifies any feature of the car
column3: say its color or registration number
column4: the features of car in garage #49 will change which means a new lock-key pair for garage #49 will be generated and since lock-key-pair for garage #50 depends on lock-key pair of garage #49
column5: lock-key pair for garage #50 will also change and same goes on for future garages.

column1: Now
column2: let‚Äôs make one last assumption that computing a lock-key pair requires lots of computing resources which means if we have to recompute these pairs in case any thief modifies any car feature in any garage
column3: it will be practically impossible to recompute all the pairs again.

column1: Hope you remember that we talked about all garage owners abiding by some rules? One of these rules is to check for a valid garage. A garage is valid if you can validate its lock-key pair and if any lock-key pair gets changed
column2: the lock-key pairs of all the following garages get invalid because every pair depends on the previous pair. (Process to validate a lock-key pair for a particular garage is very fast as compared to generating one).

column1: This dependence of one pair on the previous pair makes it a chain of garages and in technical world
column2: these garages are ‚Äúblocks‚Äù
column3: thus getting its name ‚Äî Blockchain (a chain of blocks).

column1: Blocks in Blockchain are tied to the next block by hashes just like lock-key pairs in our example. Similar to garage example
column2: if data in one block is modified
column3: hashes need to be recalculated for all the following blocks and since calculating the hash is a very resource intensive operation
column4: it gets practically impossible to do that and hence the network rules out the invalidated block. The calculation of hash is called mining and we will talk more about it in the next release of this series.

column1: All the computers on the blockchain network
column2: keep a copy of the full blockchain
column3: so if one block or one complete chain at a particular computer or multiple computers is modified
column4: the whole network tries to compare it with their own copies of the full chain.

column1: If majority of the nodes (or computers) on the network find that the modified chain is invalid
column2: the modified chain is replaced with valid chain from other nodes. This makes Blockchain vulnerable to 51% attack. In simpler words
column3: if more than 50% of the nodes on the network are malicious (or say have a modified chain)
column4: then the whole network can be compromised.

But we‚Äôve since realized a problem with personas. They are inherently an amalgamation

column1: In the 1950s

column3: 000 pilots and calculated the average size along 140 dimensions
column4: like height and chest circumference. They arrived at an average range for all 140 dimensions and theorized that most pilots would fit within that range. As it turns out

column1: So how can we put real customers first and circumvent the notion of an artificial average? One way is to kill your personas (sorry

column1: A persona spectrum is not a fake person. It‚Äôs an articulation of a specific human motivation and the ways it‚Äôs shared across multiple groups. It shows how that motivation can change depending on context. Sometimes

column3: people with a temporary wrist injury or a broken arm

column1: At Microsoft Design
column2: we‚Äôre working to use persona spectrums across a range of products. We‚Äôre asking hard questions about the intent and limitations of our personas

column1: Experiment without fear also means having to do it over and over again
column2: this constant experimentation and iteration should just feel like breathing oxygen
column3: you do it and you don't even think about it. Having this trait is essential if you want to stretch the boundaries of what can be done
column4: because when you're not afraid of proposing something that will be rejected the range of possible solutions will grow substantially.

column1: Designing is very much an exercise of using empathy (with your target user) and intuition to come up with possible solutions to a problem. I would like to stress the word possible because that's all they really are until you validate it. As a designer
column2: it's very difficult and dangerous to say that I have THE answer without actually having people look at it and trying it out.

column1: With my experience I learned that even when you have that gut feeling like ""this has to be the best possible solution""
column2: there‚Äôs always something to gain by sharing the work and getting a different perspective. It doesn't need to be a fully blown user test by the way
column3: it can be as easy as sharing with the colleague sitting next to you.

column1: When you design in a bubble it's easy to get lost in your idea and even easier to start to see it as natural and intuitive. Because you came up with it and have been looking at it for the past couple of hours it's going to seem like the most obvious thing in the world.
With that said
column2: it's also good to mention that we also need to be pragmatic and learn from what has been tested to death. Not everything needs to be tested. A designer's intuition is made of design principles
column3: design patterns
column4: affordances
column5: design history
column6: years of experience with the world with a mind focused on design
column7: and I think that can't be ignored. You just need to learn to know how much we can trust in that and try to detach yourself from the work you do
column8: so you can look at it and see whether or not it achieves the goal you're trying to accomplish.

column1: Adding to this point I think it's important to mention an essential hard skill required
column2: which is to be able to make something that can be tested.You can test static images but I think prototyping is becoming more and more an ""hygiene"" skill that any designer really needs to have.

column1: This one is also kind of obvious but I couldn't really leave it out. The notion that a good idea needs no explaining is a myth. Good design doesn't sell it self
column2: if you want to push it forward you need to know how to make a compelling case that will win over your audience.

column1: You don't need to be a salesman
column2: you just need to know how to present and explain your work. Understand who's your audience first
column3: so you can paint a picture in a way that they can understand. Show them how your design relates back to the original goal and how it serves the people that you're targeting.

column1: If you're a bit of an introvert (like me)
column2: this idea might sound a bit scary and uncomfortable
column3: but it's actually easier than talking to strangers
column4: at least I speak for myself. This is all about design
column5: sharing your line of thinking and making people buy into your idea. See it as your playground but do your homework
column6: prepare well and if needed rehearse until you have your story locked down.

column1: I wrote an article that touches this topic is the past too (#shamelessplugnumber2).
I hate to break it to you
column2: but if you don‚Äôt know how to communicate the work that you do
column3: then I can guarantee you'll have a tough time in moving your ideas forward
column4: or even in landing a job as designer.

column1: You just presented your design work
column2: brace yourself
column3: now comes the toughest part for the majority of designers... feedback
column4: more specifically negative feedback.

column1: It's all good if all you get is praise and cheers
column2: but when people start to take apart your design and find something you didn't consider
column3: that's when the shields come up and designers start become super defensive.

column1: Same happens during user tests
column2: when we see people not understanding what we've spent days refining. Then we put our shields up again and start trying to find excuses to cover up our failed hypotheses.There's not such a things as a dumb user
column3: there's only dumb designs.

column1: A great designer has thick skin and knows that critiquing the work is not critiquing the designer. They know this is the only way to look at your own work critically
column2: they also know how to take feedback and try to see whether or not it makes sense for the goal they're trying to accomplish.Last but not least
column3: they listen
column4: that's the only way you can improve and take your ideas to the next level.

column1: The ultimate mission for a designer is to make the world better through their work
column2: and to be able to actually achieve it they need to care about their user or audience more than they care about their ego. Why? Because very often the solution to someone else's problem will not align with your personal preference as a designer.

column1: This doesn't mean that you have to settle for a solution that is not at the level that you would like it to be. A great designer doesn't settle for good enough
column2: they strive to find what can be improved
column3: what can be the vision for the future and what problems might arise then. All this without forgetting who they are designing for.

column1: This mindset when it's ingrained
column2: spreads to the designer's experience with the real world. You can see this expressed by designers in two forms. One
column3: normally expressed by the majority
column4: it's all about instagram & tweet everything that is wrong with the world
column5: kinda easy to do once you know a bit about design.The other comes from a smaller set of people
column6: that will actually come up with ways to improve things
column7: rather than just pointing them out
column8: because that's what a great designer wants to really do
column9: to solve the problem
column10: not just complain about it.

column1: Working in the real world usually means a lot of limitations that will be in your way to deliver something great
column2: that's one of the reasons why you don't find in the app store most of the great animations you find on dribbble
column3: and this reality will tempt you to take the easy route and just deliver the very basic. This is where you can separate wheat from chaff
column4: a great designer will get around the limitations
column5: will question them
column6: and will still push for the best possible solution.

column1: This doesn't mean that they will ignore all the limitations
column2: it just means that they will try to get around them
column3: and invest some time in something extra
column4: let's call it a a trump card they can use
column5: next to a ""basic"" solution.From my experience
column6: having this trump card sometimes is enough to make some of the limitations being reevaluated. In other cases this might not make the limitations change
column7: but it can be enough to inspire someone else to come up with a way to get it done within the limitations.Remember
column8: you're job is not to come up with the solution but to find it. If you can inspire somebody else to come up with it
column9: then you did it right.

column1: Last but not least
column2: what I consider one of the most important skill in a designer is humility. Knowing that they're not the source of all of the the truth
column3: and that they only have to gain if they work and listen to others
column4: no matter their seniority
column5: roles or area of expertise.

column1: As a designer you are the expert when it comes to design and you should act like one
column2: I'm not saying you shouldn't. What I'm saying is that you should not automatically discard someone's feedback just because it's their personal opinion. Or just because it came from someone with no design background or even someone with less experience.

column1: The same goes the other way around though
column2: you should not take someone else's opinion as source of truth
column3: just because they're your boss or because they have more seniority than you. You need to weigh in the feedback against the goals the design is supposed to achieve and then conclude if you need to do something with it or not.

column1: Humility also means that you ask when you don't know something
column2: and you are not afraid of doing so. As a designer
column3: asking questions should be in your DNA and it's nothing to be ashamed of.

column1: Without asking questions is a bit difficult to get to the answers
column2: as already pointed out twice in this article
column3: a designer is not paid to know the answers
column4: they're paid to find them.

column1: Next to this 10 things
column2: of course it helps if you have your hard skills on point
column3: after all
column4: the reality is that you won't be able to cross all this 10 skills if you don't have the hard skills unlocked.

column1: With all that said
column2: I hope you find it useful and I'm curious to know... can you think of other traits that you consider essential that I forgot to mention? If so
column3: join the discussion in the comments bellow.

column1: The defining characteristics of this hot new trend sweeping across Silicon Valley are:
