The internet suffers from a lack of imagination
column2: so I asked my students to redesign it

column1: Photo by Pankaj Patel on Unsplash
Photo by Pankaj Patel on Unsplash
Today‚Äôs internet is bland. Everything looks the same: generic fonts
column2: no layouts to speak of
column3: interchangeable pages
column4: and an absence of expressive visual language. Even micro-typography is a mess.

column1: Web design today seems to be driven by technical and ideological constraints rather than creativity and ideas. Every page consists of containers in containers in containers; sometimes text
column2: sometimes images. Nothing is truly designed
column3: it‚Äôs simply assumed.

column1: Ironically
column2: today‚Äôs web technologies have enormous design capabilities. We have the capability to implement almost every conceivable idea and layout. We can create radical
column3: surprising
column4: and evocative websites. We can combine experimental typography with generative images and interactive experiences.

column1: And yet
column2: even websites for designers are based on containers in containers in containers. The most popular portals for creatives on the web ‚Äî Dribbble and Behance ‚Äî are so fundamentally boring they‚Äôre basically interchangeable. (See lead image.)

column1: How did this happen?

There are a few reasons. Technological frameworks like Content Management Systems (CMS) and blogging platforms like WordPress are based on templates. Web pages on these frameworks are not individually crafted but generated on the fly by piecing together various media types like images
column2: headlines
column3: body text
column4: and videos. Templates are not designs. Rather
column5: they are rules for combining related data types. Beyond the template
column6: these platforms typically offer users no way to influence a page‚Äôs visual appearance. What you see is what you poured into the template.

column1: In other words
column2: templates are content agnostic. And that is the problem.

column1: One of the fundamental principles of design is a deep and meaningful connection between form and content; form should both reflect and shape content. Separating them breaks this principle and creates generic content containers. In a design sense
column2: templates are meaningless; the form adds nothing to the content.

column1: There are plenty of other reasons for web design‚Äôs lack of creativity. Most of them are economic and pragmatic. For example
column2: it‚Äôs time-consuming to design individual pages. Considering the speed of online news and the frequency of new articles
column3: large websites simply do not have the resources to design a page from the ground up. Furthermore
column4: web design is still a matter of technical expertise: HTML
column5: JavaScript
column6: and CSS remain challenging tools for designers. There‚Äôs no web design equivalent to the direct and obliging workflows of desktop publishing applications.

column1: I suspect designers‚Äô creative and intellectual laziness is to blame
column2: too. In the age of mobile-first
column3: generic
column4: framework-driven development
column5: nobody seems to bother with the visual and contextual integrity of a web page.

column1: How can we tackle this challenge? What can expressive and avant-garde websites look like today?
Sometimes
column2: if you want to design the future
column3: you have to rediscover the past.

column1: I designed my first website about 23 years ago at the research and development group at the University of the Arts in Bremen
column2: Germany. Creating web pages was hot at the time. The web was young. Pages sparked my imagination.

column1: In the mid-nineties
column2: we were struggling with the constraints of HTML. We could only use web-safe fonts like Arial
column3: Times
column4: or Verdana. We had to use table layouts
column5: monospaced fonts
column6: or GIFs if we wanted to do anything exciting. HTML was purely content-driven initially
column7: and we had to work against the technology in order to design a page.

column1: At the same time
column2: experimental typography was exploding. From Jan Tschichold‚Äôs Die Neue Typographie in the twenties to the computer-driven layouts by April Greiman in the eighties
column3: designers challenged the status quo and tried to find a visual language that represented the ideas and revolutions of their eras. By the mid-nineties
column4: an unusual combination of technological and cultural advancements allowed for a very radical breed of graphic design. You could see it in the work of Irma Boom
column5: David Carson
column6: Paula Scher
column7: Neville Brody
column8: and many others.

column1: Compared to the visual explosion of the graphic design world
column2: however
column3: early web pages were still fairly lame. (The Web Design Museum documents this very well.)

column1: We wanted to do graphic design in the browser
column2: but nobody knew how ‚Äî or what mistakes could be made. There were no expectations of how a web page should look. There were no standards. No CMS (almost)
column3: no CSS
column4: no JS
column5: no video
column6: no animation.

column1: Fast forward to 2018
column2: and we can do everything in a browser. From massive-scale layouts to micro-typography
column3: animation
column4: and video. And what do we do with these incredible possibilities? Containers in containers in containers. Gigabytes of visually bland mobile-first pages contaminated with JavaScript. Generic templates that follow the same visual rules. If my younger self could have seen the state of web design 23 years later
column5: he would have been very disappointed.

column1: Web design‚Äôs problem is not the limits of technology but the limits of our imagination. We‚Äôve become far too obedient to visual conformity
column2: economic viability
column3: and assumed expectations.

column1: However
column2: every crisis creates an opportunity. Now is as good a time as any to challenge the internet‚Äôs visual conformity. Alas
column3: I am too old and too bourgeois to come up with a radical
column4: experimental
column5: and state-of-the-art approach to web design. But I can ask my students to do it.

column2: I gave a web design class at the Interface Design Programme in Potsdam
column3: Germany. Each team was asked to come up with a redesign for an existing website. The assignment was very clear: Treat the browser as a blank canvas and create expressive
column4: imaginative visual experiences. Use the technological potential of current web technologies as a channel for your creativity. Do not be constrained by questions of usability
column5: legibility
column6: and flexibility. Have an attitude. Disregard ErwartungskonformitaÃàt.

column1: I was very happy with the outcome of the class. (You can see all the results on this overview page.) Here are four projects that represent different approaches to the challenge.

Frederic and Jonas chose the web site of the Zentrum fuÃàr Kunst und Medien (ZKM) as a starting point for their experiments and explorations. A very fitting choice as the ZKM is one of the most prominent exhibition spaces for media art in Germany but ZKM‚Äôs website is fairly conventional. It‚Äôs functional but it lacks the avant-garde assertion that is conveyed by artwork in the exhibitions.
Frederic and Jonas‚Äôs aim was to design a concept
column2: a visual language
column3: and a technical setup for the ZKM site that represents the museum‚Äôs progressive approach. At the core of their concept is a generative design engine: Every time a page loads
column4: a new layout is created.

column1: View the redesign of the ZKM.
Streem is an art and street magazine. It is both a stage for upcoming artists and a platform for social issues. Streem includes work from illustration
column2: painting
column3: photography
column4: design
column5: writing
column6: and journalism. Daria
column7: Bela
column8: and Lucas combined these different influences and based their designs on a conceptual city structure. For their prototype
column9: they created four different neighborhoods that each represent a section of the magazine. Their approach combines strong illustrative styles with spatial typography in order to create a legible city.

column1: View the redesign of Streem.
Amelie and Fabian took a very structural approach. Instead of finding an adequate form for a specific story
column2: their aim was to dissolve a web page and break it down to semantic
column3: syntactical
column4: and statistical properties. Their idea was to demonstrate the fluidity and inherent malleability of HTML. They deconstructed Medium posts and created an environment that allows readers to break long blocks of text into experimental typographic space.

column1: View the redesign of Medium.
Fabian and Florian turned Hacker News into an interactive visualization. The social media site is a news aggregator
column2: focusing on computer science and information technology. Its design is bare-bones but it has complex functionality for voting and discussions. Fabian and Florian have taken the existing structure and turned it into a typographic space of timelines and networks. The visual presentation is based on the sequence and connections of news and comments. They also connected their design to the API of Hacker News
column3: so you can actually use it to read the site. View the redesign of Hacker News.

column1: David Carson once said
column2: ‚Äúdon‚Äôt confuse communication with legibility.‚Äù We should apply this advice to the current state of web design. Legibility
column3: usability
column4: responsiveness
column5: and especially accessibility are essential qualities of the modern web. But they should not define and limit its visual repertoire. If you equate stereotypes with usability
column6: you have understood neither visual design nor human-centered design.

column1: I
column2: for one
column3: would like to see more radical
column4: generative
column5: evocative
column6: thoughtful
column7: adequate
column8: content-specific
column9: and intelligent web design. I would like to rediscover the web as a space for design experiments. I would like to be surprised more often. I don‚Äôt know what the web will look in another 23 years
column10: but I certainly hope it doesn‚Äôt look like the web today.

column1: Let‚Äôs take as an example the Apple AirPods. We can all admit that they are the worst sounding earbuds for the price you pay. But when I look at how people interact with it
column2: I understand the real reason why they buy it. They do not make you think about why it is not working. You even don‚Äôt notice they have new technology.

column1: I look at how my mom interacts with them
column2: and she never asked me what technology is behind or how they work. She knows that whenever you open the case near your device
column3: it is going to connect. It is that easy.

column1: My favourite one. We
column2: designers
column3: love giving the users subtle effects and add beautiful delights. Right? Well
column4: what if I told you that your users don‚Äôt care about it? No matter how much they tell you they do
column5: they don‚Äôt. First time? Yes. Second? Ok. Third? Really
column6: how much do I have to see this until it‚Äôs enough?

column1: Why is this happening? Life is a much more stressful and demanding environment than an app‚Äôs delights and subtle effects. For example
column2: you are a father
column3: and your kid is screaming because he wants ice cream
column4: the dog is barking because somebody is calling at the front door and you are trying to book a quick train ticket that should leave in 40 minutes. In that specific moment
column5: people will not give a f* about your subtle cues. On the other side
column6: we should use them
column7: but not when it kills the user flow.

column1: Focus group is a small group of people that sit around at the table and discuss things. They talk about their opinions about the product
column2: past experiences
column3: their feelings and reactions to new concepts. Focus groups are great for determining what your audience wants.

column1: A usability test is about watching one person at a time trying to use something (your product in this case). In this case
column2: you ask them to perform specific actions to see if you need to fix something in your concepts. So focus groups is about listening and usability tests are about watching.

column1: All of us who design digital products have the moment when they say ‚Äî ‚ÄúI am a user too
column2: so I know what is good or bad.‚Äù And because of that
column3: we tend to have strong feelings about what we like and don‚Äôt.

column1: We enjoy using products with ______
column2: or we think that _____ is a big pain. And when we work on a team it tends to be hard to check those feelings at the door. The result is a room full of people with strong personal feelings on what it takes to design a great product. We tend to think that most of the users are like us.

column1: It is not productive and will not add any value if you ask questions such as: ‚ÄúDo people like drop-down menus?‚Äù. The right question to ask is: ‚ÄúDoes this drop-down menu
column2: with these words
column3: in this context
column4: on this page create a good experience for people who are likely to use the site?‚Äù

column1: The reason for that is if we focus on what people like
column2: we will lose focus and energy. Usability testing will erase any ‚Äúlikes‚Äù and show you what needs to be done.

column1: The point is that every question that pops into our head
column2: when using your product
column3: only adds up to the cognitive workload. It distracts our attention from ‚Äúwhy I am here‚Äù and ‚Äúwhat I need to do‚Äù. And as a rule
column4: people don‚Äôt enjoy solving puzzles when they merely want to know if that button is clickable or not.

column1: And every time you make a user tap on something that does not work
column2: or it looks like a button/link but it‚Äôs not
column3: it also adds up to the pile of questions. And this happens because who built the product did not care too much about the product.

column1: Product Management is the by-product of two exponential forces being exerted on a company.
Speed is an exponential force because with every period of time
column2: more change is occurring than in the last. Similarly with scale; every extra feature
column3: employee
column4: or user is adding more complexity to the system than the last.

column1: The reason product management as a career has been popularized in predominantly software companies
column2: is because software is inherently fast and scalable.

column1: The internet changed how software products were delivered to the market. Long gone are the days of annual releases and cardboard boxes on shelves. For the last two decades
column2: teams have been writing code
column3: deploying it
column4: and giving updates to all their customers instantaneously.

column1: Software development itself has a lowered bar of entry. Approachability of high level programming languages
column2: and the prevalence of open source libraries has super charged developers with unprecedented productivity. At the same time
column3: the infrastructure costs of building a functional product and deploying it has dropped to basically zero.

column1: In this way
column2: speed has two meanings: both how quickly you can get something to market with software development
column3: and (critically) how competition forces companies to go faster to survive.

column1: The reason why sub 50-person startups rarely have product managers is that the complexity is still manageable. The CEO and co-founders are still able to coordinate the company towards a focused problem and unleash the power of a scrappy startup upon it.
But as the company grows
column2: complexity emerges as more features are added
column3: customers become more diverse
column4: and the team grows. And that complexity grows exponentially.

column1: For example
column2: how many meetings do you think a 20-person startup can have?

column1: The answer shows why we suck at conceptualizing the exponential.
The problem the company solves grows in complexity as well. As teams solve high level problems
column2: they spawn hundreds of derivative problems
column3: all begging to be solved. The catch is the company can‚Äôt solve them all. Faced with hundreds of problems to solve
column4: choosing where to focus quickly becomes the most important decision a company makes.

column1: When you consider the simultaneous impacts of speed and scale on a company
column2: it‚Äôs easy to conceptualize how things will eventually derail without someone thinking holistically about the company. Ultimately
column3: that role is for the CEO
column4: but when they‚Äôve reached their multi-tasking limits
column5: who else can fill the void?

column1: Sure
column2: products need some oversight - got it. Why not just train everyone to be able to manage the product

column1: The short answer is that it‚Äôs harder than you think to manage a product
column2: and it takes years of experience to become capable. Here‚Äôs the long answer:

column1: The core competency of a product manager is truly understanding product development. That is
column2: how to identify which problem to solve and how to work with a team to solve it.

column1: Anyone who‚Äôs been through a few launches knows that despite the textbooks
column2: a linear product development process like the one below is a fairy tale.

column1: Even if you included feedback loops between the steps
column2: the idea of neat and tidy sequential steps
column3: where functional teams work together through a checklist is flawed. It simply does not fit into a world where technology is progressing exponentially.

column1: I view modern product development as a system of interconnected disciplines
column2: working in a network
column3: to deliver on a user‚Äôs desire. Product managers are the API that facilitates communication in this network.

column1: Each node represents a broad bucket of domain expertise
column2: each with enough depth that people dedicate careers to master them. This is an important quality of product development in a company where speed and scale have reached critical mass: there‚Äôs too much to know
column3: so only a team can effectively deliver a product.

column1: The process of product development is how this system moves through time.
Product managers shepherd this system from problem identification through to product launch
column2: ensuring that each node in the network is aware of the progression of the others
column3: and that users increasingly want what is being developed.

column1: Finally
column2: organizational scale brings with it multiple teams. And an effective product development system coordinates and focuses those teams towards the company‚Äôs vision.

column1: As the product development APIs
column2: product managers support company wide efficiency by ensuring no duplication of effort
column3: and sharing infrastructure to enable other teams to go faster.

column1: Product managers spend years to develop the skills required to be responsible for this system. It‚Äôs a multidisciplinary
column2: breadth over depth approach to learning.

column1: In my career
column2: I‚Äôve done all of: programming
column3: UI design
column4: UX research
column5: financial modelling
column6: business development
column7: support
column8: copy-writing
column9: accounting
column10: legal
column11: contract negotiation
column12: reporting
column15: FAQs

column1: I‚Äôve been an expert in none

column3: but never enough to be dangerous (in a good way). That‚Äôs the quintessential quality of a product manager‚Äôs skill set
column4: one that makes it hard for builder types to grok exactly what value they bring.

column1: A product manager‚Äôs multidisciplinary awareness enables them to communicate in whatever language is necessary to effectively deliver information across the team.
They‚Äôre also in the best position to assess the impact of change across the system. A recent conversation I had with Shopify‚Äôs CEO
column2: expressed this pretty succinctly to me.

column1: Exactly right.
In a world where speed is king and the world is changing exponentially
column2: having time to develop consensus before action is often a luxury. Teams need critical decisions made on a daily basis in order to maintain speed
column3: and those decisions have major trade offs and/or conflicting interests among stakeholders.

column1: Driving those decisions is no one else‚Äôs job but the product manager‚Äôs.
Whereas the work of engineers and designers are easier quantified

column3: the ambiguity around Product Management will remain for some time.

column1: One day

column1: If you‚Äôre a PM

column1: Case study: In the screenshots above
column2: Hostelworld could benefit from an on screen context filtering method. Only two options are being asked of the user to filter. I would use an approach similar to Foursquare‚Äôs above. Hostelworld could also benefit from a ‚ÄúReset‚Äù action to easily clear filters.

column1: Search results are tricky since the data returned varies heavily based on the input of the user. What approach will be a good solution depends on the amount of verticals and total amount of data.

column1: Unlike filtering

column1: When to use: Sorting makes sense when it is hard for users to point out extremes (e.g. the lowest price) by themselves. On mobile

column1: Case study: While TripAdvisor and Kayak use the slide-over approach

column1: It‚Äôs Bruce McCarthy‚Äôs idea. Bruce is a product manager‚Äôs product manager and one of the smartest people I know. He told this idea to me. And now I‚Äôm telling it to you.
Bruce and I were talking about product roadmaps
column2: which describe features the team commits to ship over the next few releases. For most organizations
column3: everything revolves around the roadmap.

column1: Marketing uses the roadmap to plan the stories they‚Äôll tell to entice new customers (and get existing ones to upgrade). Customer support uses it to ensure reps are trained to help with new features. And
column2: of course
column3: product development uses it to allocate resources and to speed future development.

column1: It was while we were discussing roadmaps that Bruce shattered my world with a single word: Themes. Themes are an alternative for features. Instead of promising to build a specific feature
column2: the team commits to solving a specific customer problem.

column1: A typical roadmap feature might be a data export capability to Salesforce. Customers may have even asked for this feature
column2: saying they‚Äôd buy a ton more licenses if the product made it easy to move the data.

column1: But with Bruce‚Äôs Themes
column2: the product strategy team would research why customers want to move their data to Salesforce. How does it make their life easier? Might it be even better if the data could move in both directions? How up to date does the Salesforce data need to be? What happens after it gets into Salesforce? What‚Äôs the bigger problem that needs solving?

column1: That last question is quite interesting. By understanding how having the data exported to Salesforce contributes to solving a bigger problem
column2: the team may uncover interesting alternative solutions. Maybe Salesforce is just an intermediate stop along the way to becoming something bigger? If so
column3: maybe there‚Äôs functionality the team could add to the product (or even better
column4: might already exist but is currently hard to find)?

column1: Bruce says Themes help teams stay focused without prematurely committing to a solution that may not be the best idea later on. This is particularly important for roadmaps that go out 2
column3: or more years into a fuzzy future. The viability of a feature may shift dramatically
column4: while the nature of an important customer problem will likely remain the same. As each part of the roadmap gets closer
column5: the customer problems often become clearer
column6: making solutions easier to find.

column1: We‚Äôve found this to dovetail nicely with another phenomenon we‚Äôve observed: When a team has a clear definition of a problem
column2: solutions are often easy. Usually
column3: the biggest source of trouble with defining solutions comes from unclear problem definitions. By making the problem the centerpiece of the strategy
column4: more resources will be available to help with definition.

column1: The sheer brilliance of Bruce‚Äôs idea is how
column2: with a single gesture
column3: learning everything about the customers becomes the most important focus of creating the product strategy. When companies talk about features
column4: they are saying
column5: ‚ÄúLook at us. Look at what we can do.‚Äù When companies talk about the problems of the customers
column6: they are saying
column7: ‚ÄúLook at what you‚Äôre dealing with. Look at how we want to help.‚Äù

column1: Whereas the company used to want to have dozens (or in some cases
column2: hundreds) of features in each release
column3: customer problems can be smaller in number. If it‚Äôs a big problem that lots of customers are dealing with

column1: Now
column2: after the team starts to solve the problem
column3: it might mean they make a bunch of changes throughout the product. But each of those changes goes straight to explaining its role in solving that specific customer problem.

column1: This becomes an important razor for deciding what takes priority. Pick 2 or 3 important customer problems for this release. Any change to the product that doesn‚Äôt help solve one of those problems is eliminated from the backlog.

column2: which means time to delivery will often be faster.

column1: You can‚Äôt fill a roadmap with customer problems if you don‚Äôt know anything about your customers. By moving away from the invention of features (which can be done independent of whether customers need what you‚Äôre building)
column2: the roadmap technique requires deep and thorough customer insights.

column1: The best way to acquire these insights is through solid

column1: User research changes its status

column2: they won‚Äôt start by looking at what the competition has. Any competition still working with a feature focus will miss opportunities.

column1: Almost always
column2: important customer problems aren‚Äôt being solved by any companies in the competitive landscape. This is because everybody is constantly trying to out-do each other
column3: not paying attention to customers at all.

column1: The first company to move to defining their roadmap as solvable customer problems gets a jump on the competition. They provide innovative solutions just by solving pressing problems
column2: getting an immediate jump on what the competitors incorrectly think is important.

column1: Instead of doing a competitive analysis
column2: the strategy team is now talking about what‚Äôs missing in the marketplace. They‚Äôre completely focused on what nobody else is doing. That‚Äôs a solid competitive advantage.

column1: Marketing groups face a chore when it‚Äôs time to tell the world about the next major release of their product. They have to gather up all the features and synthesize a narrative that makes people want all those things. What is the big story about how these independently designed and developed features make the customer‚Äôs life better?
Bruce‚Äôs Themes replaces that chore by handing the narrative to the marketing group on a silver platter. Here are the problems we set out to solve and here‚Äôs how we solved them.
Every element of the new release tells the story marketing needs to tell. (And if the marketing group was smart
column2: they were part of the strategy team in the first place
column3: so they saw this coming their way all along.)

column1: Part of solving a customer‚Äôs problem is making sure you don‚Äôt make it worse. By having the problem as the starting point for the project
column2: the development team has an instant baseline to measure against.

column1: Given a customer problem
column2: the team will come up with multiple solutions. Picking the best solution becomes a trade off of effort against the improvement they can deliver. Determining these factors is easier when they start with a clearly defined problem. Without a commitment to specific solutions
column3: the team has flexibility.

column1: One consistent problem with the feature approach comes when the team tries to wedge more features into an already crowded and complex product. They run the chance of making the product even more difficult to use because the new features don‚Äôt dovetail nicely with what already exists.
With Bruce‚Äôs Themes approach
column2: the team now has the power to say ‚Äúno‚Äù to any solution that makes the problem worse. That includes making the product more complex. The base requirement of making the customer‚Äôs life easier forces a more cohesive
column3: simpler design to emerge.

column1: Organizations who have grown up in a feature mindset will struggle with the shift to customer problems. The primal desire to ask
column2: ‚ÄúBut what feature are we shipping?‚Äù will not go down without a fight. Vigilance among the product strategy team (and air cover from senior management) will be a basic requirement to make Themes work.

column1: However
column2: after the team gets the hang of thinking in terms of solving customers‚Äô problems
column3: and reaps all the benefits that come from that
column4: it‚Äôs likely to become the norm. The wins felt by every part of the organization as customers are put into the center of the strategy process will easily make them a driving force in the market.

column1: The defining characteristics of this hot new trend sweeping across Silicon Valley are:

column1: As I mentioned earlier

Design also covers how users engage with a product
column2: whether it‚Äôs a website or app. It‚Äôs like a conversation. Navigation is a conversation. Because it doesn‚Äôt matter how good your site or app is if users can‚Äôt find their way around it.

column1: Steven Hoober in his research of mobile devices usage
column2: found that 49% of people rely on a one thumb to get things done on their phones. In figure below
column3: the diagram that appears on the mobile phones‚Äô screens are approximate reach charts
column4: in which the colors indicate what areas a user can reach with the thumb to interact with the screen. Green indicates the area a user can reach easily; yellow
column5: an area that requires a stretch; and red
column6: an area that requires users to shift the way in which they‚Äôre holding a device.

column1: It‚Äôs important to place top-level and frequently-used actions at the bottom of the screen
column2: because they are comfortably reached with one-thumb interactions.

column1: Many apps follow this rule and use the bottom navigation (a.k.a. tab bar) for the most important app‚Äôs features. Facebook makes main pieces of core functionality available with one tap
column2: allows rapid switching between features.

column1: Navigation is generally the vehicle that takes users where they want to go. And bottom navigation should be used for the top-level destinations of similar importance. These destinations requiring direct access from anywhere in the app.
Good bottom navigation design follows these three rules.
Use three to five top-level destinations in bottom navigation. If there are fewer than three destinations
column2: consider using tabs instead.

column1: Avoid using more than five destinations in bottom navigation as tap targets will be situated too close to one another. Putting too many tabs in a tab bar can make it physically difficult for people to tap the one they want. And with each additional tab you display
column2: you increase the complexity of your app.

column1: If your top-level navigation has more than five destinations
column2: provide access to destinations not covered in bottom navigation through alternative locations.

column1: In 1956 there was a paper written that became one of the most highly cited papers in psychology. Titled
column2: The Magical Number Seven
column3: Plus or Minus Two: Some Limits on Our Capacity for Processing Information
column4: it was published in 1956 by the cognitive psychologist George A. Miller of Princeton University‚Äôs Department of Psychology in Psychological Review. The crux of the paper suggests that the number of perceptual ‚Äòchunks‚Äô an average human can hold in working memory (a component of short-term memory) is 7 ¬± 2. This is frequently referred to as Miller‚Äôs law. Here is a summary of the article
column5: sourced from wikipedia:

column1: Moreover
column2: the human mind can remember ~7 bits of information when completing a task that requires cognitive effort. This is critical
column3: because humans are constantly performing tasks
column4: and trying to juggle various stimuli in the mind when doing so. One of the key concepts behind Miller‚Äôs Law is ‚Äòchunking‚Äô
column5: which basically means assembling various bits of information into a cohesive gestalt. For example
column6: the word ¬∑ p e n c i l ¬∑ is actually a ‚Äòchunk‚Äô of letters
column7: organized into a perceptual gestalt. If the letters were rearranged ¬∑ c n l i p e ¬∑ it would be six separate chunks of information. Chunking is a critical element of information organization
column8: and is the basis for our UX and organizational rule.

column1: Always organize elements of information in categories no larger than 9
column2: but preferably ~5 chunks.

column1: The more chunks of information you add to an ‚Äòinterface‚Äô
column2: the more difficult it becomes to ‚Äòwork‚Äô
column3: using the information at hand. This is especially critical for first time users
column4: because they haven‚Äôt had the ‚Äòpractice‚Äô needed to encode the interface into long term memory
column5: or
column6: for the behaviour to become habitual. I constantly see this rule being broken by giants like Facebook
column7: Google
column8: and Wordpress. Don‚Äôt even get me started on automobile interface design. The ~5 bit chunk rule also compliments minimalism as a rigorous design philosophy. To expound
column9: due to the limitations of working memory
column10: as a product becomes more feature-full it inevitably becomes more difficult to use
column11: because the user has to manage more information while operating the product. This makes good information design so critical.

column1: Millers Law also highlights the importance of foresight and proper planning in the design process
column2: because as you add more features to a product ‚Äî your interface must be able to accommodate those new features without breaking the visual foundation of what you built. Rebuilding a foundation takes immense time and resources.

column1: Another perceptual phenomenon observed in relation to Miller‚Äôs Law is known as the primacy
column2: and recency effect. These terms are used respectively to describe how we remember items sensed at the beginning and end of an experience
column3: more than ones in the middle. For example
column4: if I were to show you a list of words
column5: you would more likely remember the words at the beginning of the list
column6: and the end. This is also known as the serial position effect. From wikipedia:

column1: This observation raises huge questions in business and design. If people remember more at the beginning and end of an experience
column2: how do we enhance the positives
column3: and mitigate the negatives at these respective times? When does an experience truly begin and end? Should we be organizing more important elements at the beginning and end of lists due to their increased retention? These are all valid questions that UX designers and executives should ask when inventing or developing their product.

column1: Millers Law can be applied to any aspect of your life that involves performing a mildly complex task. By reducing the amount of elements in your reach/access ‚Äî and keeping them organized by relevant chunks not exceeding 9 bits
column2: your brain will be able to remember exactly where things are so you can access its functionality. When lists of items grow too large
column3: they become very difficult to mentally map them
column4: requiring the user to do more cumbersome searching.

column1: The adherence to Miller‚Äôs Law is especially relevant in the light of lean methodologies and recent trends in tech and UX. Users want and need a trial before they purchase something ‚Äî it‚Äôs that simple. If they don‚Äôt experience the value within the first day or week of using it ‚Äî they won‚Äôt buy. Since new users do not have lengthly time to learn where everything is ‚Äî information design needs to be planned and well thought out before development happens.
We live in a world with an exponentially increasing amount of information. By not organizing it properly
column2: or eliminating some completely
column3: it ultimately degrades our ability to complete critical tasks for the purposes of survival (navigation/gaining income). That is why it‚Äôs so useful to omit items
column4: products
column5: and services from your life that aren‚Äôt giving a quality return on investment. This falls in line with the Pareto principle
column6: the idea that 80% of your outcomes comes from 20% of your investments. Are you juggling too many tasks per day to be efficient? Is your team using too many tools to collaborate? Do you have too many members on your team? Are you overloading your new employees with information
column7: leading to confusion?

column1: Millers law teaches us that humans have a finite amount of information they can process
column2: and that information overload will lead to distraction that negatively affects performance. Companies should look for ways to organize information in a way that is much more digestible for their customers and employees. This could be by eliminating tools or applications that are producing cognitive overload
column3: reducing the amount of members on a team
column4: or even organizing your departments based on our knowledge of working memory.

column1: This is especially true in new science of the concept of flow
column2: made famous by psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi. Flow is a word Mihaly coined to describe a state of concentration or ‚Äòabsorption‚Äô with a specific task that humans ultimately find rewarding
column3: pleasurable
column4: and fulfilling. He describes it as an optimal state where we perform at our best and truly live ‚Äòin the moment‚Äô. One sure way to kill flow is by increasing distractions in the workplace. So
column5: do you think that by giving your employees more tools
column6: that it actually enhances performance? Miller‚Äôs Law teaches us time and time again this is not the case. When it comes to completing tasks

column1: Adaptive icons are 108dp*108dp in size but are masked to a maximum of 72dp*72dp. Different devices can supply different masks which must be convex in shape and may reach a minimum of 33dp from the center in places.
Because of the minimum reach of the mask

column1: Keyline shapes are the foundation of the icon grid helping your icon‚Äôs visual proportions be consistent with other apps‚Äô icons . The keyline shapes are:
See the templates included at the end of this article.

Adaptive icons are actually made up of two layers; a foreground and a background. Both layers are 108dp*108dp; the background must be fully opaque while the foreground may include transparency. These layers are stacked on top of each other.

Providing elements in two separate layers which are larger than the displayed (i.e. masked) size creates the opportunity for interesting visual treatments and animations. Exactly what effects may be applied and when is still something of an open question; it is up to device and launcher makers to decide. Here are some simple examples you could imagine: parallax or pulsing by independently translating or scaling each layer before applying the mask.
As the 108dp*108dp icons are masked up to 72dp*72dp
column2: the outer 18dp on each side can be considered the ‚Äúextra‚Äù content
column3: only revealed during motion.

column1: The material design guidelines for creating product icons still very much apply. Specifically the icon anatomy
column2: shadows and finish remain
column3: but you can now place elements in either the foreground or background layers yielding different effects.

column1: Now I‚Äôm sure that many icons will be well served by placing their brand mark in the foreground on a solid colored background and calling it a day. This will ensure that your icon fits in well on the device. What excites me is how we as a community will explore these new constraints and find interesting
column2: playful and innovative ways to make delightful icons. Here are a few things to keep in mind and a few ideas to potentially explore.

column1: Due to the dynamic nature of adaptive icons
column2: you cannot know the exact mask shape that will be applied. For that reason it‚Äôs best to place any critical elements like your brand mark inside the safe-zone and to stay away from the mask edges.

column1: Placing some elements which might appear to be foreground
column2: actually in the background means that they will move independently. For example the calculator app places most elements in the foreground
column3: but the equals button on the accent color block in the background:

column1: This creates interesting opportunities for motion where you visually anchor on the bright color block
column2: but it moves less than the foreground elements
column3: creating a sensation of depth.

column1: I think that there may be interesting opportunities for placing masking elements in the foreground ‚Äî that is solid elements with areas cut out. Consider a possible icon for the Google Play Store
column2: this might be constructed in an ‚Äòobvious‚Äô manner
column3: that is placing the colored triangle in the foreground atop a white background.

column1: Instead of doing this
column2: we might use a colorful background and a white foreground with the triangle subtracted to produce the same static output:

column1: This setup would allow the colors ‚Äòpeeking through‚Äô to move independently of the mask revealing different parts of the background when translated or scaled.

The interaction of lighting effects and shadows placed in separate layers can have interesting results. For example using the long-shadow technique on the foreground element can have a playful interaction as it moves within the masked area. Similarly lighting effects can be placed in the foreground layer rather than being baked into the background. For example
column2: a ‚Äòfinish‚Äô layer can be placed in the foreground to emulate a light source. Placing this in the foreground means that it will play over the background layer when under motion
column3: moving at a different rate to it.

column1: Be careful not to create an effect that doesn‚Äôt make sense e.g. a shadow detaching from a foreground element or moving behind a background element. Also remember that many icons are likely to be seen together so be conservative with bespoke lighting effects and stick close to the material guidelines.
You could place elements in the background layer which are completely obscured by the foreground layer and only revealed under motion.

column7: it saves screen real estate. Since then designers have readily adopted the modal window and some have taken it to the extreme. Modals have become the today‚Äôs version of the dreaded popup window. Users find modals annoying and have been trained to instinctively and automatically dismiss these windows.

column1: A modal window is an element that sits on top of an application‚Äôs main window. It creates a mode that disables the main window but keeps it visible with the modal window as a child window in front of it. Users must interact with the modal window before they can return to the parent application. ‚Äî Wikipedia
You may consider using a modal window when you need to:
Use when you want to interrupt a user‚Äôs current task to catch the user‚Äôs full attention to something more important.
Use when you want to get information from the user. Ex. sign up or login form.
Use when you want to show additional information without losing the context of the parent page. Ex. showing larger images or videos.
Use when you want to show information that is not directly related to the parent page or other options that are ‚Äúindependent‚Äù from other pages. Ex. notifications.
Poorly implemented overlays can hinder task completion. To ensure your modal doesn‚Äôt get in the way make sure to include the following:
Give users a way to escape by giving them a way to close the modal. This can be achieved in the following ways:
Give context to the user with the modal title. This allows the user to know where he/she is because they haven‚Äôt left the original page.
Button labels should have actionable
column2: understandable names. This applies to a button in any instance. For modals
column3: a ‚Äòclose‚Äô button should be present in the form of a labeled ‚Äòclose‚Äô button or an ‚Äòx‚Äô.

column1: A modal window should not be too big or too small
column2: you want it juuuuust right. The goal is to keep context
column3: therefore a modal should not take up the whole screen view. Content should fit the modal. If a scrollbar is needed
column4: you may consider creating a new page instead.

column1: When you open a modal use a lightbox effect (darken the background). This draws attention to the modal and indicates that the user cannot interact with the parent page.
Don‚Äôt surprise users by popping up a modal. Let a user‚Äôs action
column2: such as a button click
column3: following a link or selecting an option
column4: trigger the modal. Uninvited modals may surprise the user and result in a quick dismissal of the window.

column1: Modals and mobile devices usually don‚Äôt play well together. Viewing the content is difficult because modals either are too large
column2: taking up too much screen space or too small. Add in elements like the device keyboard and nested scrollbars; users are left pinching and zooming trying to catch the fields of a modal window. There are better alternatives for modals and shouldn‚Äôt be used on mobile devices.

column1: When creating modals remember to add in keyboard accessibility. Consider the following:

column2: I‚Äôve seen this logo before. Why does it seem so familiar to me?‚Äù

column1: After a few years in Design you eventually find out that everything has been done before. I figured out where some popular logos might have come from. When does copying become stealing? Is it even that bad?

Design solves problems while adding uniqueness to the end result. That is called creativity. We are bombarded with visual messages all day. Maybe you saw a great design featured on some blog. A few months later you come up with something similar. You might just not remember why you came up with such a solution. When creating
column2: we are recycling impressions all the time without realizing it.

column1: Some websites like calling out brands for ripping-off or stealing a design. In many cases there is no differentiation between stealing and copying. I‚Äôd like to state how I distinguish between these two terms.

Stealing means replicating a design end-to-end. The company wants to profit from the attributes the design communicates. Stealing is sewing a Nike logo on sweaters to sell them for double the price. Design is an approach that is tailored to each instance it is applied
column2: thereby making it hard to imitate. Stealing often involves a discrepancy between communicated message and content. Self-image and public image are not congruent. Thats why premium brands can‚Äôt be imitated easily. Stealing is an insidious attempt at not being discovered.

column1: Copying is different. It‚Äôs the way we learn. Think about how babies grow-up and learn new skills: they imitate their parents. Thousands of years ago some iconic Roman sculptures were created by casting exact copies of Greek statues. By copying we are acknowlodging the past and building upon existing knowledge. I taught myself how to program by copying code from other websites and playing around with it. Copying means being influenced by an idea and applying it in a different form and context. It pays tribute to the originator and always challenges the appropriate use for itself.
Take the concept of Flat Design. It‚Äôs a style that Googles Material Design leveraged
column2: but they didn‚Äôt come up with it. It‚Äôs difficult to find out who started something. Even if you do find the originator
column3: how do you know they weren‚Äôt influenced by something they weren‚Äôt aware of? Maybe they‚Äôre only hiding their source? As you see
column4: we‚Äôre quickly getting into a chicken-egg-debate here.

column1: Semantics make the world better navigable for us. We take commonly understood pictograms and alter them to a brand language. Semantics mean you recognize a symbol of which you have learnt the meaning. Think about the fire exit sign
column2: the hamburger icon or the power switch symbol. By embracing this we make our work usable for a wide variety of people. No one would call this stealing. Still
column3: it is copying.

column1: While reflecting on this I changed the way I used the words copying and stealing. Copying offers opportunity to learn while stealing avoids the hard work. Stealing implicits that all Design challenges deserve the same solution. We don‚Äôt have to act like we‚Äôre reinventing the wheel every time‚Äî even if we might sell it that way sometimes. There are a lot of replicable parts in Design. You must listen and still strive for originality
column2: otherwise you will end up with dissatisfied clients
column3: a bad reputation and zero personal growth.

column1: Have you ever caught yourself copying an idea? Were you the one that was stolen from? How did you deal with that? Is anything original anymore? I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts on this.

column1: As with a lot of aspects of typography

column1: Roman scribes would write in cursive so as to increase the speed of their transcription
column2: often combining letters into one form to save time while also increasing legibility
column3: where certain characters overlap in a visually discordant manner ‚Äî this was the birth of the ligature. The ampersand is simply a ligature of the letters E and T (et being the latin word for and).

column2: schools throughout England had started to use the phrase per se (essentially meaning by itself) when spelling out words. This was specifically useful when encountering words that consist of only a single letter (A
column3: I and originally O). As an example
column4: in order to spell the phrase ‚ÄúI invite you‚Äù
column5: children would say:

column1: At the same time

column4: when reciting the alphabet

The internet suffers from a lack of imagination
column2: so I asked my students to redesign it

column1: Photo by Pankaj Patel on Unsplash
Photo by Pankaj Patel on Unsplash
Today‚Äôs internet is bland. Everything looks the same: generic fonts
column2: no layouts to speak of
column3: interchangeable pages
column4: and an absence of expressive visual language. Even micro-typography is a mess.

column1: Web design today seems to be driven by technical and ideological constraints rather than creativity and ideas. Every page consists of containers in containers in containers; sometimes text
column2: sometimes images. Nothing is truly designed
column3: it‚Äôs simply assumed.

column1: Ironically
column2: today‚Äôs web technologies have enormous design capabilities. We have the capability to implement almost every conceivable idea and layout. We can create radical
column3: surprising
column4: and evocative websites. We can combine experimental typography with generative images and interactive experiences.

column1: And yet
column2: even websites for designers are based on containers in containers in containers. The most popular portals for creatives on the web ‚Äî Dribbble and Behance ‚Äî are so fundamentally boring they‚Äôre basically interchangeable. (See lead image.)

column1: How did this happen?

There are a few reasons. Technological frameworks like Content Management Systems (CMS) and blogging platforms like WordPress are based on templates. Web pages on these frameworks are not individually crafted but generated on the fly by piecing together various media types like images
column2: headlines
column3: body text
column4: and videos. Templates are not designs. Rather
column5: they are rules for combining related data types. Beyond the template
column6: these platforms typically offer users no way to influence a page‚Äôs visual appearance. What you see is what you poured into the template.

column1: In other words
column2: templates are content agnostic. And that is the problem.

column1: One of the fundamental principles of design is a deep and meaningful connection between form and content; form should both reflect and shape content. Separating them breaks this principle and creates generic content containers. In a design sense
column2: templates are meaningless; the form adds nothing to the content.

column1: There are plenty of other reasons for web design‚Äôs lack of creativity. Most of them are economic and pragmatic. For example
column2: it‚Äôs time-consuming to design individual pages. Considering the speed of online news and the frequency of new articles
column3: large websites simply do not have the resources to design a page from the ground up. Furthermore
column4: web design is still a matter of technical expertise: HTML
column5: JavaScript
column6: and CSS remain challenging tools for designers. There‚Äôs no web design equivalent to the direct and obliging workflows of desktop publishing applications.

column1: I suspect designers‚Äô creative and intellectual laziness is to blame
column2: too. In the age of mobile-first
column3: generic
column4: framework-driven development
column5: nobody seems to bother with the visual and contextual integrity of a web page.

column1: How can we tackle this challenge? What can expressive and avant-garde websites look like today?
Sometimes
column2: if you want to design the future
column3: you have to rediscover the past.

column1: I designed my first website about 23 years ago at the research and development group at the University of the Arts in Bremen
column2: Germany. Creating web pages was hot at the time. The web was young. Pages sparked my imagination.

column1: In the mid-nineties
column2: we were struggling with the constraints of HTML. We could only use web-safe fonts like Arial
column3: Times
column4: or Verdana. We had to use table layouts
column5: monospaced fonts
column6: or GIFs if we wanted to do anything exciting. HTML was purely content-driven initially
column7: and we had to work against the technology in order to design a page.

column1: At the same time
column2: experimental typography was exploding. From Jan Tschichold‚Äôs Die Neue Typographie in the twenties to the computer-driven layouts by April Greiman in the eighties
column3: designers challenged the status quo and tried to find a visual language that represented the ideas and revolutions of their eras. By the mid-nineties
column4: an unusual combination of technological and cultural advancements allowed for a very radical breed of graphic design. You could see it in the work of Irma Boom
column5: David Carson
column6: Paula Scher
column7: Neville Brody
column8: and many others.

column1: Compared to the visual explosion of the graphic design world
column2: however
column3: early web pages were still fairly lame. (The Web Design Museum documents this very well.)

column1: We wanted to do graphic design in the browser
column2: but nobody knew how ‚Äî or what mistakes could be made. There were no expectations of how a web page should look. There were no standards. No CMS (almost)
column3: no CSS
column4: no JS
column5: no video
column6: no animation.

column1: Fast forward to 2018
column2: and we can do everything in a browser. From massive-scale layouts to micro-typography
column3: animation
column4: and video. And what do we do with these incredible possibilities? Containers in containers in containers. Gigabytes of visually bland mobile-first pages contaminated with JavaScript. Generic templates that follow the same visual rules. If my younger self could have seen the state of web design 23 years later
column5: he would have been very disappointed.

column1: Web design‚Äôs problem is not the limits of technology but the limits of our imagination. We‚Äôve become far too obedient to visual conformity
column2: economic viability
column3: and assumed expectations.

column1: However
column2: every crisis creates an opportunity. Now is as good a time as any to challenge the internet‚Äôs visual conformity. Alas
column3: I am too old and too bourgeois to come up with a radical
column4: experimental
column5: and state-of-the-art approach to web design. But I can ask my students to do it.

column2: I gave a web design class at the Interface Design Programme in Potsdam
column3: Germany. Each team was asked to come up with a redesign for an existing website. The assignment was very clear: Treat the browser as a blank canvas and create expressive
column4: imaginative visual experiences. Use the technological potential of current web technologies as a channel for your creativity. Do not be constrained by questions of usability
column5: legibility
column6: and flexibility. Have an attitude. Disregard ErwartungskonformitaÃàt.

column1: I was very happy with the outcome of the class. (You can see all the results on this overview page.) Here are four projects that represent different approaches to the challenge.

Frederic and Jonas chose the web site of the Zentrum fuÃàr Kunst und Medien (ZKM) as a starting point for their experiments and explorations. A very fitting choice as the ZKM is one of the most prominent exhibition spaces for media art in Germany but ZKM‚Äôs website is fairly conventional. It‚Äôs functional but it lacks the avant-garde assertion that is conveyed by artwork in the exhibitions.
Frederic and Jonas‚Äôs aim was to design a concept
column2: a visual language
column3: and a technical setup for the ZKM site that represents the museum‚Äôs progressive approach. At the core of their concept is a generative design engine: Every time a page loads
column4: a new layout is created.

column1: View the redesign of the ZKM.
Streem is an art and street magazine. It is both a stage for upcoming artists and a platform for social issues. Streem includes work from illustration
column2: painting
column3: photography
column4: design
column5: writing
column6: and journalism. Daria
column7: Bela
column8: and Lucas combined these different influences and based their designs on a conceptual city structure. For their prototype
column9: they created four different neighborhoods that each represent a section of the magazine. Their approach combines strong illustrative styles with spatial typography in order to create a legible city.

column1: View the redesign of Streem.
Amelie and Fabian took a very structural approach. Instead of finding an adequate form for a specific story
column2: their aim was to dissolve a web page and break it down to semantic
column3: syntactical
column4: and statistical properties. Their idea was to demonstrate the fluidity and inherent malleability of HTML. They deconstructed Medium posts and created an environment that allows readers to break long blocks of text into experimental typographic space.

column1: View the redesign of Medium.
Fabian and Florian turned Hacker News into an interactive visualization. The social media site is a news aggregator
column2: focusing on computer science and information technology. Its design is bare-bones but it has complex functionality for voting and discussions. Fabian and Florian have taken the existing structure and turned it into a typographic space of timelines and networks. The visual presentation is based on the sequence and connections of news and comments. They also connected their design to the API of Hacker News
column3: so you can actually use it to read the site. View the redesign of Hacker News.

column1: David Carson once said
column2: ‚Äúdon‚Äôt confuse communication with legibility.‚Äù We should apply this advice to the current state of web design. Legibility
column3: usability
column4: responsiveness
column5: and especially accessibility are essential qualities of the modern web. But they should not define and limit its visual repertoire. If you equate stereotypes with usability
column6: you have understood neither visual design nor human-centered design.

column1: I
column2: for one
column3: would like to see more radical
column4: generative
column5: evocative
column6: thoughtful
column7: adequate
column8: content-specific
column9: and intelligent web design. I would like to rediscover the web as a space for design experiments. I would like to be surprised more often. I don‚Äôt know what the web will look in another 23 years
column10: but I certainly hope it doesn‚Äôt look like the web today.

column1: We forget that human mind changes very slow
column2: and the knowledge you have about human behaviour will not go old for at least 50 years or so. To make it easy for you
column3: we need to keep consistent with a couple of principles that will remind us of how to design great products. We should be told at least once a month about these small principles until we live and breathe good design.

column1: Steve Krug laid out some useful principles back in 2000
column2: after the dot-com boom which are still valuable and relevant nowadays. Even after his revised version
column3: nothing changed. Yes
column4: you will tell me that the looks are more modern and the websites are more organised and advanced (no more flash!). But what I mean about that is ‚Äî nothing has changed in human behaviour. We will always want the principle ‚Äúdon‚Äôt make me think‚Äù applied to any type of product we interact (whether it is a microwave
column5: tv
column6: smartphone or car).

column1: The reason for that is ‚Äî we are on a mission
column2: and we only look for the thing that interests us. For example
column3: I rarely remember myself going through all the text on the homepage of a product website. Why? Because most of the web users are trying to get something done
column4: and done quickly. We do not have time to read more than necessary. And we still put a lot of text because we think people need to know that. Or as some designers say: ‚Äúit adds to the experience‚Äù.

column1: Another important aspect that will help scanning a page is offering a proper visual hierarchy. We have to make it clear that the appearance on a page portrays the relationship between elements. So there are a couple of principles for that:
We believe that people want something new and more. But we forget that there are so many applications on the market that each demands our time. Each of them has different interactions
column2: and we need to learn each one of them. And our mind blows up when: ‚ÄúOh man
column3: another app to learn?!‚Äù.

column1: We as designers
column2: when asked to design something new
column3: have a temptation to try and reinvent the wheel. Because doing something like everyone else seems somehow wrong. We have been hired to do something different. Not to mention that the industry rarely offers awards and praises for designing something that has ‚Äúthe best use of conventions‚Äù.

column1: Our job is to make stuff clear and obvious. If obvious is not an option
column2: then at least self-explanatory. The main thing you need to know about instructions is that nobody is going to read them. We should aim for removing the instructions to make everything self-explanatory. But when they are necessary
column3: cut as much as possible. (but
column4: really
column5: nobody is going to read them). We muddle through.

column1: Take IKEA as an example. If you gave an average person to assemble a wardrobe from IKEA
column2: I am sure that he will assemble it right most of the times. Why? It is
column3: most of the cases
column4: apparent on how it should be assembled if we have a clear picture in front of us. But even in instances where they look at the instructions
column5: there are no words ‚Äî only images.

column1: For most of the people
column2: it is not essential to know or understand how your product works. Not because they are not intelligent
column3: but merely because they do not care. So once they nail down the use of your product
column4: they will rarely switch to something else.

column1: Let‚Äôs take as an example the Apple AirPods. We can all admit that they are the worst sounding earbuds for the price you pay. But when I look at how people interact with it
column2: I understand the real reason why they buy it. They do not make you think about why it is not working. You even don‚Äôt notice they have new technology.

column1: I look at how my mom interacts with them
column2: and she never asked me what technology is behind or how they work. She knows that whenever you open the case near your device
column3: it is going to connect. It is that easy.

column1: My favourite one. We
column2: designers
column3: love giving the users subtle effects and add beautiful delights. Right? Well
column4: what if I told you that your users don‚Äôt care about it? No matter how much they tell you they do
column5: they don‚Äôt. First time? Yes. Second? Ok. Third? Really
column6: how much do I have to see this until it‚Äôs enough?

column1: Why is this happening? Life is a much more stressful and demanding environment than an app‚Äôs delights and subtle effects. For example
column2: you are a father
column3: and your kid is screaming because he wants ice cream
column4: the dog is barking because somebody is calling at the front door and you are trying to book a quick train ticket that should leave in 40 minutes. In that specific moment
column5: people will not give a f* about your subtle cues. On the other side
column6: we should use them
column7: but not when it kills the user flow.

column1: Focus group is a small group of people that sit around at the table and discuss things. They talk about their opinions about the product
column2: past experiences
column3: their feelings and reactions to new concepts. Focus groups are great for determining what your audience wants.

column1: A usability test is about watching one person at a time trying to use something (your product in this case). In this case
column2: you ask them to perform specific actions to see if you need to fix something in your concepts. So focus groups is about listening and usability tests are about watching.

column1: All of us who design digital products have the moment when they say ‚Äî ‚ÄúI am a user too
column2: so I know what is good or bad.‚Äù And because of that
column3: we tend to have strong feelings about what we like and don‚Äôt.

column1: We enjoy using products with ______
column2: or we think that _____ is a big pain. And when we work on a team it tends to be hard to check those feelings at the door. The result is a room full of people with strong personal feelings on what it takes to design a great product. We tend to think that most of the users are like us.

column1: It is not productive and will not add any value if you ask questions such as: ‚ÄúDo people like drop-down menus?‚Äù. The right question to ask is: ‚ÄúDoes this drop-down menu
column2: with these words
column3: in this context
column4: on this page create a good experience for people who are likely to use the site?‚Äù

column1: The reason for that is if we focus on what people like
column2: we will lose focus and energy. Usability testing will erase any ‚Äúlikes‚Äù and show you what needs to be done.

column1: The point is that every question that pops into our head
column2: when using your product
column3: only adds up to the cognitive workload. It distracts our attention from ‚Äúwhy I am here‚Äù and ‚Äúwhat I need to do‚Äù. And as a rule
column4: people don‚Äôt enjoy solving puzzles when they merely want to know if that button is clickable or not.

column1: And every time you make a user tap on something that does not work
column2: or it looks like a button/link but it‚Äôs not
column3: it also adds up to the pile of questions. And this happens because who built the product did not care too much about the product.

column1: I can‚Äôt think of a better place to start unraveling the weird and confusing world of modern UX Design than this: Not even the originator of our field knows what to call himself anymore.
De-obfuscating modern UX requires understanding the history of both design and development since the 1990s. They‚Äôre intrinsically linked
column2: so it helps to start just a few years after it all began.

column1: In its purest form
column2: UX Design is waterfall based.

column1: A product team working through the waterfall methodology sets out to learn everything they possibly can before building even the simplest prototype. Research can take months
column2: or even years to complete; and the results dictate a design team‚Äôs execution. The requirements lock before design kicks off
column3: and design locks before development kicks off. There‚Äôs no going back
column4: not until version 2.0. That‚Äôs just how waterfall operates.

column1: A classic UX process is usually taught to college students. It goes like this:
That‚Äôs basically a waterfall. The classic elements of UX (Jesse James Garrett) also follow a waterfall schema
column2: building an execution from the bottom up based on well articulated requirements.

column1: The problem is that classic UX is fundamentally incompatible with agile.
For a long time innovation in the Silicon Valley was driven by Moore‚Äôs Law
column2: which states that the number of transistors in a dense integrated circuit doubles approximately every two years. Superimpose a waterfall process and you‚Äôll notice that it fits nicely into a 24 month cadence. Business
column3: design
column4: and development cycles worked like a Swiss timepiece; perfectly attuned to the release of a new Intel chipset.

column1: Then one day Sony
column2: Toshiba
column3: and IBM (The STI Alliance) decided that Moore‚Äôs Law was too slow.

column1: STI created the first cell chip
column2: which stacked 8 microprocessor cores on a single wafer
column3: and the damn thing actually worked (it powered the Playstation 2). Multi-core architecture changed everything.

column1: Moore‚Äôs law didn‚Äôt break
column2: it got life-hacked. What did break was waterfall.

column1: Almost overnight speed and flexibility replaced precision and predictability as competitive advantages. Companies turned en masse to another well established but underutilized development methodology: Agile.
Agile focuses on rapid iteration. It releases a new set of shippable increments (features) every 2-4 weeks
column2: evolving a product over time instead of all at once. It‚Äòs based on hypothesis
column3: experimentation
column4: rapid release
column5: and real-time measurement. In Agile there is no editing stage
column6: there is no perfection. As Bre Pettis put it in 2009... done is the engine of more.

column1: Waterfall‚Äôs painstaking ‚Äúmeasure twice
column2: cut once‚Äù approach went out of style faster than a StarTAC in a room full of iPhones.

column1: Classic UX operated on a waterfall cadence.
With feature releases happening once or twice a month there wasn‚Äôt time to wait for UX Designers to execute their process. In Agile nomenclature
column2: UX became a blocker
column3: and it was a bad one.

column1: Faced with an immovable block most teams simply abandoned UX. In its place they hired young graphic designers who were capable of turning out assets on a two-week cadence. Those designers weren‚Äôt real UXers
column2: not in the classic sense
column3: but they knew just enough about user centered design to avoid making the worst types of mistakes.

column1: That was okay with product development teams. The details
column2: they figured
column3: would work themselves out through iteration.

column1: Care to take a guess at what the Agile title for that type of designer was?
If you answered ‚ÄúUI/UX Designer‚Äù give yourself a cookie.

UI/UX Designers were at the heart of the storm when Apple proved that a design-lead business could become the most valuable brand in the world. They carried the torch of UX when UX itself couldn‚Äôt sharpen a pencil inside of a two-week sprint
column2: let alone design a feature.

column1: It came at a cost though.
The UI/UX bias towards digital and graphic design badly skewed the business world‚Äôs perception what an experience designer does. To this day
column2: far too many businesses still think of UX as a visual discipline. As Don Norman has been trying to explain
column3: that‚Äôs incorrect.

column1: Things didn‚Äôt start to get better until 2013.
Lean UX was Jeff Gothelf‚Äôs game changing answer to the problem of practicing UX in an agile environment. In his seminal masterwork
column2: Jeff turned the entire field of UX on its head. The book introduces a series of strategy and alignment activities
column3: which allow UX to operate inside of agile‚Äôs cone of uncertainty and rapidly update designs based on user feedback.

column1: Whereas classic UX is requirements based
column2: Lean UX is outcome based. If you need a quick primer on how that works
column3: O‚ÄôReilly has a free chapter available online that breaks things down in no-nonsense terms.

column1: Lean UX wasn‚Äôt perfect though. While UX was now able to harmonize with an agile cadence
column2: the lean model broke down if a product was vaguely defined (basically anything un-launched).

column1: Designers found themselves under immense pressure to fill a sprint backlog before they really understood what they were building. As a result
column2: a lot of development cycles got burned on features that never made it into the final product. In project management circles
column3: the Lean UX / Agile pairing was known for a high volume of waste and rework when attempted under less than ideal conditions.

column1: In a mature product there is lots of user feedback coming in
column2: which does wonderful job of driving the iterative cycle that powers Lean UX. That‚Äôs why Lean UX is the industry standard on almost any established product team. Nobody in their right mind would change a thing.

column1: On establishing teams
column2: however
column3: the user feedback cycle has yet to ignite itself. The waste and rework problem in those circumstances was serious enough that it often crippled the adoption of Lean UX. This presented a real conundrum for startups and skunkworks units that wanted to ensure a strong UX component without reverting back to a waterfall cadence.

column1: Jake Knapp and Google Ventures came out of the sky like a bolt of lightning and solved the problem with the design sprint. Nobody saw it coming. Nobody cared. The long dark night of UX was finally over.
Addendum: The design sprint has its roots in the IDEO human centered design process
column2: which is closely linked to Stanford and the d.school there. McKinsey authored a similar type of sprint using the same conceptual roots. All of that traces back to Stanley Pollitt and the roots of user-centered design in advertising but that‚Äôs a story for another day.

column1: If you were to look at a design sprint and say ‚Äúwait
column2: that‚Äôs just really fast classic UX‚Äù you wouldn‚Äôt be far off the mark. The difference (and genius) is that it‚Äôs classic UX at an incredibly low fidelity. It‚Äôs the difference between an artistic masterpiece and a napkin sketch ‚Äî but it works.

column1: The goal of a design sprint is to take all of the existing research about a problem
column2: unpack its essence to a diverse group
column3: then ideate like crazy. The ideations are then funneled through the lenses of human centered design and those that survive are voted on by the team. Designers then build a low-fidelity prototype (often in just one day) that is just barely good enough to test on potential users. The results of the test
column4: if positive
column5: create a target for designers to hit in high-fidelity; thus fueling the Lean UX/Agile cycle.

column1: Magic.
IMPORTANT: dual-track agile often refers to the split between research and design in a Lean UX environment. I‚Äôve updated this article to refer to dual-track design in hopes of reducing confusion.
So now we come to the point of modern day UX methodology.
As you might expect
column2: dual track design has two tracks (a Sherlock Holmes level deduction
column3: I know
column4: don‚Äôt everybody gasp at once):

column1: A production team is typically running on track two unless the backlog becomes poorly defined. If that happens
column2: the problem is assessed and the team runs a design sprint. Problem solved.

column1: But where does that assessment come from if the production team is busy practicing Lean UX?
The most effective answer is to put a dedicated team on it. While design & development pumps out iterations
column2: a research team investigates the results much more comprehensively in the background. Because that research team isn‚Äôt bound to an Agile sprint cadence they still have the luxury of taking 3 months to reach a conclusion.

column1: Every few months a fresh infusion of new insight will hit the production teams
column2: filling their backlog with new ideas for experimentation. At one of the companies I work with
column3: we‚Äôve now got a whole data science team feeding knowledge to multiple creative units. The insight is infrequent
column4: as researchers have much longer delivery cycles
column5: but when it comes down the line it‚Äôs wonderful.

column1: Sometimes the insight is big enough to trigger a design sprint
column2: which significantly evolves a product vision. Most of the time
column3: however
column4: it just adds additional kindling to the fire of Lean UX experimentation.

column1: So yes
column2: dual track works best when a dedicated research team is working outside the scope of the active product group. You‚Äôve probably surmised that it‚Äôs an expensive undertaking. You‚Äôre not wrong.

column1: What I can tell you is that it‚Äôs less expensive than the alternatives: operating without UX or dealing with the waste and rework problem of pure lean.
Fund it out of your savings.
So what is a UX Designer in a dual-track world?
A UX Designer is a leader
column2: a process evangelist
column3: a generator of insight
column4: a purveyor of context
column5: and a creative ideation machine. UX Design
column6: as I‚Äôve said elsewhere
column7: doesn‚Äôt really have any deliverables other than value. It has come to encompass dozens of job titles that have hundreds of their own deliverables though.

column1: Most of us aren‚Äôt actually UX Designers unless we lead a team
column2: rather
column3: we work in the field of UX Design.

column1: It‚Äôs enough to confuse anyone.
It‚Äôs enough to exasperate even Donald A. Norman.
