column1: This article is my attempt at describing what makes a design document great.
The article is split into 4 sections:
A design doc ‚Äî also known as a technical spec ‚Äî is a description of how you plan to solve a problem.
There are lots of writings already on why it‚Äôs important to write a design doc before diving into coding. So all I‚Äôll say here is:
A design doc is the most useful tool for making sure the right work gets done.

The main goal of a design doc is to make you more effective by forcing you to think through the design and gather feedback from others. People often think the point of a design doc is to to teach others about some system or serve as documentation later on. While those can be beneficial side effects
column2: they are not the goal in and of themselves.

column1: As a general rule of thumb
column2: if you are working on a project that might take 1 engineer-month or more
column3: you should write a design doc. But don‚Äôt stop there ‚Äî a lot of smaller projects could benefit from a mini design doc too.

column1: Great! If you are still reading
column2: you believe in the importance of design docs. However
column3: different engineering teams

column6: style
column7: and process of a good design doc.

column1: A design doc describes the solution to a problem. Since the nature of each problem is different
column2: naturally you‚Äôd want to structure your design doc differently.

column1: To start
column2: the following is a list of sections that you should at least consider including in your next design doc:

column1: The title of your design doc
column2: the author(s) (should be the same as the list of people planning to work on this project)
column3: the reviewer(s) of the doc (we‚Äôll talk more about that in the Process section below)
column4: and the date this document was last updated.

column1: A high level summary that every engineer at the company should understand and use to decide if it‚Äôs useful for them to read the rest of the doc. It should be 3 paragraphs max.
A description of the problem at hand
column2: why this project is necessary
column3: what people need to know to assess this project
column4: and how it fits into the technical strategy
column5: product strategy
column6: or the team‚Äôs quarterly goals.

column1: The Goals section should:
Non-Goals are equally important to describe which problems you won‚Äôt be fixing so everyone is on the same page.

column4: it was published in 1956 by the cognitive psychologist George A. Miller of Princeton University‚Äôs Department of Psychology in Psychological Review. column5: sourced from wikipedia:

column1: Moreover
column2: the human mind can remember ~7 bits of information when completing a task that requires cognitive effort. This is critical
column3: because humans are constantly performing tasks
column4: and trying to juggle various stimuli in the mind when doing so. One of the key concepts behind Miller‚Äôs Law is ‚Äòchunking‚Äô
column5: which basically means assembling various bits of information into a cohesive gestalt. For example
column6: the word ¬∑ p e n c i l ¬∑ is actually a ‚Äòchunk‚Äô of letters

column8: and is the basis for our UX and organizational rule.

column1: Always organize elements of information in categories no larger than 9

column1: Here‚Äôre the Gestalt principles which can inform today‚Äôs UI design.
Elements arranged close to each other are perceived as more related than those placed further apart. This way different elements are viewed mainly as a group rather than as individual elements.
We can use the Proximity principle in UI design for grouping similar information
column2: organising content and decluttering layouts. Its correct use will have a positive impact on visual communication and user experience.

column1: As the principle states
column2: items that are related should stay close to each other
column3: while the unrelated items should stay further apart. White space plays a vital role here as it creates contrast guiding the users‚Äô eyes in the intended direction. White space can boost visual hierarchy and information flow

column1: We can apply the Proximity principle pretty much everywhere from navigation

column4: body text and pagination.

column1: Similarly to the Proximity principle
column2: elements placed within the same region are perceived as grouped.

column1: The Common Region principle is particularly useful. It can help with information grouping and content organisation

column1: A good Common Region example would be the card UI pattern; a well defined rectangular space with different bits of information presented as one. Banners and tables are good examples as well.
Elements sharing similar visual characteristics are perceived to be more related than those not sharing similar characteristics.

We tend to perceive similar to each other elements as grouped or a pattern. We also might think that they serve the same purpose. Similarity can help us with organising and classifying objects within a group and linking them with a specific meaning or function.

Jason Clau√ü - UX Renegade|8|7|https://uxplanet.org/youtube-isnt-altering-your-comments-yet-ca7cf2ef22db?source=---------6---------------------|YouTube isn‚Äôt altering your comments... yet. ‚Äì UX Planet|So states Hanlon‚Äôs Razor:
We‚Äôd all do well to keep that truism in mind when considering the following scenario. This video was published on YouTube on October 21st
column2: claiming that YouTube was altering user comments in real time.

column1: The implications of this video are disturbing
column2: to say the least. In the wake of this video
column3: there was indeed a flurry of conspiracy theories
column4: with the general gist that left-leaning tech megacorporations are experimenting with thought control techniques. It certainly didn‚Äôt help that Google has hired some rather shady characters (read: raving Marxists) in the past.

column1: It isn‚Äôt hard to see how algorithmic comment editing could be used for evil. AI could detect a certain political position based on the content of a post
column2: then either re-word it to tweak its meaning
column3: or ‚Äî even scarier ‚Äî embed typos and grammatical errors to slowly discredit anyone who holds a specific view. Perhaps the incident in this video is just an early AI misstep.

column1: Or perhaps it was all a misunderstanding. Which it was.
As it turns out
column2: the actual explanation for what happened in that video is a lot less sinister... but it should be just as interesting if you are a UX designer.

column1: Perhaps you noticed when the guy said:
That‚Äôs because it was Google Translate. Let me explain a few things.
First
column2: the translation gaffe here most likely involved Russian. Because Russian uses the Cyrillic alphabet
column3: and because English speakers probably don‚Äôt want to bother typing Cyrillic characters
column4: Translate attempts to transliterate Latin approximations of Russian words into Cyrillic. For instance
column5: ‚Äú–¥–æ —Å–≤–∏–¥–∞–Ω–∏—è‚Äù (Russian for ‚Äúgood bye‚Äù) would be most accurately transliterated as ‚Äúdo svidaniya‚Äù
column6: however many people might misspell the first word as ‚Äúda‚Äù. Translate will attempt to factor in that error
column7: and creatively interpret the text based on what it thinks the user meant.

column1: Second
column2: Google Translate has the ability to translate a whole page from a foreign language to whichever language you choose. That can be very useful but only when the user is aware that it is happening. Unfortunately
column3: Translate‚Äôs ability to actually figure out the context language of a page is quite bad. It also seems completely oblivious to the notion that a page may have several languages written on it. Google Translate will decide which language is the dominant one on the page
column4: then translate everything it sees that is not your native language.

column1: Thus
column2: the sequence of events in the video likely went like this:

column1: The proof that this is what happened can be found if you type that guy‚Äôs exact comment into Google Translate in ‚ÄúRussian to English‚Äù mode.
Case closed. Sort of.
And now we come back to Hanlon‚Äôs Razor.
This particular incident did not come about as the result of sinister machinations. That doesn‚Äôt mean that it does not represent a significant problem
column2: nor does it even mean that there isn‚Äôt a hint of the sinister lurking beneath the surface.

column1: Let‚Äôs start off with the obvious: the tech industry needs a viral rumor about Orwellian censorship like it needs a hole in the head. Through their own doing
column2: the big tech brands currently enjoy a reputation approaching that of Bank of America in 2009. Somewhere between Zuckerberg experimenting on his users
column3: Twitter enlisting a rogue‚Äôs gallery of villainous organizations to form their ‚ÄúTrust and Safety‚Äù Council
column4: and Google demonetizing harmless channels
column5: not to mention the fact that every one of them collaborates with the Chinese government
column6: which still maintains pictures of a certain clown-haired mass-murderer on their buildings
column7: the tech giants are increasingly seen as the evil corporations from 1980s cyberpunk flicks.

column1: Combine that with the fact that there is a general apprehension about the notion that we are in a ‚Äúpost-truth world‚Äù (we aren‚Äôt)
column2: and you have a powder keg awaiting some scandal to ignite it.

column1: Your typical UX designer or product manager can‚Äôt do much about that whole issue
column2: unfortunately. Nor can designers prevent programmers from building sloppy algorithms that lead to misleading errors. You‚Äôre just going to have to work around these realities by minimizing the chances that a design blunder will be misconstrued as a digital atrocity and tank your employer‚Äôs stock value
column3: or even put them on the hit list of a regulatory agency.

column1: Here are three takeaways from this story that you would ignore at your peril.
Dan Saffer
column2: author of Microinteractions
column3: refers to modes as ‚Äúa fork in the rules‚Äù. When a particular interaction can behave in multiple ways depending on a certain variable
column4: it has multiple modes. One ubiquitous mode is ‚Äúedit mode‚Äù
column5: found everywhere from the iPhone‚Äôs text message screen to Medium‚Äôs articles. In edit mode
column6: you no longer merely consume the information on the screen
column7: but you can alter it.

column1: Misunderstanding of what mode you are in can cause all sorts of problems. If you don‚Äôt realize you are in ‚Äúedit‚Äù mode
column2: you might accidentally delete a text message thread. If you don‚Äôt realize your keyboard is in Caps Lock mode
column3: you might send off a reply that makes you look UNHINGED.

column1: The case of the altered YouTube comments is a clear-cut example of mode confusion. The user thought he was in original text mode
column2: when in fact he was in Russian-to-English mode. Simply making it more obvious to this user the mode he was in could have prevented the entire fiasco.

column1: Currently
column2: this is how Chrome indicates that you are in translation mode:

column1: That‚Äôs it. A single
column2: tiny mystery meat button in the URL bar. What are the chances that the user will even notice it? Why not text that states ‚ÄúTranslating Russian to English‚Äù?

column1: What I gather from this particular incident is that the user was unaware that translation was even a possible explanation for what happened
column2: which suggests that he did not ask for a translation of the page. I don‚Äôt know enough about the underlying software to know if he ever manually set the browser to always translate Russian to English
column3: but if he did not do so
column4: that is a big problem.

column1: The more you take control away from the user
column2: the less they will understand the way your system works
column3: and the less they will trust it. In the short term
column4: you may believe that you are taking a load off the user‚Äôs shoulders
column5: however over time
column6: they will begin to question what is happening
column7: especially if anything should go wrong
column8: which it will.

column1: While political motivations played no role in this incident
column2: users‚Äô distrust of YouTube and Google has partly political origins. And it isn‚Äôt just about corporate-level skullduggery. Tech products are often designed in ways that transparently betray the creators‚Äô personal values
column3: and even impose them on the user.

column1: One infamous example is Apple‚Äôs autocorrect. If you have ever wanted to throw your phone into a wall because it corrected you to ‚Äúducking‚Äù for the 300th time
column2: you know what I‚Äôm talking about. Apple does not allow you to train the autocorrect and autocomplete to reflect your personal linguistic values. Is it such an outrageous stretch to go from the soft censorship of autocorrect to the hard censorship of public comment Bowdlerization?

column1: Even though
column2: in this case
column3: the user was mistaken
column4: Google got themselves into this mess. Lucky for them the rumor was quickly squelched and that was that. They might not be so lucky next time.

column2: particularly people who design products. Day after day

column5: and what it means to product and service design. I‚Äôll also raise the possible implications of this phenomenon on organizational management

column7: and general performance. The psychological phenomenon I will be discussing in this article is known as Miller‚Äôs Law. Rather than just tell you what Miller‚Äôs Law is
column8: I ask you to take part in this exercise for a more immersive learning lesson.

column1: Read the italicized instructions before starting. Grab a pen and paper. This is an exercise where you will try to recall words you‚Äôve just read
column2: off memory.

column1: Below is a list of 20 words. Read them to comprehension
column2: and try to memorize as many as possible. Try to keep the words ‚Äòin your head‚Äô. Do not write the words. Spend about a minute. After you are done reading
column3: scroll down until you see the word ‚ÄòSTOP‚Äô. Then
column4: read step 2.

column1: Now
column2: use your pen and paper to write down as many words as you can remember from the list. Think hard
column3: but do not scroll back up to view the words. If you scroll up

column5: scroll back up and check how many you got right.

column1: If you are like the vast majority of human beings
column2: you will have remembered 5‚Äì9 of the words. Hundreds of experiments prove universality of this limitation on memory. When I first discovered this phenomenon
column3: I knew it had huge implications on product design
column4: because of the degree to which this limitation affects day to day tasks. This capacity for keeping ~7 bits of information ‚Äòin the head‚Äô short term
column5: is known as Miller‚Äôs Law.

column1: In 1956 there was a paper written that became one of the most highly cited papers in psychology. Titled
column2: The Magical Number Seven
column3: Plus or Minus Two: Some Limits on Our Capacity for Processing Information
column4: it was published in 1956 by the cognitive psychologist George A. Miller of Princeton University‚Äôs Department of Psychology in Psychological Review. The crux of the paper suggests that the number of perceptual ‚Äòchunks‚Äô an average human can hold in working memory (a component of short-term memory) is 7 ¬± 2. This is frequently referred to as Miller‚Äôs law. Here is a summary of the article
column5: sourced from wikipedia:

column1: Moreover
column2: the human mind can remember ~7 bits of information when completing a task that requires cognitive effort. This is critical
column3: because humans are constantly performing tasks
column4: and trying to juggle various stimuli in the mind when doing so. One of the key concepts behind Miller‚Äôs Law is ‚Äòchunking‚Äô
column5: which basically means assembling various bits of information into a cohesive gestalt. For example
column6: the word ¬∑ p e n c i l ¬∑ is actually a ‚Äòchunk‚Äô of letters
column7: organized into a perceptual gestalt. If the letters were rearranged ¬∑ c n l i p e ¬∑ it would be six separate chunks of information. Chunking is a critical element of information organization
column8: and is the basis for our UX and organizational rule.

column1: Always organize elements of information in categories no larger than 9
column2: but preferably ~5 chunks.

column1: The more chunks of information you add to an ‚Äòinterface‚Äô
column2: the more difficult it becomes to ‚Äòwork‚Äô
column3: using the information at hand. This is especially critical for first time users
column4: because they haven‚Äôt had the ‚Äòpractice‚Äô needed to encode the interface into long term memory
column5: or
column6: for the behaviour to become habitual. I constantly see this rule being broken by giants like Facebook
column7: Google
column8: and Wordpress. Don‚Äôt even get me started on automobile interface design. The ~5 bit chunk rule also compliments minimalism as a rigorous design philosophy. To expound
column9: due to the limitations of working memory
column10: as a product becomes more feature-full it inevitably becomes more difficult to use
column11: because the user has to manage more information while operating the product. This makes good information design so critical.

column1: Millers Law also highlights the importance of foresight and proper planning in the design process
column2: because as you add more features to a product ‚Äî your interface must be able to accommodate those new features without breaking the visual foundation of what you built. Rebuilding a foundation takes immense time and resources.

column1: Another perceptual phenomenon observed in relation to Miller‚Äôs Law is known as the primacy
column2: and recency effect. These terms are used respectively to describe how we remember items sensed at the beginning and end of an experience
column3: more than ones in the middle. For example
column4: if I were to show you a list of words
column5: you would more likely remember the words at the beginning of the list
column6: and the end. This is also known as the serial position effect. From wikipedia:

column1: This observation raises huge questions in business and design. If people remember more at the beginning and end of an experience
column2: how do we enhance the positives
column3: and mitigate the negatives at these respective times? When does an experience truly begin and end? Should we be organizing more important elements at the beginning and end of lists due to their increased retention? These are all valid questions that UX designers and executives should ask when inventing or developing their product.

column1: Millers Law can be applied to any aspect of your life that involves performing a mildly complex task. By reducing the amount of elements in your reach/access ‚Äî and keeping them organized by relevant chunks not exceeding 9 bits
column2: your brain will be able to remember exactly where things are so you can access its functionality. When lists of items grow too large
column3: they become very difficult to mentally map them
column4: requiring the user to do more cumbersome searching.

column1: The adherence to Miller‚Äôs Law is especially relevant in the light of lean methodologies and recent trends in tech and UX. Users want and need a trial before they purchase something ‚Äî it‚Äôs that simple. If they don‚Äôt experience the value within the first day or week of using it ‚Äî they won‚Äôt buy. Since new users do not have lengthly time to learn where everything is ‚Äî information design needs to be planned and well thought out before development happens.
We live in a world with an exponentially increasing amount of information. By not organizing it properly
column2: or eliminating some completely
column3: it ultimately degrades our ability to complete critical tasks for the purposes of survival (navigation/gaining income). That is why it‚Äôs so useful to omit items
column4: products
column5: and services from your life that aren‚Äôt giving a quality return on investment. This falls in line with the Pareto principle
column6: the idea that 80% of your outcomes comes from 20% of your investments. Are you juggling too many tasks per day to be efficient? Is your team using too many tools to collaborate? Do you have too many members on your team? Are you overloading your new employees with information
column7: leading to confusion?

column1: Millers law teaches us that humans have a finite amount of information they can process
column2: and that information overload will lead to distraction that negatively affects performance. Companies should look for ways to organize information in a way that is much more digestible for their customers and employees. This could be by eliminating tools or applications that are producing cognitive overload
column3: reducing the amount of members on a team
column4: or even organizing your departments based on our knowledge of working memory.

column1: This is especially true in new science of the concept of flow
column2: made famous by psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi. Flow is a word Mihaly coined to describe a state of concentration or ‚Äòabsorption‚Äô with a specific task that humans ultimately find rewarding
column3: pleasurable
column4: and fulfilling. He describes it as an optimal state where we perform at our best and truly live ‚Äòin the moment‚Äô. One sure way to kill flow is by increasing distractions in the workplace. So
column5: do you think that by giving your employees more tools
column6: that it actually enhances performance? Miller‚Äôs Law teaches us time and time again this is not the case. When it comes to completing tasks
column7: less is more.

column2: a colleague of mine named Mariko Sugita needed to hire a designer for a website she was creating. She‚Äôs an urbanist
column3: and not particularly involved in the digital design field

column1: I thought for a moment and realized that I had several possible answers
column2: none of which quite summed up the full scope of roles that are present in our field today and what each designer‚Äôs assumed title really says about their abilities.

column1: That started me thinking about what exactly the spectrum of digital design roles really looks like here in Common Era 2018. I started sketching out my ideas. When Mariko saw my notes for this article
column2: she said
column3: ‚Äúyes
column4: that‚Äôs exactly what I wanted to know beforehand!‚Äù I hope that this overview can be just as useful for you

column1: It would be irresponsible to casually lump designers into groups without qualifying that no two designers are the same. I‚Äôm taking a moment here to borrow an idea from a great post by Sam Jarman on dev.to
column2: who in turn got the idea from The Soft Skills Engineering Podcast. The basic concept is that rather than thinking that any person‚Äôs skills are just T-shaped ‚Äî the idea that they have a broad understanding of many things and a deep understanding of one thing ‚Äî their skills are instead better understood as a line of wet paint drawn across canvas.

column1: The paint forms a broad line across the top layer of the canvas
column2: signifying a base level of understanding of many fields
column3: but it also drips down in many places
column4: in different depths
column5: which represent the varying depths of different skills that a designer has. The point is that every designer has varying degrees of ability in different skills based on their experience
column6: whether that‚Äôs vector design
column7: digital prototyping
column8: user research
column9: coding
column10: motion graphics
column11: or anything across the entire creative spectrum. Therefore
column12: the title they call themselves on paper can‚Äôt possibly hope to define their philosophy and scope of experience.

column1: I hear you loud and clear. So
column2: with the knowledge that we will never truly represent the full scope of any one human with a single deterministic title
column3: let‚Äôs try to define some singular
column4: deterministic titles.

column1: All sarcasm aside
column2: here begins an honest look (in my own
column3: personal opinion) at what kind of design roles are generally being seen out there in the wild.

column1: ‚ÄúBut Jasper
column2: you just finished saying that T-shaped designers don‚Äôt exist!‚Äù Yes
column3: I did. And they don‚Äôt. But if you want to laser focus in on hiring a person to do a specific thing for you
column4: you might as well find someone who describes themselves as a specialist. You can usually count on someone who goes by one of these titles to do that specific task at a very high level of quality.

column1: Also
column2: yes
column3: I put front-end developers on a chart about designers. There‚Äôs enough blurring of the line between designer and developer these days that I feel like it‚Äôs important to have a baseline of where the full-time devs stand on the spectrum.

column1: One note on reading these charts: the upper line of a role represents the common breadth of that role
column2: while the shade beneath represents varying depths of ability along the spectrum.

column1: Here we start to blur some lines into generalized roles
column2: especially the role of UX Designer which I‚Äôve seen take on an incredible breadth of definitions in the past few years. These tend to serve more as catch-all terms
column3: and it‚Äôs not always easy to be sure what a designer going by this title is skilled in. This is where portfolios and interviews can back up a vague title with solid examples of what exactly this designer brings to the table and how strong their skills are on visuals
column4: implementation
column5: and ideation.

column1: These are the ones who can do it all
column2: but they have to spread their knowledge and expertise across multiple fields in order to do it. Often people in this category got there by necessity ‚Äî maybe they worked at startups that demanded they perform roles outside their expertise
column3: or they had personal projects where they had to cover all the bases themselves.

column1: Some designers are quick to naysay the possibility of one person being a master in several fields simultaneously. I tend to think that those with exceptional experience or talent can tackle the challenge
column2: especially because they tend to understand the full scope of the roles around them better than other designers. It‚Äôs a matter of understanding that this designer brings breadth over specificity to the table
column3: and helping them succeed accordingly.

Tom Hall|3.6K|11|https://uxplanet.org/how-to-choose-a-user-research-method-985112051d84?source=tag_archive---------5---------------------|How to choose a user research method ‚Äì UX Planet|‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your process?‚Äù
This is a question that you‚Äôll often get from prospective clients
column2: or in an interview for a UX design position. Of course
column3: your exact process will end up being at least a little bit different for just about any UX design project you undertake. Whatever your full answer may be
column4: as I recently wrote
column5: user research has to be a part of that process. In most cases
column6: you just can‚Äôt afford not to do it.

column1: What‚Äôs less clear is what kind of user research you should do. There are a lot of different techniques to choose from
column2: each with different strengths
column3: weaknesses
column4: and research goals. This article is intended to give a quick rundown of how to decide on what your research goals are
column5: and what techniques you can use to achieve those goals.

column1: The most important question to ask yourself before deciding on what research methods to use is: What do I want to know?
How do you go about answering that question? You could start by asking yourself why you want to learn that thing. Identify what you already know about your users
column2: and what you don‚Äôt know about them. What are your knowledge gaps? Some examples of useful questions that you may or may not already know the answers to:

column1: Once you know what you‚Äôre trying to learn
column2: you can start thinking about how to learn it.

column1: One way to break down the methods
column2: suggested by Christian Rohrer
column3: is on two axes: Attitudinal vs. Behavioural studies
column4: and Qualitative vs. Quantitative studies. In attitudinal studies
column5: you‚Äôre trying to find out what people say about a subject
column6: while in behavioural studies
column7: you‚Äôre analyzing what people are actually doing. Qualitative methods tend to be stronger for answering ‚Äúwhy‚Äù types of questions
column8: while quantitative methods do a better job of answering questions like ‚Äúhow many‚Äù and ‚Äúhow much‚Äù.

column1: For example
column2: if you‚Äôre asking the question: ‚ÄúHow many users give up partway through our sign up process?‚Äù
column3: then you might want to consider a more quantitative
column4: behavioural study.

column1: Tomer Sharon has offered a different framework for categorizing research questions
column2: which I‚Äôve found very useful. He suggested that there are broadly three types of questions that UX research is helpful for answering:

column1: You need to understand what your product should be doing (the needs and wants of users) before worrying about whether the product is doing that thing correctly (usability).
So
column2: which techniques can you use to answer each question type? I‚Äôm going to break some of them down below. This is by no means an exhaustive list of user research techniques
column3: and some of these techniques could be used to answer more than one of the question types
column4: but nevertheless it should provide a good starting point.

column1: A quick aside: Before starting any user research project
column2: it‚Äôs important to keep a couple of things in mind:

column1: Also called observation
column2: or a site visit
column3: contextual inquiry involves studying people as they go about their everyday lives or tasks. If you‚Äôre performing a contextual inquiry study on engineers who produce intelligent piping and instrumentation diagrams
column4: you would go to their office and watch an engineer go about their job. Have them show you how they do things. Ask them questions such as ‚ÄúHow do you do that?‚Äù or ‚ÄúCan you show me how you did that?‚Äù to try to dig more deeply into how they‚Äôre accomplishing their tasks.

column1: Take notes about what they‚Äôre doing
column2: what difficulties they face
column3: and your own thoughts on it all. You want to try and get into their head to help understand their needs and expectations
column4: but try not to interrupt them more than necessary. As much as possible
column5: you should be trying to observe what would they typically do to accomplish their tasks.

column1: I‚Äôm going to lump ethnographic research in here as well. Ethnographic research tends to focus more on social groups and how they collaborate or interact together
column2: but it has a lot of overlap with contextual inquiry and can be useful for answering some similar types of questions.

column1: In user interviews
column2: you‚Äôll typically meet with users
column3: one at a time
column4: and ask them questions relevant to your project. Usually this is done quite early in the process
column5: and it can be useful for reviewing your product goals. You need practice to get good at interviewing users. Questions often have to be asked in the right way to get good responses
column6: you have to know when to follow up and dig in to an answer
column7: and you have to be able to listen well. You should definitely have an interview protocol or script prepared beforehand.

column1: Remember that during an interview
column2: users can often make up an opinion that they don‚Äôt actually feel strongly about. They can also talk a lot about things that don‚Äôt actually matter to them
column3: which can be misleading.

column1: One technique that can help with this is called the critical incident technique. Your interview subjects may remember some specific cases where the product worked particularly well or poorly
column2: and can often provide more vivid details about these incidents. You can use this to get an idea of the strengths and weaknesses of your product when it comes to helping users accomplish their tasks.

column1: You can also use interviews to help you identify questions to ask in a broader questionnaire or survey. On the other hand
column2: you can use interviews after you‚Äôve seen the results of a questionnaire and want to dive into some of those questions more deeply.

column1: Surveys and questionnaires can provide you with some answers similar to what you‚Äôd get from user interviews. The downside is that you don‚Äôt have the ability to dive more deeply into those answers as there‚Äôs no direct interaction with the users. On the plus side
column2: they allow you to get a larger volume of responses
column3: which can open up the opportunity for more quantitative analysis.

column1: Just like in user interviews
column2: you need to be careful about how you‚Äôre writing your questions. You‚Äôll want to keep the survey as short as you can while still getting the information that you want; if the survey is too long
column3: you may find that you don‚Äôt get as many responses as you‚Äôd like. Surveys can be relatively inexpensive to run
column4: and there are a lot of survey tools out there to choose from.

column1: A diary study can be used to see what users do and how they interact with your product over a longer time frame. Diary studies can often be used as a follow up to a contextual inquiry or an interview
column2: to get some additional information from some of the more engaged and informative users that you encountered.

column1: In some cases you may ask users to take photos
column2: scrapbook
column3: or other similar activities. You have to make sure that you give the users good instructions so that they‚Äôre clear on what they should be doing
column4: and follow up with them at certain intervals to try to keep them engaged.

column1: In A/B testing
column2: you create two variations of an element of your product
column3: such as a registration form. The variations could be represented by anything from a simple paper prototype to a live website. You then define a metric that will measure the success of each variation that you‚Äôve created. For example
column4: you could measure the bounce rate or the NPS of a landing page.

column1: Next
column2: you run an experiment with users where one group sees ‚ÄúVersion A‚Äù and another group sees ‚ÄúVersion B‚Äù. Using the metric you defined
column3: you‚Äôll measure which version was more successful. That‚Äôs the one the users want. You can do this process with more than just two variations
column4: in which case it‚Äôs called multivariate testing.

column1: You can use A/B testing to examine a wide variety of things
column2: such as:

column1: A/B testing is an excellent and powerful user research tool. There‚Äôs a lot of nuance to doing an A/B test correctly
column2: so make sure you‚Äôre designing your study appropriately and that you‚Äôve brushed up on concepts like statistical significance so you know when to stop the study.

column1: The idea behind rapid prototyping is to get your designs in front of users early and often. Rapid prototyping is done iteratively
column2: in a three-step process:

column1: The more you can do this early on
column2: the less you‚Äôll (ideally) need to make changes during development
column3: when it can be far more expensive.

column1: The fidelity of your prototypes can vary. You might start out with paper
column2: and end up with pixel-perfect high-fidelity mockups. In some cases you might even use some live code.

column1: If you‚Äôre going the paper route
column2: you can put together a sketching kit and start drawing. You can use products like UI Stencils to give you a head start if you feel like you can‚Äôt draw particularly well. You can also use an app like Marvel to make your sketches interactive.

column1: Paper prototypes allow you to test your designs quickly
column2: cheaply
column3: and easily. If you have a real budget crunch
column4: this can be a good way to go. However
column5: it‚Äôs worth keeping in mind that it can be distracting for users if your prototype is too low fidelity. Jake Knapp actively discourages paper prototyping with users
column6: saying that:

column1: Depending on your skill level with your design tool(s) of choice
column2: you might be able to jump directly to high fidelity prototypes. Whichever direction you take
column3: the important thing is to get prototypes in front of users
column4: learn from how they respond to it
column5: and iterate.

column1: Of course
column2: this isn‚Äôt always going to be possible
column3: as some systems are just very difficult to prototype. At ThinkUX
column4: we worked on a VR project where we simply weren‚Äôt able to meaningfully prototype and test some parts of the system before implementing them in code.

column1: I could easily write an entire article about the pitfalls of focus groups. There‚Äôs no shortage of such articles out there. Among the primary issues with focus groups are observer dependency
column2: which is when the researcher reads their own feelings into the results of the group discussion. There‚Äôs also groupthink
column3: and the fact that some particularly vocal members of the group can make it seem like there‚Äôs a consensus even when some quieter members of the group disagree. Further
column4: it‚Äôs worth emphasizing once again that there can be a significant difference between what people say and what they do.

column1: However
column2: when done correctly
column3: focus groups can uncover a lot of very useful information. One of the most interesting results can be discovering a customer language that can help you to understand and describe similar experiences that your users shared. Having a group of users together can also help them to jog memories and ideas in each other that they may not have otherwise remembered.

column1: According to the Nielsen Norman Group
column2: if you do only one type of user research on your project
column3: it should be qualitative usability testing. In usability testing
column4: you recruit some users
column5: come up with a list of tasks for the users to accomplish
column6: and set them loose on your system (or prototype). You can do this formally (create a screener
column7: schedule participants
column8: have them come into your lab
column9: record the session
column10: etc.)
column11: or with guerilla usability tactics.

column1: You should test with approximately 5 users
column2: as beyond that you‚Äôll start to see diminishing returns. At the conclusion of a usability test
column3: you‚Äôll often find that parts of your design worked
column4: but that users uncovered problems that you‚Äôd never have thought of
column5: and a lot of things need to be tweaked or reworked. This is why it‚Äôs so important to test your designs with real people.

column1: Card sorting is a technique that can help a lot with your information architecture. Write down the major features or topics for your system on cards
column2: then recruit some users and ask them to organize the cards into categories that make sense to them. You can do open sorting
column3: where participants put the cards into groups and then name the groups themselves
column4: or closed sorting
column5: where you give them defined categories to sort the cards into. The results of a card sorting study can help you to decide the structure of your website
column6: how to label your menus
column7: how to group your content
column8: and so on.

column1: Card sorting can be done in person with index cards
column2: or using an online tool such as Optimal Sort. If you‚Äôre doing the study in person
column3: the most difficult part will likely be analyzing the results
column4: particularly if you‚Äôve recruited a large number of participants.

column1: You‚Äôll typically recruit more users for a card sorting study than with a usability test
column2: but don‚Äôt go overboard here as you‚Äôll tend to get diminishing returns beyond 15 or so users.

column1: Tree testing is another research technique that will help you to assess the information architecture of your product. It can (and likely should) be used along with a card sort. Tree testing helps you to answer questions like:
In a tree test
column2: users navigate the site to complete tasks (e.g. ‚Äúbuy a sweatshirt‚Äù) using only links ‚Äî the user interface is stripped away entirely. If
column3: through previous research
column4: you‚Äôve found that users aren‚Äôt reaching an important page on your website
column5: a tree test can help you to determine if the issue is caused by a problem with your information architecture or by something to do with your UI.

column1: At the end of the study
column2: you‚Äôll end up with metrics such as task success rate
column3: failure rate
column4: time to complete the task
column5: and what routes users took through the site tree before selecting an answer (correctly or incorrectly).

column1: Before you can decide on what research techniques you‚Äôre going to employ
column2: you need to figure out what you‚Äôre trying to learn
column3: and why you want to learn it.

column1: Again
column2: this is not an exhaustive list of UX research techniques. There are a lot of different ways to attack a given problem
column3: but this article should help give you some idea of what techniques you can use in your research
column4: and what kinds of questions they can help you to answer.

My design soul will likely suffer eternal damnation. And
column2: like Judas Iscariot
column3: I‚Äôll be forever haunted by the sound of thirty pieces of silver rattling about in my pocket. Forgive me father
column4: for I am about to sin...and I have sinned.

column1: After more than a decade of projects gone afoul
column2: designs that never made it to development
column3: concepts that should have never made it beyond being a concept and the snail‚Äôs pace of many projects I have worked on
column4: this article is long overdue. I‚Äôd like to be able to write an article placing the blame somewhere other than the UX teams I have worked with. But
column5: that wouldn‚Äôt be honest or true. It wouldn‚Äôt be a confession. Often times
column6: it has been my team or myself to blame for failed projects or projects that could have yielded better results.

column1: At the outset
column2: I must state there is a lot I like and love about UX and design in general. But
column3: there is also a lot that gets under my skin. UX can be a great solution to the problems an organization faces with their products in the market. But
column4: UX can also be part of the problem. I have often become part of the problem.

column1: In life
column2: I have generally found solutions do not come without cost. You often solve one problem and create another. I have seen the same thing happen with UX design in organizations. We solve a lot of problems when introduced to an organization
column3: but often create more via our very existence.

column1: So
column2: I‚Äôm ‚Äúbreaking bad‚Äù with UX. Specifically
column3: I‚Äôm outlining the mistakes I have made and have seen teams make ‚Äî mistakes that inhibit the final product and user‚Äôs experience. In parallel
column4: I am pushing against some of the dogmatic philosophies inherent in our profession. This article is where I see UX go awry. It‚Äôs also a short list of things that irk me about the profession. This is an article about flouting the maxims
column5: thinking for yourself and sometimes
column6: just sometimes
column7: going against the crowd‚Äôs conventional thinking.

column1: Paradoxically
column2: these are all transgressions I have committed in my own past. My sins. These are the confessions of a UX designer.

column1: I don‚Äôt know how my mind dysfunctions. But most of the time when someone gives me a rule
column2: I automatically question it or try to break it. This isn‚Äôt always true. Early in my career
column3: I would follow the rules of UX to a tee. I didn‚Äôt know any better and was too green to have experiences where the rules didn‚Äôt work or to know they weren‚Äôt applicable to the situation.

column1: We‚Äôre designers. We are thinkers. Rules are little more than cognitive offload. Now
column2: I am not suggesting there aren‚Äôt any good design rules or there are not any rules you should follow in UX design. I am merely suggesting we think before we mindlessly follow a design rule.

column1: Here are just a few UX rules you can find in a quick search:

The rules above are less rules than guidelines. Consistency for the sake of being consistent is simply being stupid as I point out below. There is a time to use fake copy and a time not to. Fake copy can actually be advantageous in circumstances when you don‚Äôt want the content to get in the way. It is generally true that you are not the user. However
column2: there are research methods where being the user is appropriate and adds another point of data to your research. It‚Äôs called immersion. And
column3: research of any type is only one point of data. Users do not always tell you what they need nor know what they need. And the seven plus or minus two rule is a classic example of a research study being misinterpreted or
column4: as even Edward Tufte puts it
column5: not read.

column1: It seems like every week or month
column2: a new trend starts in our profession and shortly thereafter
column3: it will become our ‚Äúgolden calf‚Äù until it‚Äôs forgotten or the next new thing comes along. I get tired of rules ‚Äî especially when they are mindlessly followed. I got tired of following the rules and realizing they don‚Äôt always work.

column1: Designers don‚Äôt follow rules all of the time. In fact
column2: they often break rules to create ingenious designs. This
column3: of course
column4: comes with experience. Design is part art and part science. And
column5: great art often breaks rules.

column1: About once or twice per year
column2: I notice an uptick in the UX community on a certain topic. A few people come across an idea or concept in an article or perhaps a presentation at a conference and slowly you‚Äôll see a larger group running to jump on the bandwagon. A few years ago
column3: the hamburger icon became one of those topics.

column1: The basic essence of the argument against the hamburger icon cited low discoverability
column2: lack of recognition and lack of engagement in A/B testing
column3: making a case users just didn‚Äôt understand or use the hamburger icon. Ultimately
column4: the demonization of the hamburger icon was a bit of a boring argument and was based on some pretty weak studies. It ignored the fact that an icon becomes an icon through its pervasive presence. An icon is a language. It‚Äôs a symbol representing a concept just like a letter represents a sound.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: a good percentage of the profession jumped on the bandwagon and demonized the hamburger icon. Lean UX was another trend a few years ago and despite trying to move our profession out of the ‚Äúdeliverable business
column3: ‚Äù a brief internet search will quickly reveal we‚Äôre still in the deliverable business with plenty of writings on UX deliverables.

column1: Mobile design is probably my favorite example. This is where teams chase that shiny object and employ a technology simply because it is there. I have been on numerous mobile design initiatives that were complete failures. Hell
column2: even I thought some of them were a good idea at some point. But
column3: I have been burnt so many times that I now scrutinize any proposal for a mobile design with extra vigilance. Just because you can put your design or product on a mobile device doesn‚Äôt mean it should be on one. It‚Äôs a trend teams like to embrace because all the other monkeys are doing it too. Monkey see
column4: monkey do.

column1: If you spend a lot of time surfing the net and regurgitating the last article you read on a specific topic (like I spent so many years doing)
column2: you‚Äôll quickly find it isn‚Äôt much different from the current fashion you are wearing. About 5‚Äì10 years from now
column3: you‚Äôll look back at a picture of you sporting those new pants and the shirt you thought was so cool only to laugh at how dated you look. The UX bandwagon is no different. Five years from now
column4: you‚Äôll no longer believe even so much as half of what the current rage in our profession is.

column1: Some trends will stay in our profession. Those are usually theories based on sound foundational principles ‚Äî the principles of our profession from decades of research and application. They‚Äôre like 501 Levis and a solid print t-shirt. They‚Äôll never go out of style. But
column2: most trends will fall by the wayside. Following them will often lead you and your project astray.

column1: As a general rule of thumb: Stay off the bandwagon
column2: stray from the crowd and step to the beat of your own music ‚Äî no matter how measured or far away. And as for those trending concepts that do stick around or seem to hold some validity ‚Äî make sure you aren‚Äôt adopting them just because everyone else is. Don‚Äôt build a mobile app for a user base who would benefit more from a desktop application. Don‚Äôt adopt an idea based on an article you read citing a weak study or misrepresenting a study. In short
column3: critically and strategically evaluate the concepts you add to your repertoire.

column1: I don‚Äôt know if it is a UX designer personality trait to be pedantic and detail-oriented. I don‚Äôt think so because I know a lot of designers who aren‚Äôt. But
column2: I‚Äôve never encountered a profession where discussions over minute details go on ad nauseam and occasionally even stop a project.

column1: Yes
column2: the little things count. I concede to that. And when you have the time and resources to address the little things
column3: you should. But what I see far too often is UX teams coming unglued over the little things while they ignore the larger problems. It‚Äôs as though the house is on fire and we‚Äôre worried about the storage shed in the backyard.

column1: I‚Äôve had long discussions over toggle switches versus checkboxes
column2: radio buttons versus drop menus
column3: rounded versus square corners
column4: save dialogs with multiple options
column5: colors
column6: button placement
column7: grids and more. Long discussions. Discussions lasting weeks or months. Email threads longer than the arms and legs of an NBA All-Star.

column1: There is an appropriate use and there are guidelines for each of these examples. And sure
column2: if you have the time
column3: money and resources to entertain the finer details in a design
column4: then have at it. But if you have bigger fish to fry
column5: your resources and energies are better placed elsewhere.

column1: But
column2: here is where I always land: Does it truly impact the user experience? Does the user really care whether the corners are rounded? Will that impact their experience? Do they care if all of your components snap to a grid? I‚Äôve spent a lot of time in the field on various projects and it is rare I find a user who comments on some aspect of a feature I had discussed ad nauseam with my team. It‚Äôs usually something I never even thought of that turns out to be problematic ‚Äî something we should have spent more time discussing
column3: but didn‚Äôt.

column1: I confess to being sucked into this in the past and even recently. I‚Äôll get into these discussions (most of them surrounding the visual aspects of an interface) and they‚Äôll go on forever. We‚Äôll set up a small team to ‚Äúinvestigate‚Äù these issues or test a group of users. But at some point
column2: I‚Äôll be sitting there while the discussion drones on and think about how this really impacts the overall design. Usually
column3: it doesn‚Äôt and has very little impact on the user experience from a holistic perspective.

column1: Always ask yourself this one question: Is this an issue
column2: given all of the other issues I have to address
column3: that will impact the user?

column1: Consistency is important. But
column2: I firmly believe the law of diminishing returns comes into play with consistency. How much time are you willing to spend with each screen to ensure absolute consistency? Time is money and will that time spent give you a good ROI?

column1: Obviously
column2: if you have a total lack of consistency between screens and the system doesn‚Äôt even look the same from one screen to the next
column3: it will cause a myriad of problems. But if you are a few pixels off on button sizing from one screen to the next
column4: will this truly impact the user experience? It‚Äôs sloppy design
column5: absolutely. But
column6: it won‚Äôt kill the product on release.

column1: I‚Äôm not suggesting we ignore consistency or the little details I note above. I am only proposing a fair balance between the energy we spend on these things and the return on our investment. If you are working with Atomic Design in a large system
column2: how much upfront work will you do versus the time you will save in designing and amending the design? If it is done right
column3: you can probably reap a greater return on your investment. But at some point
column4: the law of diminishing returns will take effect.

column1: Consistency must also be contextually dependent. Consider a search component in a system. Let‚Äôs suppose you define how search should work and then state it should work the same throughout the entire system you are designing. This seems logical right? We would want search to work the same across a system and not trip the user up by switching up the functionality. The only problem with this is we have now prioritized consistency (as a primary heuristic) over the user experience.
Wait a minute
column2: you might ask. Aren‚Äôt heuristics supposed to support the user experience? Yes. When they are used as a guide or rule of thumb they do. When they are strictly applied they may not. In the search example
column3: a different search functionality could be warranted in different parts of a system depending on how complex the search needs to be
column4: how many results may be returned and the size of the database being searched.

column1: Don‚Äôt fall into the trap I have fallen into where you have screens taped up on every wall and spend weeks or months going through them with a fine-toothed comb to gain consistency. This often evolved into a major effort for me and upon release
column2: I discovered larger items I could have been managing instead.

column1: The context of the user‚Äôs experience should be prioritized over consistency. Component or symbol consistency in a system should not become so rigid it does not afford the opportunity to design for the context in which the user is employing that functionality. Being consistent for the sake of being consistent is often just one more way to not use your brain when designing for the user experience.
This may be more of an organizational problem than a UX problem. But
column2: almost every team I have worked with over the course of my career has allowed themselves to be sucked into the release cycle ‚Äî including myself. Yes
column3: you have to release a product and you have to set a deadline that will allow your team to build a product with the time and resources you have. But when the focus is solely on the deadline at the expense of building a great experience and product
column4: you have essentially sold your soul to the company store. Don‚Äôt let the deadline be the spurs that drive you forward.

column1: I have rarely seen a project make its deadline. It happens ‚Äî but not very often. That means there is room to play with a project timeline (since they are usually poor projections driven by financial concerns and put in place by projects managers who don‚Äôt understand the complexities involved in a feature or product). This means you do have the time for that research you wanted to squeeze in or that next iteration of the design.
Yet
column2: this is really about where our focus lies and what we end up chasing in the process of building a product and experience. We often become so focused on deadlines
column3: milestones and release dates
column4: we forget what our true mission is. Nothing annoys me more than a project manager at my desk suggesting we aren‚Äôt going to make a milestone or deadline and we‚Äôll be red-flagged as a result. The deadline is not the goal.

column1: In my case
column2: I have to constantly remind myself I am working on a patient experience. That is my ‚Äúprimary directive.‚Äù I am not showing up each morning to make a deadline for the next sprint. That goal is secondary. My highest loyalty must be to the patient experience.

column1: Here‚Äôs the rub: You can meet the deadline
column2: make all the bean counters and project managers happy and still build a shit product. I‚Äôve done this. I have run the whole race and crossed the wrong finish line a number of times in my career. It‚Äôs not a win. It‚Äôs me sitting at the finish line wondering how in the hell I ended up here.

column1: Stop focusing on the deadline and put your sights on the user experience. Make sure you are running in the right race and on the right track.
If I have to listen to one more debate over design tools and how one tool is better than another
column2: I think I might hang myself by one of my unworn neckties. I had the displeasure of working with a consulting team not too long ago who had the audacity to suggest using one tool would give our team a competitive advantage in the future workforce. Such rubbish. I don‚Äôt know if they were getting kickbacks or if they had just drank too much of their own Kool-Aid.

column1: I grew up with a mechanic ‚Äî my father. (He‚Äôs really more of a mechanical engineer than a mechanic.) But
column2: I always remember all of the tools he had ‚Äî some of which I didn‚Äôt even know what they did. There was a set of tools for every job. I learned by watching him and riding along on his trips to the Sears Craftsman store when he would need some special item. UX is no different. A design tool has a specific purpose and needs to fit the job.

column1: Some tools are better for prototyping and others are better for visual design. You can‚Äôt beat a whiteboard and dry-erase marker to get ideas down quickly. A lot of our choices are very subjective. And
column2: if there is any profession that should know how personal and subjective this choice is
column3: it should be UX.

column1: The mark of an experienced and rational designer is knowing which tool to use in which scenario. Religiosity around tools is simply dogma with no real scientific basis underlying these claims. So
column2: stop sending tweets and writing articles debating which tool is better. If you want to make a useful contribution to the profession
column3: write an article about a design tool‚Äôs features and how you used it in a project to solve a specific problem creating a kick-ass experience.

column1: No one ever actually says it. But
column2: the attitude is often evident even if unspoken. It‚Äôs often territorial. We wouldn‚Äôt want anyone infringing on our space or replacing us
column3: right? It‚Äôs this attitude only those formally trained (or those who hold a job title with UX in it) can design.

column1: We‚Äôve all been there. A business analyst or a developer shows up to your desk with a rough sketch of an idea they have. And
column2: many of us have turned our nose up to these people ‚Äî effectively ostracizing them from our privileged ranks. Who are they to propose a potential solution? I‚Äôve done this and was once a UX snob. I didn‚Äôt want anyone to do anything closely resembling my work.

column1: Fortunately
column2: most of us mature a little and realize this is not only a great way to develop a shared understanding
column3: but also a method of increasing collaboration and rapport with other teams. But
column4: I routinely encounter those insecure UX designers who believe anyone with an idea not bearing the title or training of a UX designer should be pushed out of the circle as quickly as possible. This is simply the wrong attitude to have. These are usually the same types of designers who will spend an inordinate amount of time advocating for UX in an organization and wondering why no one wants to work with them.

column1: As controversial as it may seem (and was at the time)
column2: Jared Spool stated:

column1: As a designer working in healthcare UX
column2: I have generally found this statement to be true. The design of a product or service is often not rendered as I originally intended
column3: having been influenced by other teams. Is it so far fetched to believe we build and design a product as a team through our shared understanding of what we are attempting to create? I think not.

column1: If you are having trouble advocating for UX in your organization and looking for acceptance
column2: ensure you aren‚Äôt a UX snob. Your career (and designs) will go a long way if you concentrate on building relationships and bringing different viewpoints (via other disciplines) to the table.

column1: UX is an evolving profession. That‚Äôs probably a good thing. Were we steeped in centuries of tradition (like medicine
column2: for example)
column3: we‚Äôd probably have a whole different set of problems. But
column4: we are still finding our way. And
column5: we‚Äôre finding our way in a new world where communication can be enabled through the click of a publish button on the web. We are still finding our space in a profession that
column6: once
column7: largely operated without our assistance. And
column8: we are still attempting to figure out how we integrate ourselves into the product development process.

column1: To accomplish what we need to accomplish requires us to understand more than just our profession. It requires us to see a larger picture
column2: to think bigger and to always maintain a center of balance. That center of balance must connect our daily activities to how it impacts the user experience. That impact falls within what we create and it falls beyond our designs as well. Focusing on the wrong details (details that have little or no impact on the user experience)
column3: ostracizing ourselves
column4: employing narrow-minded thinking and embracing the latest trends regardless of their foundational validity will do little more than have us designing in circles.

column1: Yet
column2: these are my confessions as well ‚Äî all transgressions I have committed. I have fallen in all of these traps. And though I would like to say I‚Äôll move forward without falling into future traps
column3: I know I will not live without sin. Ten years from now (likely sooner)
column4: I will have an entirely new list of confessions to make. I am not alone though. May the gods of UX have mercy on all our souls.

column2: KRISTEN DUDISH
column3: ELENA GIANNI
column4: KELLEN HENRY
column5: MELISSA LODER and DAN SHERMAN

column1: For many of our readers
column2: the New York Times desktop home page is an important and familiar place to connect with the news each day.

column1: It hasn‚Äôt changed much over the last decade
column2: even as the story formats we use
column3: the platforms we support and the ways our readers consume content online have rapidly evolved.

column1: We‚Äôve invested heavily in making our mobile apps expressive and visually dynamic
column2: but our desktop website has lagged behind
column3: powered by a siloed and aging set of tools.

column1: These fractures in workflow and technology have meant our newsroom editors and our engineering teams had to do duplicate work across multiple systems for our mobile apps and our desktop website.
They weren‚Äôt the only ones. Whenever readers switched between devices
column2: they were met with different reading experiences
column3: which made it hard for them to follow their interests and gave them an inconsistent experience with our brand.

column1: In a few weeks
column2: we will update our desktop home page experience as a final step to bringing readers a consistent experience across all of our platforms and screens. Readers who visit us on mobile have already seen many of the changes. But with the desktop rollout
column3: readers will be able to engage with the stories that interest them most on all of the devices they read The New York Times.

column1: We started our home page project with plenty of data about what people chose to do there
column2: but it was more difficult to tell from the numbers why they made those decisions.

column1: As a product and design team
column2: we always want to go beyond what readers say they like and dislike to understand how reading
column3: watching or listening to our stories fits into their lives.

column1: We realized that in order to help our readers go deeper
column2: our team had to engage deeply with our readers. We visited them at their homes and got to know them. Then we asked them broad questions about how the the news fits into their day ‚Äî or doesn‚Äôt.

column1: We came away from those interviews with a better understanding of three major needs our readers wanted to fulfill on our home page:
We also came away with a strategy for how to help our readers meet those needs.
Readers said they wanted us to curate their experience on the home page
column2: but not limit it. We needed a system that empowered them to follow their own interests. At the same time
column3: readers wanted our help to navigate a chaotic world of information overload and filter bubbles.

column1: We used those insights to begin sketching out possible ways to address reader needs that also mapped clearly to our mission and goals.
While we design layouts and custom-made typography with care
column2: we also know what truly makes or breaks the reading experience is the content itself. Our readers told us loud and clear: what matters is access to New York Times journalism.

column1: To test our initial concepts
column2: we needed to see how they would hold up with real news flowing through them. So we created a series of prototypes to gather feedback from a small panel of readers.

column1: Our first round of prototypes were pretty crude. We built them quickly
column2: with the intention of testing our assumptions and threw most of them away after gathering data. We started out with simple paper prototypes. (Our favorite was a cardboard and paper iPhone we nicknamed ‚ÄúThe pPhone.‚Äù)

column1: The more prototypes we built
column2: the more confidence we gained. We knew we probably weren‚Äôt going to get everything right the first time (spoiler: we didn‚Äôt). But we also knew how much we could learn when we got things wrong.

column1: Once we gained confidence through paper prototyping
column2: we moved on to a higher-fidelity web prototype and recruited a few news editors to run it using some bare-bones publishing tools.

column1: While our readers helped articulate the original needs that inspired our designs
column2: our prototype editors were instrumental in stress-testing our concepts. They gave us feedback on how well the stories they wanted to highlight fit into our proposed structure and helped us calibrate what areas of the page needed to be elevated or suppressed.

column1: Having editors join the conversation early on helped us quickly understand what was working and what might be missing. The editors were also candid with us about standard newsroom practices and internal dynamics that we needed to consider. The first time a major story broke
column2: we learned that our system and tools would need maximum flexibility to support a wide variety of news scenarios.

column1: Throughout this design process
column2: many members of our product
column3: design and engineering teams also volunteered to curate the home page for a day to gain first-hand experience of what the home page workflow was like under the constant pressure of breaking news. Embedding directly with our news editors showed that we were committed to making our home page work for them and gave us plenty of empathy for what it takes to produce the home page every day.

column1: By working closely together
column2: we developed a version of the home page that was polished enough for wider distribution. To prepare for a larger-scale rollout to a subset of readers
column3: we worked with our internal tools teams to build more realistic tools that let the newsroom curate the new version of the home page.

column1: While we always planned to launch a fully responsive home page
column2: our early tests left us most confident in our new features at the mobile breakpoint. We solidified and rolled out our changes to all mobile readers in October of last year.

column1: Creating the right layouts to scale our newsroom curation efforts up to more complex desktop and tablet layouts took our team another cycle of iteration. With mobile fully live
column2: we launched our initial desktop concepts to a small percentage of readers
column3: and studied metrics and qualitative survey feedback closely
column4: while making adjustments.

column1: Early in our desktop test
column2: we focused on showing readers the breadth of our coverage. We limited the number of prominent stories at the top of the page and used layouts that highlighted more of our photography. The page layout was airy and encouraged readers to scroll more.

column1: But readers pushed back. While they didn‚Äôt want to be overwhelmed
column2: they were eager to see more related news stories in order to get a complete picture of the day‚Äôs news.

column1: The ratio of photography to information also felt off. In a news cycle where much of our major news came from Washington D.C.
column2: the photos of politicians in suits soon felt repetitive and stale from day to day.

column1: In order to give readers a more nuanced picture of the news and editors the flexibility to choose which visual and text elements to highlight
column2: we developed a system of tools and layouts that let editors group a few related stories into a ‚Äústory package.‚Äù

column1: Creating a system for packages that would work across every device and support all of the possible grouping combinations was a complex design and development task
column2: but it ultimately gave us more flexibility to create strong presentations for every news situation.

column1: It also helped the page look more dynamic for readers because there was more depth and density at the top of the page.

We also added visual differentiation between hard news stories and softer features to help readers quickly distinguish between types of content. This provided a better visual rhythm on desktop where stories are frequently displayed side by side.

Our home page update is a significant step forward in helping our readers meet their needs across all of their devices. Our investments in a new technical architecture will make the site faster for readers and more flexible for our teams. We are confident that the system of story groups and packages we‚Äôve created will allow us to continue evolving the experience in ways we can‚Äôt even imagine today. We‚Äôve created a system that‚Äôs rooted in highlighting both what our readers feel is important to read and what they want to read. Best of all
column2: it can grow and adapt as those needs do
column3: too.

column1: What to write? Use your design thinking skills. When you‚Äôre applying to work for me

column1: Here‚Äôs how to write a letter that will get you noticed.
First

column1: The very first sentence should tell me why you‚Äôre writing me ‚Äî even if you‚Äôre applying through an online job portal. Include the name of the job
